b'"Just Married" is a painfully cheesy film that is almost too light and cute. Ashton Kutcher and Brittany Murphy play a couple of Romeo and Juliet - esqe that has been rehearsed in so many movies, it\'s disgusting - he\'s the classic dorky sports fan and the kid of middle-income parents. whose job never teaches us. Her parents would have rather married the snob Peter Prentice, a dull antagonist who is more a roadblock than a real character. Anyway, the pretty couple gets married and flies to Europe where their lies and their incredible circumstances (they are expelled from a hotel after spoiling the circuit while trying to plug some kind of sex toy) perfect honeymoon. The film was made worse by bad jokes, boring characters and clich\xc3\xa9 & egrave; scenarios. I think I considered laughing once. The terrible thing about this movie was how amazing everything was. Each character was able to draw a magnificent and comforting monologue. Most of the speeches did not even match the personality of the character, for example, Kutcher\'s character gave at least two of these monologues, and each was one of the best parts of the film\'s script. Too bad they came out sounding inevitably and awkwardly, since the character is not supposed to be the brightest bulb in the box. Finally, the characters were painfully underdeveloped. We do not know if Murphy\'s character likes to be rich or not, and we can never really discern whether she\'s a rich girl or an art lover. We never find out what Murphy\'s father does, and although a good father-son relationship is evoked between Kutcher\'s character and his father, we never know. Finally, a pretty blonde was constantly around the character of Murphy ... was she a sister? friend? cousin? It pestered me throughout the movie. So, why not 1 star instead of 2? Well, Murphy and Kutcher have been great actors with amazing chemistry. Murphy has especially illuminated the screen with his dazzling personality and his cute and squeaky voice. Kutcher will always be considered an idiot, but he is a character that fits him well. I found them to be the only highlights of the film. It was fast and slightly pleasant, but something was missing or something different. See if you like girls, not if your idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8ba movie is the one that will make you think.'

b'I may not be able to add much to the critics, which I fully share the praise of the content of this beautiful film, but I still felt compelled to offer my two cents on BluRay, this which is just as fantastic. With the full measure of the glory of the backdrop of this story now rightly restored in HiDef, the drama inherent in the script now, finally, finally, a canvas just as worthy of being presented - a fact that has been perpetually lost on all the other video presentations I\'ve seen before. In fact, it is an impressive revaluation of the anticipated impact of this film and, from all previous editions of this video, a transformation of a first-rate adventure of acceptable magnitude to an adventure of the first order. a remarkable show! I dare say it did not sound so good when I remember seeing it in my local theater years ago. Besides, it looks so good, I do not think anyone can dream, as soon as it appears here, that this film marks its 50th anniversary. From the opening credits, I find that the film was shot at 70 mm, so with much more detail than the most common 35 mm films. You can expect similar performance in HiDef with other 65 or 70mm movies, like 2001: A Space Odessy or Lawrence of Arabia - IF disk transfer is good - and it\'s certainly the case here. The image as part of this disc is still and completely as stable as the Rock of Gibralter. There was only the slightest amount of flicker, as seen in my setup, but, again, rarely and barely noticeable when she was seen - still not sure whether the record was really to blame or no. Not a hint of moir\xc3\xa9, nowhere. The sound is rather good and much better than I could have hoped. Although John Barry \'s beautiful score was apparently originally in mono, it is by far the best I\'ve heard of - it even has a better feel than the soundtrack (mono) available on CD, if I remember is good. However, the sound effects track on this disc is either a true stereo or, more likely, derived from various isolated sound effect elements, and then "panned" during post-production. There are even good extras: more than two documentaries on the making of the film, a commentary on the film, the trailer and even a brief but interesting interview with John Barry himself about the origin of his ideas for the film. partition. But overall, I love it so much when a film as majestic and monumental as this one receives the royal treatment it does here. Sometimes the presentation is everything! Highly, highly recommended! !'

b'I have been a 3D nut for several decades. I pre-ordered amazon and man, what a disappointment! The quality of the video is only slightly better than that of the 3D slide shutter bootleg DVD from the 90\'s (and at least the 3D DVD was FULL SCREEN), made from a 3D 3D VHD disc. Even the 3D "red / blue" trailer for this movie (from 3D Film Expo at the Egyptian Theater in Hollywood) was full screen. If you Google on this title, you will find some websites with photo comparisons (PAL, NTSC, DVD, Blu-ray, etc ...) and you can clearly see that this Blu-ray 3D collects the movie of ALL SIDES. Only a small number is cropped from left to right, but it lacks a bit of the top and bottom to create this ratio of 1.85 from the full screen. Part of the 3D perception is lost because of that, and that\'s probably what the others mean here by some scenes that look like "flat" or "2D". One of the most striking scenes is when Margot & Mark are chatting on the premises. This beautiful shot is obviously configured for the 3D effect. Margot\'s hand is resting on the end table in the foreground, showing this beautiful diamond ring. Guess what ? In this 3D Blu-ray version, his ENTIER hand is completely cut off! I continued to notice these cropped scenes throughout the film ... discarded characters, cut - out lampshades, and so on. Yes, it\'s great to see this red dress look really red, but unfortunately the colors are seriously oversaturated. I think I would not stick to the House of Wax or the FTBL Creature before other reviews of LOL guinea pigs arrive! I\'m sure others will agree that the black ink printed on the Blu-ray disc itself looks awful. I saw better labels on DVD bootleg! Anyway, just my 2 cents.'

b'If you look at the fine print on this DVD, you will see that it is not approved by the Wayne Foundation. And the picture quality of this DVD has all the features of being a DVD recording of a VHS copy of the movie. They did not even bother to use a new VHS tape - judging by the grainy texture and flaws (flicker, "hair" on the screen, etc.) annoying, they were captured from an old copy of the tape. I have a VHS tape that has a better picture than this DVD. Do not forget to write to the Wayne Foundation and tell them about the bad publication of this movie! If we make ourselves heard, we might be able to convince them to release the higher quality Criterion versions of John Wayne\'s lesser-known films. UPDATE: PLEASE NOTE! This review does not necessarily apply to the SPECIAL EDITION. Amazon mixes all McLintock! critics in one bag. I do not know what is the quality of the special edition (released in October 2005), but it is not necessarily the same as previous editions.'

b"If you want to be alone while watching Alone In The Dark, there is good news and bad news. The good news is that you will get your wish. The bad news is that misery loves the company. To be hanged by red nipple clamps on a cactus and scorpion fossa would be less painful than sitting through that household trash on Reid aliens as a museum curator. Pinch me, I must be dreaming.Make a pinch a slap in the face, and that's what this movie hokey movie offers you. Alone in the Dark is supposed to be based on an old Atari game, which I have never heard of. What I remember from the old Atari games is their graphics and their rudimentary intrigues. I doubt that the long story of the film was taken into consideration. To fill the gaps, writers Elan Mastai, Michael Roesch and Peter Scheerer borrowed and stole other films. Better movies Films that make you realize that you're not just looking at an imitation, but a very bad imitation, like Chuck Norris paying tribute to Judy Garland. I admit that his interpretation of Easter Parade made me cry, but only because he was kicking me in the face. That's what it was like to watch Alone in the Dark. I do not like stupid and stupid horror movies, but I hate stupid and stupid horror movies that refuse to acknowledge this fact. Alone in the Dark comes with such a poker face that it's impossible to know if we're supposed to take it all seriously. We are, but we are not, or more precisely, can = t. There is no room for maneuver in the scenario, direction or game. Government conspiracies abound (after a long operating session) in Alone in the Dark, where paranormal investigator Edward Carnby (Christian Slater) defeat an old evil. As an orphan, Edward escaped the clutches of unscrupulous agent / scientist Lionel Hudgens (Matthew Walker), whose depraved experiences turned children into cross-zombies. Now that Hudgens has found the final key to opening the portal between darkness and light, it's Edward, former lover and curator Aline Cedrac (Reid) and Burke (Stephen Dorff) commando chief of saving humanity. which I would call when the ultimate evil would decide to dirty humanity: two actors straddling this rail of direct video and an actress known for her flashing paparazzi. Was it a casting or refund decision? Director Uwe Boll (The House of the Dead) does not help much, never allowing actors to get out of the paper box or express an emotion beyond the written word. If everyone in front of or behind the camera had just recognized the obvious, Alone in the Dark would have been a hoot. Computer-generated monsters that never seem to occupy the same frame as the actors, joyful commandos, a complicated plot that makes no sense, paper doll characters, all the pitfalls of a good time. Dark did not fall into this trap."

b"I do not know who I'm sorry for, Stephen Dorff or Christian Slater. There is not a redemptive factor about Alone in the Dark, and if you surrender to the House of the Dead parody, then you know what to expect here."

b"This DVD attempts to cover in one hour the complete history of North American exploration. Given its purpose, I think it's a pretty decent job to do it. He summarized five hundred years of history and dozens of expeditions and explorers in brief information. I do not think this is a good teaching tool, because it would probably be somewhat uninteresting - it does not have very interesting stories, just a flow of information. Rather, it is a good starting point for those wishing to research North American exploration and would like an introduction to key events and people in its history. Not really something that excites people about history, people who see this should already be excited."

b'Before looking at this, do not make the mistake of putting this film on stage with ridiculous comedies like "Tootsie" and "Mrs. Doubt Although based on a true story, director Greenwald avoids several Western (and Hollywood) conventions to bring one of the best Westerns of the 1990s. Suzy Friends plays Jo, a woman who has a little confidence in some nasty men. After escaping to the west and leaving her son, she is almost raped by two soldiers. To hide, she wears men\'s clothes and scars on her face, possibly using her new facade to get what she needs in the west to survive. Ian McKellen embodies a woman who takes him, believing she is a young man. She ends up befriending Bo Hopkins, who has her best role in years, and starts a sheep ranch. She falls in love with a Chinese woman she has been forced to hire as a cook and eventually has to fight with a group of cattle to try to gain a foothold and hunt sheep farmers. Friends looks like Eric Stoltz in his man scenes. is totally believable. McKellan and Rene Auberjonois have modest but essential roles as an older father, who trusts Friends, but eventually turns on her. Bo Hopkins is great because the neighbor Friends tolerates, befriends and tolerates. David Chung incarnates the Chinese nicknamed Tin Man as a deficient man dependent on opium. It looks perfect for the party, the scars of life and everything. Heather Graham also has a small part as a Friends partner, and does her best with her. The most surprising aspects of this film are what the film is not. There are no cute scenes from "Yentl" where Friends falls in love with a man as a man. The war of cattle herders, a classic plot of the West, never goes beyond history or ends in a banal conclusion. The final scenes, with Jo\'s unmasking, look almost like joke, but when you think about it later, play very sincerely and touchingly, especially the Hopkins reaction. His script is also very clever, never leaving for cheap laughs or the kind of exploitation that a male director might have had. I highly recommend `` La Ballade de Petit Jo. "This is noted (R) for physical violence, gun violence, some sexual violence, violence, some profanity, some female nudity, sexual content, sexual references, substance abuse and adult situations.'

b'I bought this DVD without having seen it in the theater or on video. I bought it based on the strong reviews I\'ve seen on the top ten end-of-year lists. This is one of the few (only?) Big animated works that is not a musical. He relies solely on the strength of his characters to tell the captivating story of the young "Hogarth" (yes, Hogarth!) Who befriends a giant robot that landed on the ground in the 1950s. Naturally, the military and other adults are wary of the seemingly benign giant. The real strength of this film is that adults and children will enjoy it because it works on many levels. It\'s a devious commentary on 50\'s paranoia (without being cumbersome), an exciting adventure film and a humorous comedy for adults and children. Both will fall in love with the "Iron Giant" (played by Vin Diesal of "Saving Private Ryan") who will finally teach us things about loyalty and sacrifice. A word of caution for those who have very small children: there are some "damned" and "hell" (3 or 4) throughout the film; thus its PG rating.'

b"It was the franchise that slugfest fans thought never happened except in comics. After years and years of unsuccessful attempts and false starts, the powers finally come together. In the hope of capitalizing on the surprising success of merging two horror franchises with Freddy and Jaso, two of the most popular science fiction creatures compete in Alien. Predator with those annoying humans caught in the middle. There is no clich\xc3\xa9; that this movie does not like. Disposable characters are widely drawn. For example, a bottle cap worn around a character's neck is considered a characteristic feature. The film even manages to include this old chestnut where the characters exceed the explosion of a fireball. Fans waiting for the two extraterrestrial races to start beating will have to wait nearly an hour before their first battle, but it's impressive. like something in a comic book. Certainly the fight scenes are pretty cool in all their CGI-assisted glory, but that's hardly an endorsement. Poor Lance Henriksen is here a selfish businessman who provides the only human link with other Alien films (implying is the inspiration for the bishop android in Aliens). It may be only a quarter of the film before being shipped quickly. There is an audio commentary by writer / director Paul W.S. Anderson and actors Lance Henriksen and Sanaa Lathan. They are connected to the game, seemingly unaware of the narrative mess that constitutes this film. An audio commentary by visual effects supervisor John Bruno and creator effects creators Alec Gillis and Tom Woodruff Jr is also included. Anyone who likes to listen to such details will find this track informative. at Dark Horse 's Alien vs. Predator.Alien Series vs. Predator was not worth the wait and fans of the comics would feel cheated. The film begins slowly, but once the Aliens and Predators begin to fight, the weak scenario and the clumsy plot disappear in the background. It's a shame because these two extraterrestrial races are ripe for countless story ideas that the following sequels have not been able to exploit effectively. All we have left is a beautiful painting film by numbers."

b"If you have never seen THE EXORCIST, or if you have not seen it for a long time, this is a great opportunity to add this classic horror movie to your library! The plot involves the possession of a 12 year old girl by an old demon (is there another type). Murder, a dubious priest and a famous mom are thrown into the mix. It's as scary and realistic as you remember. On a special note, this DVD edition contains about a dozen minutes of cutting room footage - and that's a good thing. It was omitted at the time when movies were generally limited to two hours. The descent of stairs is particularly memorable, not to say too much."

b'"Battlefield Earth" is rightly considered one of the worst movies ever made. He makes "Manos, Hands of Fate" a profound, human and poignant drama about the suffering of a cult and "Plan 9 from Outer Space" sounds like a profound meditation on world peace and the dangers of science. . b"Great Milestones is an exploration of breeding habits and mating rituals of different types of animals. The interesting aspects of this subject are the way the Moon and the tides regulate and synchronize certain elements of the reproduction and how the weather conditions also play a role. Not only are terrestrial animals studied, but certain types of underwater creatures are also presented. In the second half of this documentary, parents protect and feed their newborns. Finish is a look at young animals leaving the house or nestling in the struggle to join the circle of life. In just 60 minutes, this feature may leave you wanting more. The sound, storytelling and video are pretty good in my opinion. No bonus features are available, with the exception of a few trailers from other programs. The chapters are a little short because of the time limit, but what is presented is nonetheless fun and enjoyable. As diverse as the animal kingdom, we hope that Reader's Digest will do more of these types of documentaries. If you are a fan of this type of subject, it is recommended to watch."

b"I bought this DVD as Christmas stockings for my husband. We watched it together in preparation for a future trip to Amsterdam. It was sometimes troubling because of the heartbreaking description of Van Gogh's severe mental illness. Anthony Quinn, who played the painter Paul Gauguin, and James Donald, who played Van Gogh's brother, also contributed to the pleasure of the film. The film was visually stunning and you could see the evolution of Van Gogh's art. I am looking forward to seeing Van Gogh's art in person."

b"Hellboy 2 continues the story of Hellboy and his work with a paranormal agency. He is still surrounded by friends and a new leader who reminds me of Doctor Who's Morbius brain. The years pass and humans forget the truce and take control of most lands of elves and trolls. The prince of the elves has decided that his father is too weak to do anything about humans and decides it is time to wake up the Golden Army. Filled with tons of action and a naughty look to be different, Hellboy 2 offers the benefits.The following special features are also included: 6 deleted scenes, Troll Market Tour, Commentary, set of tours and an animated cartoon epilogue ."

b"Hollywood werewolves have long been considered serious creatures who attack their victims like a Groucho Marx hirsuit. The image of this wolf-shaped werewolf was originally engraved by Lon Chaney and subsequent generations of actors simply continued his style. But with AN AMERICAN WEREWOLF IN LONDON, director John Landis not only pushed the werewolf on all fours, he looked like nothing more than a mobile tank top, but he also added a touch of humor needed to to force the spectators to detach themselves momentarily. from the gore to contemplate what they had just seen. David Naughton and Griffin Dunne are two Americans who make their way through a dark English moor at the exit of WUTHERING HEIGHTS of Heathcliffe. They are attacked by a screaming werewolf who kills Dunne but simply bites Naughton before he is shot by the villagers himself. This introductory scene where Naughton and Dunne are banished by a group of hostile drinkers is a confusing mix of scary fear and biting wit. It is precisely this same fusion of horror and humor that suggests that the viewer engages in extremes of emotions ranging from laughter to choking, the viewer sometimes having no choice. Jenny Agutter is a very underrated actress who shines like a nurse who falls in love with Naughton, and does not understand a radical change in her eating habits as he prefers more and more his extra rare meat. Agutter adds an unexpected dimension to a role that, on the other hand, the hand of a less competent director might have relegated it to little more than an English candy. Griffin Dunne provides visceral humor like a corpse that continues to emerge, like the ghost of Hamlet 's father, at the right time to remind Naughton that the price to pay for being free of lycanthropy may be a little too high. And then there is the music, played in the same vein as Simon & amp; The words of Garfunkle from THE GRADUATE, but here, the legend of Credence Clearwater Revival & quot; Bad Moon Rising & quot punctuates the eye of scenes of transformation that make a bad moon leads to bad vibrations. Finally, the special effects of Rick Baker are amazing in that you can see the bones lengthen, the sprouting of the fur and the nostrils stretching while Naughton is as scared as the audience. In the end, AMERICAN WEREWOLF IN LONDON is a werewolf-type revolution in that sight and sound combine to present creatures as helpless in their own way, while their victims are theirs."

b'Amazon to their complete discredit posts reviews of two totally different movies in one! There are two versions of The Big Trail: a 35-mm version that lasts 110 minutes and was released in 2003, and a new large-format version released in 2008 with a duration of more than 122 minutes. The important version, to add more confusion, comes with the first as a cabinet. Potential buyers must be informed! The "Full Screen Edition" will confuse many buyers - in fact, it is nothing like that, so I rate it as the lowest. The film, in its historical format, deserves a FIVE STARS! and can be purchased in the game called "The Big Trail Two Disc Special Edition", which includes not only this lower DVD version, but also the all-important and historic "WIDESCREEN EDITION" version of the film as was the first time. Again, I would easily rate this five-screen DVD big screen edition! The widescreen version lasts 122 minutes and is taken directly from the original 70 mm. The "Full Screen Edition" presented here as it is not a cropped version of the widescreen picture, but rather a 35 mm shorter version (110 minutes) shot at the same time by Fox for most rooms movies. day that could not turn the huge movie. Yes, it\'s a real movie and certainly a good movie until you see the 70mm. My low note is to draw attention to all these important details that are not mentioned in most positive reviews. Most of what makes this epic film scale is so much better appreciated in a widescreen format, and not the full-screen, totally confusing edition as it is proposed here. Lawrence of Arabia \'\' on something less than a 60-inch screen is like watching a colored ribbon stretched in the middle of the television. Faced with such a small image, it is understandable that many people opt for cropped or "full" screen versions instead of widescreen versions. But the goal of "The Big Trail" is the magnificent GRANDEUR format, a monstrous image of the breathtaking details of the vast panoramas that make up the film\'s backdrops. These are breathtaking images, worthy of consideration with the great black and white landscape photography of the best Western photographers in the West. If you have a big screen TV, just try "The Big Trail" in Widescreen on the Fox "Two Disc Special Edition". Once you\'ve seen the movie in its entirety on a good sized screen, you\'ll wonder why Fox first released the movie "The Big Trail" in 2003, in a "Full Screen Edtion" .To order the big screen version of "The Big Trail" and see a milestone event of the American filmmaking, something extraordinarily spectacular. The Big Trail My only complaint is Fox insists on joining the full-screen DVD to the Widescreen DVD and charging us two DVDs when most viewers want to see a single version.'

b"While the 2006 Le Mans DVD is similar to previous incarnations, the extremely poor video quality due to a large amount of distortion and pixelation makes it undoubtedly the worst of Le Mans DVDs. Tests and qualifying with a little over an hour dedicated to the race itself. However, the poor image quality makes this DVD almost like a VHS tape. Distortion and pixilation are sometimes ugly and really take away the pleasure of watching the race. If you compare this DVD to Le Mans DVDs covering the races of 2002 and 2003, the 2006 edition is definitely worse. Another complaint is that the DVD covers twice the highlights of the tests and qualifications, thus adding a lot of repetitions to the DVD. s 140 minutes of execution. It was a habit for the producers of this series, who participated in this show that was broadcast on the SPEED channel before its live coverage of Le Mans. This preview, which takes a little over an hour to cover tests and qualifications, gives the real beginning of the DVD, which turns into tests and qualifications. The lack of special features and onboard cameras is another disappointment. In the 2005 DVD, producers included for the first time embedded cameras (even though the DVD had slight pixilation problems). In the 2006 version, there are no special functions and the images taken by the onboard cameras do not exceed two seconds per car. It was good if the Audi R10 Turbo Diesel had a full lap in the car. Overall, I would recommend this DVD to all fans of Le Mans, as it is the best record of a race that saw Audi triumph with a diesel engine for the first time in 74 years of history. the race. He also does a good job showing all the racing action and all the drama and glamor that make up the annual endurance festival on the Circuit de la Sarthe. It's just disappointing that the quality of the picture is so bad."

b"The title comes from the idea that serial killers have graduate degrees in murder, although I would have thought that committing multiple acts would divert them to a postgraduate territory. The four murderers mentioned here - Charles Manson, Henry Lucas Lee, Ottis Elwood Toole and Kenneth Bianchi - receive disproportionate coverage. Manson is not seen at all, which can be a blessing considering the crazy interview that I saw him give. Henry Lee Lucas also makes a small shift, but his partner Ottis Toole may be the most troubling situation. Although convicted and jailed for what is considered an incredible 700 killings, with Lucas, Toole gives the impression that he has committed none. This does not mean that he is completely helpless, since he freely admits various acts of fire, but he claims to have confessed to the murders on the basis of the information provided by the police, that is to say that he wanted him to be guilty. The study by Kenneth Bianchi, known as Hillside Strangler, also addresses this behavior that psychiatrist Martin T Orne defines as textbook sociopathy. Although it is easy to believe that Bianchi, in his interviews, pretends, it is more difficult to accept than Toole, with his bumpkin character and his smiling facade. Maybe that makes Toole the best actor, Orne also thinks that Toole is a serial killer. Bianchi's initial defense for his murders was a multiple personality disorder, and when Dr. Orne proved to him that he was a fake, denying the testimony of other psychiatrists, Binachi abandoned the charade and was found guilty. This video was made in 1987 and it is said that Bianchi was to be released conditionally in the 1990s, which Dr. Orne thinks has a good chance of winning since Bianchi's tactics, without remorse - not of memory, has earned him alliances. . b'The only thing that is wrong with this picture is the title. Adapted from Thomas Harris\'s novel "Red Dragon", it was decided to change the title. But Alien 3 starts by changing the end of his predecessor and destroys almost all the characters we care about.Fans will remember that Ripley (Sigourney Weaver), Hicks, Newt and the Android Bishop escaped into a spaceship at the end of `` Aliens. \'\' But this film begins with their ejection of the ship and landing on a prison planet, which kills them all but Ripley! Those looking for thrills or an improvement of the first films will be very disappointed. Those who are looking for a puzzle will be in the right place.And why is this "Alien 3 (ie. Cubed)" instead of just "Alien 3" or "Alienz" or "Alien: One of These drooling monsters have survived after all? It\'s probably something to get writers like me to think about the issue and give the film a little more ink. It worked .'

b'As many critics show, if you like this movie, you will really like it. if you hate it, you will really hate it. As I have seen twice before and am ready to see him again, you can put me firmly in the first category - I have not been so transported and moved by a movie since `` The Fountain \'\' (which evoked responses similar to love or hatred among viewers). This requires the voluntary suspension of casual cynicism, which could be a sticking point for some ... but if you are ready to open your mind and your heart even more, you will be well rewarded. simple as it should be: a thread woven through the lives of several characters, who carries them through the great events of the sixties. Richness comes in the evocation of times, in countless little details that revolve around the characters. And most importantly, in the end, it\'s a love story, beautifully told. If you have already felt the intense emotions expressed in these beautiful songs, you will identify yourself with Jude & Lucy, Sadie & JoJo and all their friends. Not just romantic love, but the sincere love of others as brothers and sisters, all together in this confusing and exhilarating world. Are there difficult moments or scenes that are a little too precious for contemporary tastes? Of course ! But that does not really matter, because one of the characteristics of the 1960s was the willingness to take ridiculous risks, to risk appearing stupid or even to fall flat on your stomach. I am happy that Julie Taymor has taken similar risks here, as it helps to capture the sensibility of that time, a sensibility that has led to considerable creativity and innovation. Are not the questions of useless war, of the demonization of the Other, of intolerance and fear of change, of mistrust of the imagination, as powerful as they are today? But while the film is really on the side of the counterculture, Julie Taymor does not hesitate to show how even the best idealistic intentions could penetrate in dark places, like some protesters going bombs. A film of peace and love, which is also very familiar with grief and despair. The film ends with the anthem "All You Need Is Love", a song that some have rejected without hope. naive artifact and dated power of flowers. But I remember something George Harrison once said, when he was asked if love was really all you needed - he replied that even though it was not everything. So what is the rest? Yes, it\'s a cloud of golden nostalgia shimmering and sunny in a way ... but it\'s also a reminder that there is more to life than fear and darkness, that there is hope even in the midst of madness and chaos. And in that sense, it\'s really a contemporary film, with a vital message. Very strongly, thankfully recommended!'

"28 Weeks Later" should become a case study in film schools on how to take all the best in an amazing movie and set it aside for the future. As mentioned in other reviews, the holes in the plot are huge and relentless. My "favorites" being: 1) children leave the safe area and we even see soldiers in the guard tower let them go, 2) no one monitors or monitors the infected (but not symptomatic) survivor, 3) her husband is stupid enough to kiss her and 4) no matter how many blocks the boy runs through frantically, his father "Raged-Out" appears quickly and attacks him and him alone. I was particularly eager to see the virus spread through a crowd, as told in the first movie. Nope . When he hits the fan in the station, what happens? The lights go out and we get a lot of fast, stroboscopic shots. Hey, thanks. Unless you are epileptic, you are not afraid. I give two stars mainly because I could not give seven days. Well, let\'s call it one for the opening sequence and one for the end. If it were not the promise to see France receive it in the next, this film would have totally diverted me from any "28 Anything".'

In their constant quest for intimacy, they meet a queen of Broadway, a drag queen and other characters, all more absorbed than each other. And they call the 70s the & quot; me & quot; decade! Absolutely no one notices that Mark and Gabe, holding hands and waving and hinting, might want to be alone. Gabe can not blow his horn and say it. It's like an extended sitcom episode. To top it off, after spending a whole night getting to know Mark, with beautiful private moments en route, Gabe insults him by acting like it's just a ride. Mark, in real life, is much more tolerant and kind than a handsome guy is likely to be in real life, so it looks like things will go well. It's worth it to just watch for the cute cast. I deserved only three stars, but that made four."

b"Based on a true story, Nigel Cole's CALENDAR GIRLS is a whimsical, touching but sometimes trivial film. Trivial only in the fact that there are many times when nothing really important happens, and the crisis points are predictable and exaggerated. But a delicious cast always manages to entertain. The idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bwomen over 50 in nature is difficult to understand, but these ladies are so elegantly attractive and the calendar set with great taste, we can not help but be caught when the calendar becomes a success international. for a long time an Oscar, brings his role of Chris, the instigator of the calendar, to a wonderful achievement. Ciaran Hinds (The sum of all fears, Lara Croft Cradle of Life) is very good, her husband whose comments on a sneaky journalist cause a break in their marriage. Julie Walters (Oscar nominated several years ago for Educating Rita) paired Mirren in her role as a widow whose death is inspired by the husband. The other ladies, Annette Crosbie and Penelope Wilton in particular, are all very accomplished in their performances. Not a film that shakes the earth, but a film that proves that beauty is not relegated to the young, perhaps the youngest."

b"Before seeing The Girl Next Door, I was expecting it to be a scorching teen sex movie. After watching it, it became one of my favorite movies, if not my favorite. It is a story of love and a comedy. Emile Hirsch plays Matthew Kidman, a high school student who is a great student and a good kid, but he is a bit cheesy and did nothing memorable. throughout high school. This changes when he meets his new neighbor Danielle, played by Elisha Cuthbert. Danielle is beautiful and Matthew instantly falls for her. Shortly after spotting her, he sees her undressing through the window and can not help but watch. Danielle catches her looking at her and becomes angry at first, but it seems that she has fallen in love with him soon. Danielle is a former porn star, whom Matthew discovers only when his friend Eli (played by Chris Marquette) shows him video with her in it. To make matters worse, Kelly, former producer and ex-girlfriend of Danielle (played by Timothy Olyphant), comes one day and wants Danielle to return to the world of adult cinema. Kelly and Matthew get along well at the beginning, but that changes when Matthew tries to get Danielle out of the porn industry, which Kelly does not like at all. Eli and Kelly are two characters who really steal the show in this movie. Eli is Matthew's high school friend who is excited and obsessed with sex and hot women. He had some of the funniest lines of the entire movie. Kelly (the director who worked with Danielle and who was dating her) is the cool and wise guy who cracked me in just about every scene in which he was. I could not decide to love him or hate him - he's a nice and cool guy when he and Matthew are friends, but when Matthew makes him angry, he becomes psychopathic and violent. I do not want to say too much in this film, but Danielle asks Matthew to do things he never imagined doing. It 's really an opposing affair that attracts: Matthew falls in love with Danielle' s wild adventure, and Danielle falls into Matthew 's innocence and purity. In many scenes, we can say basically that Danielle is really a good person, she does not really want to be part of the porn world, and she really cares about Matthew. Matthew feels the same about Danielle and gets into a lot of risky situations for her. This film was so touching that I cried in two parts and did not cry easily. Still, there were also so funny parts that I could not stop laughing (mostly scenes with Eli and Kelly)."

b"You think Hollywood would have no problem making a film about Hollywood. Think again. Certainly, there have been some great photos in which Hollywood is looking at himself. The oldest I can think of is A Star is Born, from 1937, which was redone in 1954, an even better movie. 1950 Sunset Boulevard is one of the greatest movies ever made, and a few years later, Singin 'in the Rain, a classic musical. Yet, over the years, the industry has produced more bad movies about itself than the good ones. Lovers of America are somewhere in between. Its beginning is rather promising, but it weakens and disappears thereafter. Lee [Billy Crystal] is a Hollywood press agent who has big problems. His boss, Dave [Stanley Tucci], needs him to promote the new film starring Gwen Harrison and Eddie Thomas [Catherine Zeta-Jones and John Cusack]. The couple was the hottest and most popular couple in America, and audiences flocked to see their movies. Now that they are on the verge of divorce and can no longer stand, they are box office poisons. Lee must find a way to convince the press that Gwen and Eddie are recovering together without the two stars knowing what he's doing. He asks for help from Gwen's sister, Kiki [Julia Roberts], who is not only unhappy with Gwen's order but secretly in love with Eddie. Then there is the problem of the film itself. All the studio has seen is the opening credits. The director [Christopher Walken] does not want to show it until he makes some changes. These changes will result in a film very different from the one that the studio paid for $ 86 million. As I read the synopsis above, I discover how much America's Lovers have been fun and insightful. The plot leaves room for farce and satire, but the authors did not take advantage of the opportunity. Instead of being brilliant, fragile and insightful, the story is rather cute, disgusting and tame. Most chances for Hollywood to laugh at itself are wasted. The same goes for Julia Roberts. Although I'm finally able to respect her, I do not think she's right in Jane's role. In addition, she has most often done the ugly duckling. The film is primarily a vanity project for Billy Crystal, who also produced it, and for the director Joe Roth, who used it to launch his new company, Revolution Studios. They were probably afraid to upset the Hollywood establishment they are part of, too. If your mind wanders while watching a movie, it usually means it does not grab you. There are several scenes in American darlings where a character says something and everyone in the room gasps. I started to think about it. In all my life, I have never known anyone who can say to all listeners, and I have known very neat people. It's something that only happens in movies. Then I started listing in my head other things you only see on celluloid. Before I knew it, the movie was over."

b"At the time of its release, Hostel caused a lot of controversy and aroused a series of audience reactions. Many have reacted with hatred to the violent and indestructible nature of the film. My problem with this is not violence. I can not connect to the first part of the film, which focuses on the insane behavior of men hiking in Central Europe. All this becomes a long wait to see what awaits in the second half, and it provides very little evidence for what we will have to endure. All the violence of the film is hard, personal and disturbing. It's not fun, but in a broader sense, quite interesting. You are wondering about the world and the dark places where everything or anyone can be bought at the right price. This DVD contains very good performances and, overall, a very good set of extras, including a featurette almost entirely about the inspiration and reaction for the film, and how much of that is based in reality. Eli Roth is certainly a smart man, and he's ready to say a message, not just shocking, but because of the harshness and harshness of the film, it's hard to digest, and it's too uncomfortable to be really memorable . There may be a little too much truth in Hostel."

b'TETSUJIN 28 is a Japanese action film based on Mitsuteru Yokoyama\'s manga series, better known in the West for its 1963 animated black-and-white adaptation that appeared on American television in 1966 as `` Gigantor . There are some pretty spectacular scenes of two giant robots, Tetsujin 28 and Black Ox, strolling through the streets of Tokyo and falling into the skyline, including a heartbreaking movement where Black Ox rises to the top of the tower from Tokyo. There is even a good place where Black Ox launches the disabled Tetsujin in the Diet building (Parliament). These sequences are quite exciting and well done, as if the cameras were on the scene and took the action as it unfolded. Unfortunately, the two subsequent fights do not deliver the goods. The punches thrown are quite weak and there is not much movement in the fighting. Robots never fly and fight in the air, even though, by the final encounter, they both have that power. The original animated series had a lot more giant robot action than we have here. Even worse, the young Shotaro, who has been designated to pilot the remote device that controls Tetsujin, never seems to want to do it. He is weak and scared for most of the film. When he finally accepts his role at 90 minutes, which is way too long for us to wait, he is not particularly effective. While the boy playing Shotaro may offer a realistic portrayal of the reaction of a ten-year-old child in the circumstances, I must admit that I was not exactly looking for realism. I wanted the boy to be packed and eager to control this powerful robot and send him into a furious fight to end Black Ox\'s depredations. Exactly how Shotaro (or "Jimmy Sparks" as he was known in "Gigantor") behaved in the original manga and anime. Or the heroes of the movie "Johnny Sokko and His Flying Robot" and the 1960s Gamera movies. These new Japanese heroes are really thin when put to the test (see also Toru in GAMERA THE BRAVE and Tadashi in THE GREAT YOKAI WAR, two films also made in 2005, and both also on this site). What do you say about the next generation of Japanese heroes? At least Ash of `` Pok\'\' My \'\' still knows what to deal with a threat. I did like one aspect of the movie, though. I loved seeing two idols of Japanese pop music in the cast. The oldest is Hiroko Yakushimaru, who was popular in the 1980s and starred in a film I remember, entitled SAILOR SUIT AND MACHINE GUN (1981). She plays Shotaro\'s mother and she is very beautiful. The other is one of my favorite pop pop singers, Yuko Nakazawa, one of the founding members of Morning Musume, here a young police officer assigned to the case. They give her short brown hair and a rather plain navy suit, clearly an attempt to minimize her usual glamor, but she has a lot to do and it\'s always a pleasure to see her in action. Another key female character is Mami Tachibana (played by Yu Aoi), an MIT robotics expert recruited to help refurbish Tetsujin 28 after a disastrous battle in the beginning. She is young and brave and looks very uniform and beret when she befriends young Shotaro. The score of Akira Senju is nice and melodic and keeps things optimistic when the film slows down (which is often the case). I also have the CD of the soundtrack. The end music mixes with the chorus of the male chorus singing the 1963 theme song "Tetsujin 28", accompanied by shots of the original manga, which seems much more action-packed than anything in this film. The Pioneer / Geneon DVD does not offer credits in English anywhere except on the DVD case.'

b"It was a very interesting film. In fact, it is NOT banned in Singapore. I saw this film while living there and it was a real relief. b'If you liked the first, it\'s okay.I say it mainly because the tone (darker than many mainstream movies), the occult nature and the unusual imagery tend to extinguish some moviegoers. But if you just want to see a movie about a demon that has been raised by humans to fight evil, it\'s a great movie for you. Guillermo del Toro\'s leadership style is very kinetic and fluid. This helps keep the film moving, preventing it from feeling as if it is dragging. The scenes go very well from one to the other (which is also very good with wipes and creative overlays). The real appeal of this film, however, is Hellboy and the team that has been provided. Ron Perlman is the absolutely perfect Hellboy. His delivery of the lines is just perfect to create a sharp character, but ultimately adorable (and also loving). He has an ironic humor about him that makes Hellboy something that we can all refer to. We have all had moments when we feel under appreciated. We all felt like unwanted strangers. Yet, despite all the incentives he had to give up on defending these humans, he continues to do so because that\'s what his "father" taught him to do. Of course, Abe and Liz are also present, as well as Doug Jones and Selma Blair doing an excellent job of portraying their respective characters. But it\'s not their movie. It is interesting, however, to see one of the elements of the story of the first film turn around to portray the other side of it when the team meets the angel of death. In short, as I said above, if you liked the first, it\'s just your kind of movie. I can not wait to see what del Toro has in mind for the third film. (Of course, you\'ll have to wait until he finishes `` the Hobbit \'\'.)'

b'Former government agent Edward Carnby (Christian Slater) must solve the mystery of the events that took place as a child to save the planet from destruction by monsters from another dimension.OK, I admit, "Alone in the dark" does not appear on my best movies of all time, but it\'s not my worst movie list either. It can be directed by Uwe Boll, considered by many to be the worst director of all time, but if all the other Boll films are like that, then Boll was grossly underrated because I saw a lot of movies that are much worse than this one (for example, the remake of "The Stepford Wives"). The script is based on a video game, which gives it the "video game", going from level to level, getting with a lot of movies of this type (such as "Resident Evil" or "Doom"), but that does not did not put out of the movie like making me want to play and play the game. Not being a player, it was my first encounter with "Alone in the Dark" and I found the story interesting enough to maintain my interest in the movie. The game is of unequal quality. Christian Slater and Stephen Dorff (as other government agent) both offer decent performances, but Tara Reid is not convincing as a scientist, which adds to the entertainment value of the film. My main criticism is that some of the battle scenes are too long. There is a fight scene at about 1 hour that includes about 15 minutes of people shooting at monsters with very little dialogue, which has become tedious after a while. Despite that, I have always loved the film and I would be ready to see it again.'

b'My son absolutely loves the book I Stink! So when I saw this animated version available, I knew it would go all right. The people of Schoolastic have an excellent track record of animating classic children\'s books, and this is no exception. I Stink was animated in a way that perfectly complements the illustrations in the book, and Andy Richter, a Conan sidekick, does a fantastic job of giving the floor to a garbage truck "all in attitude, all the time". The animated version of I Stink is almost as popular with my son as the book. The DVD also includes some other animated adaptations that (somehow) deal with the topic of garbage trucks. Trashy Town is the only other story on the DVD, but with its simple animation and catchy chorus, it went very well. The others are mean. Arnie the Donut was funny and a little disturbing (it is a conscious pastry conscious of its impending demise), but Monsieur Racine \'s Beast was just a little too strange. I would absolutely recommend the DVD I Stink to anyone whose (ren) child has enjoyed the book. It\'s a fun collection of animated stories, and a welcome break from Elmo, Wiggles, etc.'

b'While for me, "Upstairs, Downstairs" remains the most beautiful Masterpiece Theater series of all time, this one takes the second. Gemma Jones is superb like Louisa Trotter, the Cockney Cook / Hotelienne who never loses her sense of common sense or her heavy cockney accent even after being stewardess of Edwardian England \'s Rich and Famous. The first episodes focus on the rise of Louisa, assistant cook to mistress of the Prince of Wales (future King Edward VII). But most of the series concerns the activities of Bentinck Hotel, an exclusive private London property managed by Louisa. With a few exceptions, the family must have been registered with Debrett\'s Peerage for at least 100 years before being able to book a room at the Bentinck. And yet Louisa\'s selectivity is not so much a reflection of snobbery as her passionate commitment to being the best in everything she does. The entire series is rich in characters and incidents, and in fact Jones / Louisa is well back in several episodes. But she is undoubtedly the dominant and dominant character of this series. You did not see the unbridled outrageous outrage until you saw Louisa, in the last episode of this collection, testify at trial on behalf of her friend, Lord Haslemere, pouring out a diatribe in all his glory of cockney. Now, it\'s a character! This magnificent series deserves to be much better known than it is. Do not hesitate to buy this set. I can not wait for series 2!'

b"As a lover of ancient history, I was excited to watch another film about Cleopatra's life. The comedy Billy Zane (Antony) and Timothy Dalton (Caesar) was very good, and Lenor Varella (Cleopatra) offers a good show, if you like passion and exaggerated drama. If you want to see a fictional and modern TV view of Cleopatra's life, it's your movie, but Cleopatra's film with Elizabeth Taylor is far superior."

b'In simple terms: Style over substance. There are some excellent sequences, but that\'s all that this movie seems to be, well-planned and executed sequences - but nothing coherent sticking together. The "crash plane and the last-minute rescue" are extremely impressive and the machine gun ammunition coming out of Supe\'s chest, followed by the bullet in the eyes, is beautiful. My jaw dropped and I almost wanted to applaud. This is what Superman is talking about: seeing him defeat the bad guys in a new, attractive, even fun way. But that was where the pleasure ended. Like what Superman is not sure about, it\'s the children\'s love and ridiculous heroics with kryptonite. I find that both are so implausible that they both must be ridiculed. As Brodie (played by Jason Lee in Kevin Smith\'s Mallrats) points out, "It\'s impossible! Lois Lane has never been able to have Superman\'s baby. Do you think that his fallopian tubes could support his sperm? I guarantee you that when he comes during sex, he will probably explode like a gunshot ... on his back. "Apart from the fact that Lois Lane is alive after coitus, you would then have the impossibility for a human being to conceive and bring to term the child of a stranger. Remember that the fact that Clark Kent looks and acts ostensibly like a human is an alien. He is a completely different species. And entirely different species can not mate. Just think of the ravages it would cause in the animal kingdom if a lion fell in love and mated with a crocodile. Or a guinea fowl. The other problem that thrills me with anger is the Cretinist concept of Superman\'s physical ability to lift a whole continent of kryptonite into space. As the internet blogger dpogue21 says (much better than I could not - so thank you) in his imdb review, "My next big problem is that Superman is raising a continent of kryptonite in space. It does not take the Simpson cartoon guy to say what\'s wrong with that. I do not know how many comics Bryan Singer has read, but when Superman is exposed to a small amount of kryptonite, he hardly has the strength to stay upright. Anyone who has had the idea to fly a large island with its greatest weakness in space is no longer dealing with projects related to Superman. The concept is as ridiculous as making a Dracula movie where the main character has a stake in his heart and still manages to fly a garlic spacecraft in the sun. Why not just Superman eating kryptonite? He can eat it and brush his teeth with him, then go sleep in kryptonite pajamas. It is no more absurd to have a continent of kryptonite hoisted into space, then let it fall into the atmosphere without burning back or splashing the central park when it hits the ground. \'\' Do I need to say more? I did not mean it. ** [...]'

b'The special effects were ok, but the story was weak, stupid and predictable. As a child, I loved Alien movies. Aliens (the 2nd) is considered a classic in our house because we continue to laugh at the way my mom rained M & M on the stage after a stranger scared her. So, with that, I was excited to see this movie and relive some memories. What a desappointment. It was not scary at all. The people at the theater were actually *** SLEEPING ***. I was jealous of them. I was especially happy that it was a short film. Unfortunately, the most frightening thing in this movie was a penguin. Do not see it. If you are a big fan of alien or predator and you have to catch it, wait for the video or HBO.'

b"Peter Brooks 's spartan adaptation of William Golding' s immortal novel about a group of English schoolchildren stranded on a desert island still lives nearly four decades after its initial release. Despite the total absence of star names and limited production values, the film succeeds thanks to the performances of children's actors and to a general primitivism that makes everyone credible. At first, shipwrecked people do not seem to have it so badly; there is a lot of food, no adults and no predators ... except maybe one, one & quot; beastie & quot; it could be a strange animal or a ghost or something worse ... A moving and ever poignant indictment of inherent human savagery, Lord of the Flies translates the essence of Golding's tale to the screen. Like many adults, children think they are good enough to make their own utopia. Too bad for utopia. So much for the innocence of childhood."

b'From the trailer and Julia Roberts\' presence in the cast, I went to CLOSER while waiting for a light romantic comedy. (My preconceptions have not been so broken since I saw Bambi\'s mother being shot by hunters on Saturday night). CLOSER opens as Alice (Natalie Portman), a New York stripper visits London a car after looking left instead of out of the sidewalk. She is taken to the hospital by a stranger, Dan (Jude Law), a writer who could start a live relationship. Dan then sits for an official portrait of photographer Anna (Julia Roberts), to whom he has failed. Thereafter, Larry (Clive Owen), a dermatologist, meets Anna, whom he marries, then divorces after discovering that she had had recent sexual intercourse with Dan, once scorned. On the rebound and in need of physical comfort, Larry looks for Alice, polishing clothes at a London striptease club after leaving Dan, and whom he had already met at a photo exhibition. Anna. But Dan still loves Alice and is emotionally devastated to have sex with Larry. Is it messy or what? (The weather is dark, apparently all this has been happening for a few years.) CLOSER is a painful film to watch, of sexual manipulation, possession and obsession, in which the four main characters influence each other. It\'s not a vacation for an afternoon at the movies with your old mom. The language is sexually graphic and, in a sequence of scenes from the London Strip, visually hot. CLOSER is however one of the best films of 2004. Julia Roberts is perhaps the biggest surprise because she shows that she can transcend radically - even beyond ERIN BROCKOVICH (2000) - her usual cute roles; I was strongly impressed. It would be difficult to choose the lead of this film and the support parts. All four (Portman, Law, Roberts, Owen) have about the same screen time (even if I did not follow the stopwatch). Some or all of them could win an Oscar nomination. I had begun to doze about a quarter of the length of the film, but then I woke up almost when I realized that CLOSER is an exceptional adult film, with no visual explanation. sex or violence, which brutally shows adults in dysfunctional relationships behaving at their worst. Really, as a line in KINSEY indicates: "Sex is a dangerous game. If you are not careful, it can open you completely. \'\''

b"Beginning in the late 1950s, there was a series of country music movies, perhaps in response to the successful series of B rock and roll movies around the same time. Most of them had a kind of plot involving rubes that ran into all kinds of problems. But these movies are not just the wacky hi-jinx of hilarious hillbillies; They were the wacky hi-jinx of hilarious hillbillies who had famous country music stars as friends. In other words, fragile intrigues and declining movie stars were just an excuse to present a large number of country music stars of the time. Many of the performances were synchronized, although some were recorded live. The Nashville Sound, recorded in 1969, was different. Perhaps influenced by the Pennebaker documentaries of the time, this film has no fragile plot or funny gags. Instead, it was a serious look at Nashville and the country's stars. It's well filmed, meticulous and fascinating to watch. Much of it was filmed at the Grand Ole Opry, but you also have priceless images like Loretta Lynn performing in front of a group of radio and record labels, Bashful Brother Oswald singing a Mountain Dew chorus in front of the Record Shop. Ernest Tubb. , a rehearsal of Mother Earth (with Tracy Nelson), a performance outside Shelby Singleton 's house, a recording session with Doug Kershaw and a hairless Charlie Daniels, and many more. There are also many beautiful pictures of Nashville itself. All the performances are exceptional and the film does a great job capturing the essence of country music at the time: performers, fans and people from the industry. I waited a long time for it to come out on DVD!"

b'The last Samurai is a very good movie that is not very good. The only problem I have with this film is how important it is. Even movies of this magnitude should not pull too hard on the epic strings. We understand that this is a great historical epic. No need to continue to involve him. However, this film still deserves some prizes and a good public.'

b'This DVD is not what you expect. It sounds like something someone did in their basement. He only has excerpts from 6 interviews and has no songs, etc. The last interview is on a talk show and when they announced she was going to sing her cup, not worth the money that was spent on it.'

b"Action movies remind me of the true beauty of movies, how a story can be told through a visual arrangement and a movement through the frame, instead of a dead dialogue and two still actors who converse. These films are like filmed plays, while others are inspired by black and black white roots, telling stories without words. Road Warrior contains one of the finest examples of this genre - such a small moment, a minor hurdle overcome, but which dances boldly across the screen like a painter. Here's the magic, shot by shot. Midway through the final chase sequence, a red hot rod approaches Max's big truck behind with intent to kill him. In a shot that has been copied several times, Max gets out of the cabin and pushes his shotgun into the camera - a forced perspective, moving right and left, zigzagging back onto the screen. The wicked's head explodes like a firecracker, and we are treated with a shout of joy by Max's wolf's wild friend - an animal reaction to the violence ironically given by a child raised by animals. clippings that tell the little story of the red car losing control and hitting other nasty vehicles. This little story is closed by the famous and almost peaceful shot of a man who jumps his head in a horizontal fall, still in forced perspective and flying to the camera. Now another series of jumps takes us back to the red hot rod and we are fighting to stay out of Max's huge wheels. In a beautiful game of movement, the car dances in front of Max's truck, making trips back and forth to Max and our screens like a carrot, until we have a third shot in forced perspective: the camera approaches the The truck grills, then climbs up and enters the cabin to Max, when Max finally puts an end to the misery of this car by nailing it into an explosion of pieces of gasoline and metal. A beauty so sick and twisted ... Did you know that George Miller, the director of Road Warrior, also directed Babe?"

b"let me first say that it is an excellent video. i love to watch it every time i do, i want to go out and try something new. it also made me want to discover the generations of parkour as an organization. the more I look, the more I am interested. The film is essentially a documentary about the members of this group and some of their training sessions in different places. it's well set up and I like music. there is a lot of content on the DVD, so there will be a lot of things to take. There are many good ideas on how to train and unorthodox workouts that teachers pass through to students. So, for this aspect, you could not ask for more. The only complaint I would make is that it's not a step-by-step presentation on training. there is no progression from this skill to another. I really thought I was buying something more like this. so in that sense, I was a little disappointed. there is a video produced by american parkour which is specifically intended for the initiation to the formation of parkour. I will probably receive this one too. But it is really cool because I feel that there is a connection with the roots of parkour in France and that it helps me to have a better overall impression of art."

b'& quot; The Breakfast Club & quot; is the film on the brat pack that I allow myself to guess and which will be remembered for a long time as a turning point in American cinema - at least as far as comedy for teenagers is concerned. The plot (for those who do not know him already) is articulated around 5 teenagers from different horizons, forced to sit together during a relaxation session on Saturday afternoon. A hilarious, well-crafted and often poignant film about the fundamental truths that make us all human, John Hughes & quot; The Breakfast Club & quot; is perhaps the greatest exploration of the anguish and confusion that has afflicted all of us during the high school years. Although anamorphically improved for 16X9 screens, this newly created DVD offers no improvement in video compared to the previously released DVD. The colors are dated, unrealistic, often unbalanced with bleeding and burrs. The details are minimal, even in well-lit scenes. The contrast, shadow, and black levels are all extremely low. Age-related artifacts, including chips, scratches and spice cuts are all obvious. A considerable amount of film grain is present everywhere for a totally unsatisfactory visual presentation. The 5.1 audio in Dolby and DTS features a dated feature with a muted dialogue and virtually no spatial separation, except in the music tracks. The Breakfast Club & quot; is a brilliant film However, the lack of extras (a documentary would have been nice) and the very low processing of the transfer led me to say that this record was not worth it.'

b"It only takes a few minutes to see how terrible this thing is. The film begins with jets involved in a high-speed, transcontinental race. Well, our hero pilot Grant (Antonio Sabato Jr.) decides he needs to be refueled. Have you ever seen a crew refuel a car on the track during a NASCAR race? No, me neither. It would be a little dangerous, I guess. Well, Grant's jet is refueled by another plane while it is in the direct flight path of the other race planes. What happens ? Duh ... there is a horrible collision and three drivers (with 11 spectators ... huh?) Are dead. Good move guys. Maybe the funniest and most pathetic event of the movie happens a little later. Several years have passed since the tragic incident of the jet race and we are listening to a person in charge of the network who broadcast the race live. The executive says ... are you ready? ... he says that the sequence of jets colliding during the race was the highest-rated video they had shown in the last four years. Unbelievable! ! Talk about a future world where nothing exciting happens. Must be boring. Other things to look for are a guy who makes noise when his mouth does not move. In addition, a scene where a shirtless Sabato Jr. is about to wear a tank top. He takes it but the camera changes angle and now there is nothing to see. Then the camera changes angle again and pulls it on his head. Good editing! In this film, everything is cheap, except for decent actors. With a fine paper plot and terrible effects, I strongly recommend you not to waste your time watching this dreck. One last note ... without nudity and graphic violence, I have no idea why this note is R."

b"Bloodrayne (Uwe Boll, 2005) From time to time, you meet a really bad movie director, but every time he undertakes a project, he does something, even if you know that the movie will be even worse than the last piece shit he has released, it always makes you want to see it.In this case, Uwe Boll, responsible for such execrable films as Alone in the Dark and House of the Dead, managed to sneak into a casting is hard to believe were willing to take a chance on a movie based on the video game Uwe Boll. Michael Madsen (Reservoir Dogs), Billy Zane (Posse), Michelle Rodriguez (Girlfight), Udo Kier (Suspiria) and many others are also present. I can not believe they were all short of money. All are presented under television actress Kristianna Loken (who saw the big screen playing the bad boss in Terminator 3), in the title role of the film, a half-human half-vampire who wants to kill Kingsley. The character of Kagan, because Kagan killed Rayne's mother. The fact that he is also his father does not seem to make him doubt his motivation. Not that anyone in this movie has enough character to really have a lot of motivation. That does not seem to bother Boll, who cuts this film exactly the same fabric as his colleagues: a lot of action, sex notes that could actually be interesting if he cared enough to explore these scenes, a useless script, a camera that is right on this side of the skill, and Boll's somewhat impressive ability to do the worst possible of anyone. And yet, despite everything The most depressing thing about Bloodrayne is that the film has gone quite well overseas (predictably, it has had a nightmare in America, making two and a half million, less than one fifth of the budget). At least none of the original actors, including Loken, had the courage to sign for what can not help but be another Boll monstrosity. (zero)"

b'This film almost reminds me of the television series Alice: in a small restaurant run by a grouchy little chef with a golden heart, and led by a trio of waitresses, the brave Blondie Southern, the childish and naive, and the single mother who has the means (or the expectant mother, in this case), as well as the typical assortment of wacky and colorful customers. The writer / director Adrienne Shelly manages to take this model and to draw something marvelous. Far from being a simple remake of Alice, Waitress is a well designed and well - executed exploration of a woman \'s fight to take her place and make her dreams come true, despite the bad choices and bad decisions she made on the run. of road. what really sets it apart from the rest of the big screen is the script. The dialogue, written by Adrienne Shelly - who also directed and co-starred Dawn, the smiling waitress who ultimately finds true love - sparkles with wit, charm and humor. It\'s fast and it\'s funny, but it always seems quite natural, thanks in no small part to the talents of the actors and the actresses responsible for broadcasting it. Unlike the writing, say, of Gilmore Girls, widely appreciated for its uniqueness, the dialogue in Waitress never seems forced or unnatural. It\'s great without being intrusive. My only reduction to this movie is the fact that the message "men are dogs" is a bit heavy. Without exception, all waitress\'s male characters are portrayed as being either naughty, like Earl (Jeremy Sisto), unprincipled, like Dr. Pomatter (Nathan Fillion), or just weird, like Ogie (Eddie Jemison). Even Joe (Andy Griffith), who is really kind and caring, shows up throughout the aggressive and demanding film, so much so that Jenna, who has been suffering for a long time, is the only person able to deal with him and his only friend . This is obviously a film made by a woman, mainly for a female audience, but we can not help thinking that if a man made a movie in which all the female characters were nothing else, would be a game serious, well deserved. Waitress is a good movie that is worth the detour. It is tragic that Shelly, who was brutally murdered in November 2006, is no longer making films, as this film will undoubtedly raise the impressive talents of the author / director to a wider audience than ever before. . Fortunately, Waitress is an appropriate memorial to remember.'

b'This is my favorite film about Bernadette and Lourdes. And now, this new large format remake by Ignatius offers exceptional image quality, as well as many bonus additions, including the first availability of the French version (original) and the wonderful movie and radio. interviews with the wonderful Sydney Penny. These interviews add a lot to this movie kit. It\'s great to see and hear the lovely Sydney Penny in person talk about what it meant to play that role. (This film was filmed in English and French, shot twice back to back by Jean Delannoy, and both versions are on this DVD.) PLUS - the glorious voice of the incredible singer Jenifer Warnes and this moving song she and Leonard Cohen wrote "Song of Bernadette" on the bonus CD of this package. Now we hope that many people will be able to hear this beautiful song and tribute to Bernadette by this fabulous Grammy winning artist. There is also a second beauty sung by Jennifer Warnes on the CD, her song `` Prairie Melancholy \'\'. Another jewel of the music of this celestial singer. In this year of the 150th anniversary of the apparitions in Lourdes, this newly wrapped remastered film, with audio CD and songs, Penny\'s interviews and the 16-page Collector\'s Booklet, is a wonderful way to honor the story of Lourdes . inspiring movie.'

b'The cultural revolution that shook Paris from 1905 to 1930 is well documented in this two-hour documentary DVD, which includes photographs, film archives, literary excerpts and analyzes. The focus is on the arts, from classical music and jazz to sculpture, from poetry to dance, to paintings painted in novels. The rise of post-Impressionist modernism to Fauvism, Cubism, Dada and Surrealism and their many pioneers of the fine arts and literature is considered an extraordinary period of free experimentation and interdisciplinary interaction, especially between poets and artists. Paris was the pot of fermentation and the vanguard was strong, strong and varied. Watching this documentary can inspire envy. O have lived in such a time! Of course, my generation and I experienced such a revolution, albeit for a shorter time in this fast-growing society, while San Francisco Bay, between 1965 and 1980, was the hub of musical, artistic, and noetic innovation. , ecological and scientific. and explorations. Which evokes a minor gap in the documentary: the absence of any mention of developments in science, especially physics, and its influence on the arts, when the concepts of time and space and matter have made the object of a radically new reflection. Otherwise, the survey is a wonderful cultural story, optimism before the First World War and the engine of cynicism and creative criticism after the carnage. The viewer can then immerse himself in the many books covering this exciting period to continue his studies. This DVD is an excellent introduction to the history of art and cultural studies.'

b"We should all congratulate Uwe Boll. He's like a kind of cinematic roach. No matter how little talent he has, and no matter how bad these films are, he manages to make them. I know, he finances them himself through some kind of bizarre German fund, but still, his ability to continue making movies despite absolute and complete failure is one of the great mysteries of the universe. that video game developers continue to give their best properties to this guy. Someone has to withdraw their line of credit, or these video game publishers have to realize and realize that when they make a bad movie in a game that kills the franchise, no one is interested in that title. Is House of the Dead or Alone in the Dark a viable game title? No way . A new House of the Dead game is coming out for XBox and nobody cares. The title is dead, and all because of Uwe Boll. So, if one of you works for a game publisher, or knows a game publisher, or has access to a game publisher ... please let them know. This movie itself is not even worth reading. I can not separate what I did not like from this pile of dung from the rest. Literally, everything is zero. Writing, playing, music, synthesis effects, editing. I thought that if I waited for the release on DVD and that I rent it with few expectations, I would not be disappointed. Even the 5 dollars you will spend on this DVD if you buy them on one of Amazon's sellers is too much. You are going to regret it . This movie is just a bunch of Boll."

b"Right on the money. Do not miss a beat. Creative writing and beautiful performances. Humor and occasional drama come in the subtle waves. b'YOJIMBO was my introduction to the great work of the incomparable Japanese actor, Toshiro Mifune, who plays the main character, Yojimbo (English translation: Bodyguard). This man can be bought with sake or rice, basically to do what he does best: being physically imposing and eliminating the bad guys. However, he keeps his cool, even if he discovers that the couple who hired him is stabbing in the back. Just see the movie to find out, no?). The great Japanese director Akira Kurosawa does a fantastic job telling a captivating story, original, dark and very endearing. The jazzy and Japanese soundtrack largely reflects the themes and tensions of the story, the incident camera work is spontaneous and teases the audience, while the actors grimace, growl and surrender with a vicious and (sometimes) reckless abandon . Fantastic ... By the way, it was the inspiration of the spaghetti western, FISTFUL OF DOLLARS, with Clint Eastwood. Do not miss ... ... ..'
