b'This musical continues to delight and seduce us ... more than 40 years after its creation. This is worth our old fashioned applause - with a good show of songs and solid dances. Robert Preston shines like Professor Harold Hill ... an unscrupulous crook who tries to deceive the entire population (about 2,400) of River City, Iowa. He makes his way through their hearts (and their wallets) and manages to stay one step ahead of the authorities. Along the way, he (Professor Hill) touches the life of a future woman (Shirley Jones as Librarian Marian) and her extremely shy little brother Winthrop (played by a very young and adorable Ronnie Howard) and, to his surprise, he finds himself in the unfamiliar territory of a good friend. His planned escape has been blocked, he is caught and must, uh, face the music. Throughout this journey, we receive many memorable and fun songs and delicious dance routines. The filmmakers showed a little courage ... using a little imagination and taking risks ... and gave us a lot of entertainment. My favorite places are the opening sequence of the train and the excellent dance (and song) scene inside the library. The people of River City are stubborn and narrow-minded ... but in fact they are comedy producers. Virtually all the adult characters in the film contribute their share of the workload ... and add humor to the pleasure of the image. Paul Ford, like Mayor George Shinn, is particularly talented ... and Hermione Gingold, who plays his wife Eulalie, is funny too (albeit in a different way). Shirley Jones is pretty good here. She has always been a great singer, but she also plays stage and fantasy. Pert Kelton, as an Irish mother, is a delight. But the show belongs to Robert Preston. A very talented artist, he is light and agile (and agile) by manipulating his lines. He is not a great singer ... he speaks most of the lyrics of his songs ... but they (the songs) work, and they work well. I had heard that in the pre-production phase of the film, they wanted to replace Robert Preston (the star of the stage version of "The Music Man") with someone else. Meredith Willson, the author of the original story, gave them an ultimatum ... either Robert Preston remains or ... no movie. And by watching it (Preston) happen here, it\'s easy to understand that feeling. It\'s a delight.'

b'This Is It shows that until the end, the king of pop possessed all the elements that made him a superstar. Here we see the preparation for his unfortunate London Comeback, but even though we all know how this story ends, you can not help but smile when you see Michael in his original element and have fun. The most intriguing part of this documentary is the lack of dialogue with Michael Jackson, but you can feel totally in his expressions the cogs that work actively inside; He strove hard in this last effort to make the world vibrate. It\'s Michael Jackson, unlike what he\'s been seeing for years. Here, he sings all his songs live, even those who have a fast past such as Jam, They Do not About Us and Smooth Criminal - this item also shows fans how exhausting it really was to dance and sing, and this sequence clearly shows why, for the Dangerous and History tours, he had to synchronize several faster numbers. Many of the signature MJ dance moves have been omitted, and I would have liked to see some images without occasional distractions of the 3D short films (I wish they had put it on a split screen so we could see this sequence AND the performance of the scene at the same time). The performances of the rehearsal are clearly the following: I can not stop loving, I will be there Thriller (totally new production that used in the Dangerous and History tours!) Beat It (the first time in years, I have I saw the same dance in 1982!) The others are good too, but none are close as sharp or polite as these figures of the repetition. The key point of this rehearsal sequence is to be able to hear her sing live, and it would have been better if this Is It album contains these versions instead of the studio versions ... Moreover, the new guitarist of Michael is great (on the eyes and on the ears). Many of MJ\'s dance moves are omitted, and I would have liked to see some rehearsal footage without the occasional distraction of 3D shorts (I wish they were split) screen so we could see this footage AND the performance of the scene at the same time). So, in all fairness, this is not at all an experience in concert with MJ, but it has all the elements of one. The slogan of "Get to know the man you have never known" is not really accurate because Very few dialogues with Michael Jackson apart from seeing him say "God bless you" to all the members of the production team and noting when it thinks something needs to be changed about how something is done. It will be remembered as the greatest concert ever to take place in the history of music. From these few vague excerpts of what This Is It\'s current concert may reveal, Michael would have made a comeback in this series of concerts, and once again, he proved that he was and will always remain king of pop. It is recalled that even though the tabloids tried to throw it into the light of evil, the only message from Michael Jackson was that of love. LOVE. simple and simple.'

b'I found this film very pleasant. The scenario is simple and, in a way, unimportant - Camille, a well-known Parisian actress, returns from Rome to perform in front of her audience in a play directed by her new lover Ugo. The play is "Come Tu Mi Vuoi" by Pirandello, a classic work (written for his lover Martha Abba) about a woman stuck between the yin and yang forces of reality and illusion. Throughout the film, Rivette tilts her camera between the room and the "reality" of Camille and Ugo, as if to ask us who are the real Camille and Ugo. What do they really want? What motivates them? Can I, the viewer, enter their universe without script? Rivette (and his excellent actors) show us that delicacy can be robust and inventive, that the desire of others can never be filled and that accomplishment does not really matter, because in the process of struggle for to achieve this, we become alive and creative. . What matters is the style; style is the substance. We are also confronted with a brilliant representation of the incestuous relationship between Italians and French and there is a delightful succession of nuances, allusions and games with national stereotypes that have brought a lot of smile to my face. I can see why some - those who are used to Hollywood clich\xc3\xa9s with their happy ending and so predictable intrigues - might not find the film so hot. Well, it\'s a shame ...'

b'Cleanliness training is part of the parenting process and although it usually starts in the early years, it may take more time with some children than others. Potty Power is trying to speed up the process by introducing a DVD that encourages kids to use the potty and give up their diapers or pull-ups. He accomplishes his goal through his potty, his songs, his sketch and his optimism about the use of the potty. Jessica, the narrator of Potty Power, is encouraging and extremely cheerful. She talks about pee and poo, slang terms for bodily functions, and more while still keeping a smile on her face. She really wants kids to learn how to use the potty, and her enthusiasm, hopefully, will be reflected on the kids watching the DVD. This DVD certainly has its utility and I know many people who have had a lot of success young toddlers. But it gets a little tacky and many adults will roll their eyes listening to the dialogue and the songs. Songs like "I\'m proud to wear my underwear," "Wipe Your Bottom" and others are certainly appealing to young kids, but even some young people will find the material too silly to be true. One of my little ones has already had toilet training and she laughs aloud when she looks at this DVD, because of her silly and often silly style. Apart from the simplicity, the effectiveness of the DVD and my experience. My youngest loves to repeat the lines she has heard on this DVD and she likes to sing on tunes. She went alone to the potty, so the DVD seems to have a positive effect, even if it sometimes becomes boring. Despite its foolishness, Poty Power is an effective way to wean children. their diapers and pull-ups. If you manage to overcome the awkwardness of the whole experience, the narrator\'s excessive cunning and the boring skit at the end, Potty Power seems to have something to offer. Kids will remember tunes and messages, making this DVD a good complement to the toilet.'

b'Manny Pontoriero\'s latest instructional DVD set includes two DVDs offering exceptional instruction in landscape photography. As with previous Manny DVDs, do not just watch a DVD once. Instead, watch a DVD, take a ton of photos, and then watch the DVD again. Digital photography allows you to take many pictures of a scene, from all angles, using different lenses and filters, with an immediate review of your efforts and no need for development, as with photography. class course including drawings and subject examples. Then he is on the ground using these principles in action. It\'s in the first DVD that Manny also explains parallel thinking. Parallel thinking is "how can I photograph this scene"? Do not just take the picture you originally saw. Instead, what other options (different times of the day, different seasons, use of different lenses, etc.) can you use to capture scenes in one place? The second DVD features 14 field sessions at different locations on the east coast. During each session, Manny offers a detailed description of what he does at each location, and explains why. Throughout these sessions you will find information that you might miss, but that is important. For example, if you stack filters on a lens, use a ring lift so you can use larger filters on a lens and not burn your photo. Or, do not change lenses at the beach if the wind is blowing, because you do not want to introduce grains of sand into a lens or into the camera; and when you return home, vacuum the lens and the camera to remove the grains of sand on the outside surfaces. The second DVD contains a fifteenth additional session during which Manny switches from camera to computer. It uses the raw Photoshop editor to make these adjustments, as well as the neutral density setting available in this editor. I highly recommend Manny\'s DVDs, especially this two-DVD landscape photography kit.'

It\'s a brilliant, inventive and inventive film with great special effects that you\'ll never forget, as I did not see it on the screen in \'81. Night begins with two young Americans crossing the scary European countryside . I love the scene where they enter a pub and are welcomed like the plague. b'A Faustian spin through New York and post-war Louisiana, "Angel Heart" tells a very old story from a surprisingly original and wonderfully frightening angle. The plot, which focuses on the case of a missing person more and more violent, is relatively simple, but the story that triggers it is remarkably complex. When you collect the pieces at the end, it makes sense, but right. De Niro is superb like Louis Cyphre, the "shopkeeper" with some guarantees to collect, infusing the right balance between sardonic humor and demonic threat. Mickey Rourke gives what will probably still be his best performance as Harry Angel, a shocked war veteran and a disjointed P.I. The support cast is excellent, especially Charlotte Rampling as a occultist, and Lisa Bonet as a voodoo witch. But the real star is the writer / director Alan Parker. He has an extraordinary talent for the simple but powerfully disturbing image: a slow zoom on the exterior wall of a New York hotel; a New Year\'s crowd in Times Square; a descending elevator; a wide staircase; the blades rotating a fan. These images are simple, cold, but overflowing with hellish threats. Trevor Jones\' music is the perfect accompaniment, his saxophones exuding threatening rhythms and the omnipresent pulsation of a beating heart. It is a deeply disturbing marriage that will be afraid to close around you with the same uncertainty as the fate of the protagonist.'

Anyway, I rarely write more than 3 or 4 line reviews, but this is an example. of these rare exceptions. Some details that had escaped, I noticed now. Despite what some people may say, I can not think of anything more beautiful and purer than the love the boy visibly felt for his soldier. By reading some of the comments, I tend to agree with many of them. They say they have become extremely sad. One woman said that she wanted to get the boy in and tell him that his prince would come back. Another guy said he wondered if the soldier really knew how much the child loved him. Rudi Van Danzig died in January of this year and someone said that he would finally meet his soldier. Well, I could not read it, but judging by the movie, it's hard to imagine anyone who would not want to live a story as intense, though short, and whatever. always remain a mystery, and this, in my opinion, adds to the magic. I will not repeat here what has been said about the actors. They are really good. However, a particular observation about the boy and the soldier: they are really convincing and sometimes you even feel like enjoying them. The boy has the kind of unusual and fleeting beauty you see once in your life. His eyes are sad, even when he smiles. Of course, there will always be those who are ready to criticize it, but it is to be expected. Let's face it: some things are not meant for everyone. Technically speaking, my only complaint is that, unfortunately, the quality of the picture is not great, but the movie itself more than makes up for it. And I will watch it again! ! !"

b"It's hard to find words to start describing this fantastic show. First of all, the writing is superb. Some elements of this story lead the viewer to go online or visit the local library for more information on what is being presented. For all that we are told, there are nearly twenty things that we are not told ... which really involves the viewer in the series. It encourages active visualization, speculation, discussion and research, among others. This does not mean that one could not simply watch the show and derive a supreme level of pleasure. The first season, I was an almost-active spectator and I always thought it was the best show I've ever seen. The images created by the dialogue are incomprehensible. And of course, what is the good writing without great talent to deliver the lines? In the foreground, there are powerful actors such as Clancy Brown as Brother Justin in conflict and Nick Stahl as Ben Hawkins, intrepid but discreet. Seeing seemingly unrelated stories between these two evolving characters is an incredible event. The show also includes Tim DeKay, Clea Duvall, Cynthia Ettinger, Amy Madigan, Michael J. Anderson, Toby Huss, Brian Turk, Adrienne Barbeau, John Savage and even Pa Walton himself, Ralph Waite. If one is a fan of any of these actors, their talents are highlighted in this series. The emotions go through the first season and these actors know exactly how to represent them. And what is good writing and a beautiful action without a spectacular return for the action to take place? From the windy sandstorms of Dustbowl Oklahoma to the beautiful countryside of rural California, every set is perfect. The eyes receive beautiful images to absorb. Last but not least, the mere involvement of the store alone. As I mentioned earlier, this show makes you an active spectator. If you've ever, for a moment, believed in the era of wonder ... the magic of the past ... this series is definitely worth it. Elements of our daily life are challenged and an entirely new world is created before your eyes. I challenge everyone who buys the DVDs of the first season to watch only one episode at a time. Look at one and wait a week before seeing another one. I bet you can not. You will be impatient to see what happens next. If you did not think it was possible with a TV show, remember ... it's not TV ... it's HBO."

b"Very disappointing. After waiting so long for more than Battlestar, which is the best television series, Razor left a lot to be desired. An irregular rhythm, a disjointed narration and none of the new characters was very interesting. Wait until it's on Sci Fi again and save the $."

b'I must confess with some shame that before this movie, I did not know who Harvey Pekar was. But that did not limit my ability to enjoy this movie, which was one of the most interesting I\'ve seen in a long time. The theme of the film as a whole is brilliantly summarized in the first seconds of the film. Several boys climb into a house on Halloween, all dressed up as superheroes, except for one boy, who is simply dressed as himself: Harvey Pekar. The film as a whole is about Pekar\'s attempt to tell his mundane, boring, and disappointing life in a comic book. Instead of a comic book about superheroes, he devised a cartoon about himself, a clerk at the Veterans Hospital in Cleveland. The film tells the story of Pekar\'s life in more or less detail, highlighting his encounter with R. Crumb in the 1960s and his inspiration in the drawing of a comic, despite his inability to draw. By taking incidents of his own life, involving his friends and colleagues, designing comic book frames and engaging artists to illustrate his stories (many by Crumb himself), Pekar manages to create something unique , funny and strange way, triumphant and beautiful. The film implies that we can all be the heroes of our own story. There is not much going on in the film, but it still manages to compete. The major events of the story are Pekar\'s meeting with R. Crumb, his decision to write his own comic book, to meet his wife, a series of performances in the late 1980s on the Dave Letterman Show and his cancer. Throughout, there is no attempt to make Pekar better than him. He is portrayed as physically unattractive, a little weird, a chronic underachiever, more than a little neurotic and extremely self-absorbed. But in spite of all that, there is an honesty to look at her life and describe her as she is, warts and everything. The way he treats everything with an indefatigable sense of humor and his determination to make his life an objective and a goal is heroic in a very concrete way, as opposed to the fictitious heroism of Superman, Batman, or the Green Lantern.It would be difficult to impress Paul Giamatti too much by playing Harvey Pekar or Hope Davis while playing Joyce Brabner, the woman who marries Pekar. The real Pekar and the real Brabner also appear on the camera, as are most of the real models of the Pekar characters. In fact, the way the story of the film circulates transparently between real people, actors and comics is one of the highlights of the film. In a scene, the Paul Giamatti playing Pekar and Judah Friedlander playing with Pekar\'s friend (and MTV celebrity) Toby Radloff are on the screen while the real ones Harvey Pekar and Toby Radloff have a conversation. In another part of the film, Hope Davis and Paul Giamatti are supposed to be behind the scenes of the show Dave Letterman, but when Giamatti, as Pekar, comes out on stage with Letterman, he cuts the images of the real Pekar interviewed by Letterman . I remembered Margritte\'s famous painting, where he painted a pipe with the words "This is not a pipe" underneath. By switching from real Pekar to an actor who plays it, it\'s a way of saying, "It\'s not Harvey Pekar" whenever Giamatti is on the screen. In addition, it is clear that Giamatti is the cinematic equivalent of the different Pekars drawn in comics. It\'s a great movie, and I hope it gets the attention it deserves. It\'s very different from the CRUMB movie, but I guess it will appeal particularly to those who enjoyed this strange but fascinating documentary.'

b"I believe Waitress's excellence is unique, but my desire to help him was undoubtedly reinforced by the post-production tragedy of the murder of writer / director Adrienne Shelly. I think co-star Cheryl Hines says the best in the performance: Shelly's tragic and senseless death forces you to watch the movie through a different prism. I was surprised that Keri Russell was not nominated for the best prices. I thought she was exceptional. She is in all the scenes. His performance carries the film. It's really a series of interactions between her and her husband Earl (a wonderfully unresponsive Jeremy Sisto), she and the client / owner Old Joe (a dyspeptic Andy Griffith) and she and the doctor / suitor Dr. Pomatter. In particular, the relationship between Jenna and Russell's Nathan Fillion is very well played, both by the actors themselves and by the solid writings and direction of Shelly. She will be missed."

b"Beverly Hills Cop did not need an introduction. It was one of the best action comedies of 1984. He helped introduce Eddie Murphy into the mainstream and reigned in 1984. Beverly Hills Cop II was pretty good. A little exaggerated but still fun. It complimented Tony Scott's style and captured most of the 80s. This monstrosity is instantly forgettable from start to finish. A bust goes wrong and Inspector Todd (Gilbert R Hill) is killed. Axel (Eddie Murphy) traces the murderer known as Ellis De Wald (Timothy Carhart) to a Disney idiot named Wonderworld where Ellis De Wald is the supervisor. Where to start first? Axel Foley does not even feel like Axel Foley (much like Big Top Pee Wee was different from Pee Wee of Big Adventure). Eddie spends the whole movie looking like he does not know what his character is supposed to be. Gone is the tenacious but stupid cop who annoyed his target. He is replaced by a guy so relaxed that it becomes boring after a while. The only characters to return are Inspector Todd (but he gets killed early) and Rosewood (Judge Reinhold). Taggart is gone and Sgt too. Bogomil. This film was based on DOA. The first two films of the BHC had very good villagers considering the period. Victor Maitland and The Alphabet Killer were good villagers but Ellis De Wald is awful. Without wishing to show disrespect for Timothy Carhart, he was rather a martyr and his plan of maturity was weak and lazy in the name of the writers. Use an amusement park to make counterfeit money? The film is rarely funny and bringing back Serge (Bronson Pinochet) was an inexpensive attempt to remind us of the first interaction of Serge and Axel Foley in the first film. There is a moment of redemption in this film: the faulty sequence of driving in the park where Axel saves two children. This scene is the only reason I gave it two stars. Humor for the most part is forced and if ever hearing this annoying theme song for Wonderworld, it will be too soon. Who thought it was a fun thing? In conclusion, this film killed a promising series. It's a shame that the same director (John Landis) behind Animal House, Blues Brothers, Coming To America and a few other of my favorite movies is behind this mess. John Landis is a great director but not a great director for this type of film. Thumbs down."
b'EXCELLENT! FINE ACTING! BEAUTIFUL MUSIC ! NOSTALGIC! GREAT, INSPIRING STORY. Highly recommend the movie and the soundtrack.'

b'In movies, as in most other art forms, the most important works are often presented in smaller packages. Such is the case with "The Five Senses", an independent Canadian production that chooses for its subject nothing less than a meditation on what it means to be human. Writer / director Jeremy Podeswa has conceived a poetic, high-profile piece centered on a group of people sharing the universal need to find true love and acceptance in a world where injured and broken relationships all too often lead to loneliness and despair. Like all of us, each of these characters seeks to achieve the twin goals of intimacy with others and self-acceptance that are essential to human happiness. Some succeed, while others fail, just as in life, but none of the characters are left untouched by experience. "The Five Senses", though intriguing, is more of a mood piece than a narrative drama. With an exceptional casting, Podeswa is able to attract us to the center of his world through sensory imagery and deliberate and methodical stimulation. In fact, one of the film\'s strongest themes is its examination of the role our senses play in defining our world and our character. Podeswa understands that we have become insensitive to our senses. As a result, he uses this film to reconnect with this crucial element of our beings. The silent, silent tone, the muted autumn colors, the slowly moving camera, the bewitching musical score combine to create an atmosphere in which the audience can become aware of every sight and sound that comes to us. In our effort to establish meaningful intimacy with other human beings, we most often rely on the sense of touch - but that can serve, Podeswa shows us, as much to trap us in a false intimacy as to make us one who be authentic. and sustainable. A number of his characters use sex as a substitute for true proximity, while others establish a physical connection at a much deeper level. One of the most moving moments of the film occurs when a gay man - probably an AIDS patient - falls into tears during a massage session, heartbroken because no one has dared to touch him for so long . This film recognizes the vital part played by tender physical contact in the totality of humanity. In the same way, the film explores the beauty of sound, one of the characters - ironically an ophthalmologist, a man dedicated to preserving the organ of a sense - is faced with the prospect of impending deafness and aspires to create a mental catalog of all the exquisite sounds of everyday life that he will soon be unable to hear and which we take so often for granted. Yet, like all other characters, it is his spiritual emptiness and his inability to make a meaningful connection to another human being that brings him his greatest obstacles to happiness. Podeswa also examines the smell that plays a vital role in the life of man, one of the characters - a gay and lonely man - revisits his old lovers to give them a smell of perfume to discover if he can feel true love. "Yet, The Five Senses is not just a movie built on a clever gadget. "On the contrary, it breathes the fullness of humanity because each of its many characters emerges as a fully developed and instantly recognizable human being. There are adolescents who are alienated by their own inability to conform to society\'s accepted norm and feel guilty by their acts of careless irresponsibility. There are mothers terrified of losing their children, in one case, literally, as their young girl moves away and disappears and, in another case, figuratively, her teenage daughter seems to sink into a "Inexplicable strangeness. "There are adults who can not understand a life filled with failed relationships who are desperately seeking that last chance for happiness, often with the result that they are farther away than ever from the universally desired goal. One of the most daring aspects of "The Five Senses" is that it does not give in to the temptation to provide a "happy" or even conclusive ending for all of its characters. The film recognizes that life is a disordered and endless process of change of fortune and personal growth, and that it stays true to this theme until the end. This courageous, captivating and captivating film is undoubtedly one of the true discoveries of recent films. years - a true work of art!'
b'A real tear, but a good movie. I had the movie in a week and a half'

b'`` The Exorcist \'\', as well as movies such as `` Rosemary\'s Baby \'\', `` The Shining \'\' and `` The Ring \'\' stand out to me as some of the greatest movies of horror of all times. Not only were they good movies in themselves, but they "broke the rules" and adopted new ground. This DVD contains many deleted scenes and behind the scenes watching the realization of the movie.I know that I heard that after a movie screening a few months before it was released, some screen managers thought that the film should not be released. It was just too scary. When you really watch the movie for the first time, you\'ll really be scared ... Some people remember it for the "pea soup" incident, but this movie did not use gore to argue its point of view. Like the other movies mentioned above, he used smart imagery, dialogue, and symbols to make his points people. Most reading of this review know that the story was based on a case in 1947, in which a 13 year old boy was supposed to be possessed. Obviously, some details have been changed for the movie. I would like to see a film of the "true" story of 1947, in which no name is revealed, but the facts are given. The Exorcist really deserves all 5 stars. Maybe more and more writers and filmmakers should go back before trying to make another senseless teen movie that is a horror movie.'

b'You\'d better eat ham if you plan on going through this movie. John Carradine, an old millionaire from Nutty, dies and states that his four children and his three servants must accomplish their inheritance through a grumpy testament in which he expresses nothing but hating everyone and saying odd things like "It could separate the rabbits from the alley cats" and then laughs handsomely. They have to spend a week at home or they will not be able to get their share of inheritance. Every person in the movie is totally hateful, and at the halfway point, I did not care about how the movie ended so long. After the children are settled in the house, they all begin to die in a variety of ways that are all subdued: Johnny is killed in a tank of piranhas, another is under a sheet of aluminum on a tray in the refrigerator, a couple is killed by electrocution in the bed, the other by the head, etc. . There are additional features such as Carradine that makes an adult dress up like an organ grinder monkey, a free ax to the head (one of the worst special effects of all time), voracious insects, a The film continues, and it is obvious that the conclusion will take place in the middle of the film. A special mention goes to the last line of the film addressed directly to the public: "And I bet you thought it was the butler all the time. "The closing music, which is at the limit of the non-listable list, is also extremely unpleasant. I gave this movie two stars (generously) for John Carradine\'s hilarious but minor performance. Really a master of the horror of his time, but an even bigger master of his past day.'

b'I enjoyed the special features as much as the episodes. Some of the stars invited to Bonanza gave comments on the episode in which they were. b'The Enterprise picks up several envoys from various planets to place them on a planetoid named Babel. Their plans are to discuss the acceptance of Coridan as a member of the Federation. Some members of the Federation are strongly opposed to accepting them. Reasons can range from vendettas to the desire of criminals to steal the precious Dylithium crystals on the planet - the protection of the Federation would put an end to such criminal enterprises. Among the delegates, there are Vulcans, Andorians and a foreign delegation that looks like crossings between Bassett Hounds and the Ugnaughts of `` Return of the Jedi \'\' with obsessive eyes and a short temperament. The composition of the Andorians has been remarkably successful. When Ambassador Vulcan Sarek and his wife Amanda board the Enterprise, there is obvious tension and Sarek asks that someone other than Spock be his "tour guide" of the ship. It is then revealed that Sarek and Amanda are Spock\'s parents. Jane Wyatt is the loveable wife and mother who has subdued much of her emotions to fit Sarek, but still allows them to emerge from time to time. Mark Lenard begins his Sarek career, which we continue to see until his death in one of the last seasons of "Star Trek: The Next Generation". Sarek has not spoken to Spock for 4 years. Angry that his son refused to study the same subjects that he and his father had studied, there are between them silences pissed off but discreet. Amanda must run to appease both of them in her own way. One of the pig-faced extraterrestrials, a gruff guy named Gaz, confronts Sarek in the living room and threatens him when Sarek declares his intention to vote for acceptance of the Coridans. Shortly after, Gas is found, murdered. An autopsy reveals that his neck was broken in a place that would cause instant death. Spock recognizes this as a form of death penalty used on Vulcan centuries earlier, preferred for its speed and painless delivery. A method called Tal-Shaya, well known to his father. An interesting element that the Romulan equivalent of the KGB is called Tal-Shayar in the Next Gen episodes - the Romulans are distant cousins \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bof the Vulcans and their languages \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bprobably have common roots ... maybe the English translation of the Tal -Shayar is: "the neck killers"? Anyhoo, Sarek is thought to be a suspect, but he is eliminated when it is obvious that a defective heart valve prevented him from functioning. A risky operation requires that Spock, the only Vulcan on board equipped with the same rare T-negative blood type, provide close to half of his blood during a transfusion. Why they could not take a pint a day exceeds me. Spock is preparing to be the source of blood for his father when Kirk is attacked by an Andorian. The Andorian clearly stabs Kirk in the lower back, close to his loins in the attack, just before Kirk kicked him and knocked him out cold. Kirk leans on his side and pulls a bloody hand and uses the wall-mounted intercom to ask for help just before losing consciousness. In the infirmary, we see Kirk with a bandage around his naked torso. We are now told that his lung has been perforated and the Andorian has barely missed his heart. Considering he was using a small knife that could not reach his heart, I think they should have redone the fight scene, but it\'s just me. It is as if the lung injury was a reflection after the battle and perhaps the authors thought that the public would not "find" a kidney lesion as they would understand how a lung injury would leave him helpless. Hey, whatever. Poor continuity in these scenes, anyway. Spock suddenly refuses to participate in his father\'s surgery. Instead, he must command the Enterprise because there was a murder on board the Enterprise, an attempted murder, arguments between the delegates and an unidentified alien vessel barely pursuing them beyond the reach of their detectors and their weapons. Kirk, disoriented, wakes up in Sick Bay, he says the news and must find a way to put Spock on the operating table without violating the Federation\'s rules and the stubborn oath of Vulcan. A subsequent interrogation and search of the Andorian who attacked Kirk led to interesting discoveries that will put you on the edge of your seat. Despite some cheese here and there, this is one of the most exciting episodes of the old series. An excellent show.'

b'Stephen King is best known for his books on the macabre, but what some people do not know is that he is also a master of comedy - as is the case with "The Langoliers". complex and hilarious study of the human mind. The film plunges even deeper, showing how funny people can be in the face of imminent destruction. The film and the book ask the question: "What would you do if you fell asleep on a plane, but all those who were awake are dead and that one of the people on your plane is a psychopath and another is a girl blind, who can feel bad, a bit like Haley Joel Osment in "The Sixth Sense", then you\'re looking for shelter in an airport, but all the soft drinks are flat and the food is spoiled, then you discover that these creatures look like Pac-Man (the "Langoliers") literally consume the past? `` Well, what would you do? It\'s a tricky question, and to be honest with you, I do not know what I would do. But I can say one thing, Bronson Pinchot (in a performance that departs quite far from his beloved character Balki Bartokomous in the popular TV show "Perfect Strangers") also does not know how to answer the question. Man, is he going crazy - and I\'m not talking crazy about Riggs in "Lethal Weapon" - I mean, he\'s going REALLY crazy. You can say that Pinchot really accepted this role for what it was and took the method to a whole new level. After all the laughs and the routines (the scene where Dean Stockwell drinks beer at the airport is absolutely great!), You attend a fantastic and suspenseful chase scene where the Langoliers are speeding on the plane. Just as the plane is preparing to take off the sharp teeth of Langoliers ... Sorry, but you will have to watch the film to know how it ends. That is to say if the Langoliers do not reach you first.'

b'This biopic, based on Take Me Home, an autobiography by John Denver, will be appreciated by hardcore fans (like me), but it remains horrible in many ways. The story begins in the early 1960s as John (Chad Lowe) begins his career as a folk singer. He meets Annie (Kristin Davis) at a concert and falls in love instantly. They get married and move to Aspen, but as John\'s career takes off, tension rises in the marriage. They divorce, he has a second marriage in short and discovers his love of theft, which finally earns him the respect of his father (Gerald McRaney). This film is a summary of Cliffs Notes on John\'s life; it\'s badly written and amateurish and lacks depth or emotion. Lowe (who wears a hideous clown wig that makes him look like Dana Carvey in "Waynes World") kills shamelessly everywhere, playing an innocent who never seems to grow up. (In fact, although the film covers thirty years, no one is getting older.) Davis is very pretty, but the horrible scenario does not give him much of a chance to develop. McRaney plays the only character that seems real, and he\'s the villain of the play. The story is shallow and Lowe\'s Denver is not particularly friendly. Her hair is so laughable and distracting that the movie has no chance. Although we hear Denver singing many of his songs, Lowe is terrible about lip sync. DVD supplements are worthless; Where are the pictures of the real JD that we liked?'

b'Wish You Were Here was the follow-up album of Pink Floyds, the very popular commercial album, Dark Side Of The Moon, which, among other great songs, contained perhaps their signature, "Money". Released in September 1975 Wish You Were This is the favorite album of many band members as well as fans. When he came out on the streets, he went straight to number one albums from the United States and the United States. From the first four notes - the basis of the song - he invokes a sadness, that of Syd Barrett. Recorded at London\'s Abbey Road Studios during numerous sessions. Although some of these sessions were problematic, Roger Waters\' idea was to split the "Shine On You Crazy Diamond" centerpiece into two and join each half with three new compositions. "Shine On" was a tribute to Barrett, who, coincidentally, made an impromptu visit to the studio during his recording. Wish You Were This is the second Pink Floyd album written entirely by Waters. This reflects his feeling that the friendship that had united the group was largely absent. Anchored in the themes of absence, the greed of the music industry and Barrett. The album begins with a long instrumental preamble and enters the words of Shine On You Crazy Diamond, a tribute to Syd Barrett, whose mental depression forced him to leave the band several years ago. Barrett is fondly remembered with lines such as "Remember when you were young, you shined like the sun" and "You have reached the secret too soon, you have cried for the moon". This simultaneous release on Blu-Ray and The DVD is the authorized story of the album and was made with the full participation of the band members. The film is filled with new interviews with Roger Waters, David Gilmour and Nick Mason and interviews with the late Richard Wright. Cover creator Storm Thorgerson, guest singer Roy Harper and band member Ronnie Rondell and others involved in the album\'s creation are also in attendance. the decision to split "Shine On" became the catalyst. The interviews also shed light on the fact that before Barrett left the band, he gave up or gave up trying to make music successful. he did not want to make music for "Top Of The Pops" and, ironically, members of the band blamed the music industry\'s greed on themselves as the main impetuous of wanting to make music more commercially acceptable , if not exactly "pop" songs. The film is also full of excerpts of concerts and performances as well as pieces from the group that works on the parties.Pink Floyd: The story of Wish You Were Here is a fascinating documentary that pays tribute to the group in the creation of the masterwork album. For casual fans, collectors and musicologists, you\'ll want to add this to your collection. If you\'re an aspiring musician, then you\'ll play again and again just to get a glimpse of the creative concept. Syd Barrett has been active in music for only about seven years, recording four singles, Pink Floyd\'s first album The Piper at The Gates of Dawn (and contributing to the second), as well as several unreleased songs with Pink Floyd. In 1969, Barrett released a single single, "Octopus", which announced his first solo album, The Madcap Laughs (1970), recorded in one year (1968-1969) with 4 producers including David Gilmour and Roger Waters. Nearly two months after the release of Madcaps, Barrett began working on his second album, Barrett, produced by Gilmour and Richard Wright, which will be released in the late 1970s, before becoming more than thirty years old. Barrett\'s innovative guitar work and the exploration of experimental techniques such as the use of dissonance, distortion and feedback have had a huge legacy, not only in determining the direction that Floyd would take without him, but also from David Bowie to Brian Eno the influence of drawing. After suffering from diabetes for several years, Barrett died at home in Cambridge on July 7, 2006. He was 60 years old. The cause of death was pancreatic cancer. The occupation of his death certificate was given as "retired musician. According to local newspapers, Barrett left about 1.7 million euros to his two brothers and two sisters. This amount apparently has been largely earned royalties from Pink Floyd\'s compilations and live recordings containing songs he had written with the group. The Dirty Lowdown'

b'Lacombe of Louis Malle, Lucien always impresses, although he tends to have fun in the third act at the very moment when one can expect a tightening. But it remains a discreet reminder of the less heroic side of France under the reign of Vichy (the Nazis are barely seen in the film), his derisory farmboy is only accidentally collaboration with the German police composed entirely of compatriots after having been refused for resistance. The main achievement of the film is to show, like Fascism in general, the attraction of collaboration for disaffected and underperforming foreigners in the community (only one of the "policemen" is a true fanatic) and the attraction of the undeserved power that Lucien finds the power he has over people (especially the tacit threat of giving his Jewish "girlfriend" - perhaps a little more symbolically called "France" - to the Germans) is even more intoxicating than to kill simple animals. with Melville\'s masterpiece of resistance, The Army of Shadows, there is a banal sense of reality that accentuates the drama. Located in the kind of small picturesque village that foreigners find idyllic, but which is a tedious hell to live for the locals, it shows how much discomfort and opportunities are more a driving force than wickedness. Admittedly, this is not glamor, his colleagues hang out in a local hotel getting drunk and lamenting their fate as the news of the war gets worse (as noted, you have to listen to reports from the German and British radio). and divide the difference \'\' to find the truth) and they are progressively noticed by the emboldened inhabitants. The only extra on Criterion\'s disc is the imaginative theatrical trailer, so it might be worth it in Criterion\'s box set which also includes Au Revoir Les Enfants, Murmur of the Heart and an exclusive album of extras mainly on Louis Malle rather than on the movies themselves.'

b'Paul Verhoeven and Joe Eszter opened their film with the ultimate oxymoron of love and death: the moment of orgasm coincides with the moment of greatest agony and death. Never before has a film character been killed in the throes of orgasm. Never before has such a creative and controversial opening polarized public opinion of the first scene. Never before has orgasm in the cinema reached such a frightening, cynical and dark point with every counter-penetration of the murder weapon. The very concept of getting rid of a victim in this way in the first minutes of the film demonstrates the genius of the creators - and their "mediocre" taste. But this is just the beginning of a delightfully ironic, even amusing dance. between life and death which forms the twists and turns of Basic Instinct. Besides a film analysis of the infantile and simple level of sex and violence, a great film reaches an emotional intensity too, " Scenes in which characters look at non-verbal communication access - and Basic Instinct scores 200% in this department. Directed by Verhoeven, director of photography Jan De Bont, and the actors themselves, the "looks" reach a particularly fine level when Curran and Gus meet Roxy for the first time in the scene "his and his Picassos" home . Verhoeven and again set the bar in the oceanfront scene on the deck in which Curran, Gus and Trammell meet for the first time. The cut and the movie score in this area are so beautiful that it hurts. It is surely the most beautiful score of Jerry Goldsmith, whose power throughout the production is invaluable. Nonverbal glances are the key, and Joe Eszterhas\'s famous dialogue makes Basic Instinct such a coherent and vital film A delightful character rub, this Basic Instinct is absolutely perfect - at least until the violent sex scene between Curran and his psychotherapist, which seemed unnecessary, but adds a touch of madness to Curran and Garner\'s relationship. The fact that this relationship is discussed openly in the department brings the final touch to contradiction and astringency. A great film simultaneously stimulates all parts of the mind, from the most intellectual to the most primitive, and the Basic Instinct of gore, emotionally satisfying interaction, and intellectually stimulating intrigue. Basic Instinct is jam-packed with classic and memorable scenes, but most scenes of sex and violence are definitely off the list. Verhoeven has to do it with taste and trick, of course. No missteps here. But who cares how they can make love or stab themselves? This is the trick between violence, fantastic interactions and thorny dialogue of one of the best movies ever assembled, which makes Basic Instinct so great. The scene with Dr. Lamott, Dr. Garner and all the police staff, particularly remarkable and satisfying, highlights the ambiguity and folly of the film\'s basic themes, again with the brilliant support of Goldsmith. the pinnacle of Michael Douglas\'s career - and Sharon Stone for that matter. Aside from Douglas\'s astute expressions, let\'s not forget this fabulous voice. Douglas is simply incredible and I have never liked seeing a main character attacked by all the other actors in the cast, especially his own people. A particularly underestimated performance of Denis Arndt, Lieutenant Walker, Curran\'s immediate supervisor. acridic and sardonic delicacy for the continuation of Curran\'s investigation. If characters like Curran and Walker are irritating, then Stone as Trammell is the ultimate lubricant, nothing sticks to it, it can easily get out of any situation. Basic Instinct dares to portray an invincible murderer without guilt, without weakness, who, as an antagonist, outweighs Curran\'s seduction. Finally, I would like to address Jan De Bont\'s beautiful camera movements, associated with long, multi-character dialogs loaded with camera movements, enhancing the European style and making this film one of the most enjoyable films to watch in Europe. terms of camera movement. The interaction of the camera and the actors is electrifying in its vitality. I really enjoyed Verhoeven and De Bont\'s comment on the Blu Ray. In his craft, Basic Instinct goes well beyond the average thriller to become the ultimate thriller against which all others must be measured. This film will last by far on its critics - the best Verhoeven film by far.'

b'My seven year old son wanted to learn piano, so I bought a traditional piano book for kids - he ended up crying. I was looking for a way to teach him that would not destroy his passion and creativity, nor steal his joy of learning. While browsing the library, the title "Piano for Quitters" caught my attention. A few days later, my son was writing nice chord progressions and asked that "musical practice" be added to his daily work chart so that he could play the piano before his other tasks were completed. Our whole family now learns to play the piano and to love it! I am a former piano fan - I managed to survive for a year of traditional piano lessons and tried several other piano methods, but using Piano for Quitters (and its sequel: Piano for Life), I learn to play music with my children and my husband.'

b'Almost nine years after watching the film for the first time and nearly 34 years after the events, the movie "Apollo 13" seems even more captivating. The story of Apollo 13, for all those who followed the space program and especially for those who witnessed it, is a story as captivating as that told throughout American history. It is fraught with drama, intrigue, twists and dangers. Moreover, everything really happened! In April 1970, the American public already saw the tremendous success of the landing on the Moon as a past. and could not have been less concerned about the Apollo 13 mission. The interest was so apathetic that the astronaut was not even broadcast while the ship was about to enter the lunar orbit. The capricious public certainly had its pique interest when, shortly after the unsupervised broadcast, a simple maneuver cleaning the house (stirring the oxygen tanks) revealed a fatal flaw that caused a tremendous explosion. This explosion made Apollo 13 out of control, put an end to any hope of landing on the moon and left a lot of doubt about the fate of the three astronauts (Captain Jim Lovell, LM Fred Haise pilot and the pilot of the module Jack Swigert). The heroic efforts put forward by Mission Control members, as well as the astronauts themselves, to bring Apollo 13 back to Earth safely, are one of the greatest stories ever told. His own personal account of this mission has created one of the greatest historical movies ever shot on screen. Apollo 13 is a real cinematographic success. He rekindles the imagination and wonders if the space program was held in the 1960s and early 1970s. Using advanced special effects in the service of history (and not instead), Howard is able to give the public a close-up view of the Apollo mission. Using archival footage to create special effects scenes, the director is able to make the launch realistic, as if the viewer stood at the top of the tower and watched the rocket about to take off. The scenes in space are well designed and extraordinarily realistic. When astronauts are forced to stop a large portion of the lunar module and the entire control module to conserve energy, the public feels the cold and abject abandon that these men have had to undergo. The true mark of the greatness of this film lies in the fact that, although we know by history that the men of Apollo 13 have survived, the last moments of the season, as presented in the film, are still incredibly striking and tense. Then, the emotional release that comes from knowing they did it is so overwhelming that even the most cynical and hard-nosed viewer will feel choked. The narration and effects of Apollo 13 are excellent, but the film would probably still fall short if it is not the case for the huge cast engaged to play these roles. Tom Hanks is solid while the impressive Jim Lovell, Bill Paxton (who always seems to find a way in every blockbuster) is good as a confident rookie, Fred Haise, and Kevin Bacon gives an accurate representation of last-minute substitute Jack Swigert. Gary Sinise plays Ken Mattingly, astronaut Swigert replaced because of the fear of a measles infection, with appropriate melancholy. The other performance is that of Ed Harris, who plays director Gene Kranz. Harris really deserved his Oscar nomination for this performance and there is certainly a strong argument for him to win the award over Kevin Spacey, winner of the finalist actor. "Apollo 13", himself, was a serious contender for the honors of the best film, losing only in front of the brave "Braveheart". The only disconcerting question is why Ron Howard was omitted from the Best Director nominations (he should wait another 7 years before receiving his due for "A Beautiful Mind"). Apollo 13 is not just a big thriller. it is also a revealing history lesson. This allows us to remember those wonderful days of the quest to reach the moon, as well as the drama of this endangered flight. These days, it is discouraging to realize that the space program has stagnated since these heady days. "Apollo 13" proves, without a doubt, that we still have the men with the will, the knowledge and the courage to take this space exploration to places beyond the imagination.'

b'On my short list of movie titles not to be missed in 2011, Jose Padilha\'s "Elite Squad: The Enemy Within" was certainly at the top of the list. I first realized Padilha with the 2002 feature documentary "Bus 174", a true and unforgettable story of a bus hijacking that was very public in the Brazilian media. It was a poignant image that had as much to say about contemporary journalism, rampant crime, local corruption, political maneuvering, and the state of the police as it was about the actual event she described. I think it is fair to say that some of these same themes have remained a constant in all future film projects of the author / director. That said, I want to point out that "Elite Squad: The Enemy Within" is actually a continuation of the 2007 project titled (you guessed it) "Elite Squad. "Although both films are certainly more useful as companions, they have a story in their own right that can be appreciated on their own merits. If you choose to see this without seeing the first frame, you may miss part of the character\'s story, but the scenario allows you to become familiar with it quickly and efficiently. The film focuses on the character of Captain Nascimento. actually played by Wagner Moura. Moura is responsible for a special criminal unit and when a riot in the prison goes badly, human rights defenders (led dramatically by his ex - wife \'s new husband) question tactics and decisions. of the brigade. Public opinion, however, is on the side of Moura\'s quick and uncompromising action and places it in an even more powerful position. By targeting the elimination of the Rio drug crisis, it targets the lower-class slums where the problem has the greatest weight. But by eliminating the obvious enemy, he could give way to a more unexpected enemy. As unscrupulous policemen and politicians argue over the new power, Moura begins to realize he has cut off a monster\'s head to see another (more damaging) one. Unable to trust those in power, he sees new allies in the media and activists who once criticized Moura\'s methods. The filming is compelling and credible and undeniably scary. The film is shot in a rigorous documentary style that makes the inconvenience all the more tangible. Although the narrative may be a little too much on the analysis of the voiceover, Moura\'s point of view remains in perspective, because the great story leaves him on the sidelines for large portions of the action. In essence, this is a morality game disguised as a ruthless crime saga - but in the same vein, it is surprisingly underrated. The character changes are subtle and the action is inexorably real. It is difficult to imagine that the film can have a happy or satisfying conclusion, but what remains to us certainly seems appropriate, even if it does not sum it all up in a pretty little bow. In the end, the characters distinguish this piece (Moura is fantastic) which has universal relevance in its themes of corruption and those who fight it. "Elite Squad: The Enemy Within" is a rare image that will make you think during the entertainment. About 4 1/2 stars. KGHarris, 2/12.'

b"This DVD was extremely useful to me as a self-taught knitter who started with socks several months ago. The comfortable format of a mother and her daughter, sitting on a couch and discussing knitting and demonstrating various techniques, was very helpful. It's a joy to watch at so many levels. I love the spirit of Elizabeth Zimmermann and her daughter Meg Swansen 's expertise. The well-organized index provides easy access to different techniques for later review. This DVD is full of information because it is very well edited and includes a beautiful interview at the end. I highly recommend this video to new and experienced knitters. I also bought the DVD Knitting Workship, but the glossary is the most useful of the two."

b'"Destination Moon" and "Rocketship XM" both came out the same year - but that\'s where the similarity ends. I consider "Destination Moon" as the father of the modern science fiction film. The quality of the production and the magnificent Technicolor give this film a quality that few sci-fi movies from the 50\'s could achieve. What helps this flem is the fact that there are no real stars - but very competent players and very recognizable at a minimum. "Rocketship XM", meanwhile, was a pressed film designed to beat "Moon" at theaters. The print quality in black and white is beautiful, having been restored to its original quality. Lloyd Bridges stars. The special effects for "XM" were suitable for their time, but the effects for "Moon" were ahead of their time. If I wrote down these films, I would give "..Moon" a B + and "XM" a C +. Both films are nice and make beautiful pieces of accompaniment.'

b'+++++ This film is based on the musical piece "Cabaret" (also called "Goodbye Berlin"). The music and lyrics are from the big John Kander and Fred Ebb respectively. It was directed by, and the dance and music numbers were staged by the late Bob Fosse. Personally, I\'m not much for musicals, but this film is more than just a great musical. Do not believe that there are just songs and dances. There is also a good story about corruption, decadence and false dreams of Berlin in the early 1930s, when Hitler came to power. The story follows the life of Sally Bowles (Liza Minnelli) during this turbulent period. She is the so-called star of the Kit Kat nightclub who has a mischievous master of ceremonies (Joel Gray). Writer Brian Roberts (Michael York) intrudes into Sally\'s world, hoping to take the vacant room in front of his. He soon learns that she is a ball of fire and energy. She tells us her dream: "I\'m going to be a big movie star. That is, alcohol and sex do not appeal to me first. `` The film alternates between real life and hard outside Kit Kat nightclub and carefree life indoors where attendees can forget about their troubles and troubled times. the drama of real life outside. Five songs from Broadway\'s original production did not appear in the film as "interpreted" songs, but appeared as background music. The music, the costumes, the choreography and the game are all exquisite. Minnelli\'s performance, impressive on stage and equally convincing, is particularly impressive. Added to this is Gray\'s fascinating performance as Master of Ceremonies, which infuses humor and pathos as well as effervescence and solidity. The last scene of singing and dancing performed by Minnelli is historic and unforgettable! This film has won eight Oscars including Best Actress (Minnelli), Best Supporting Actor (Gray) and Best Director (Fosse). Finally, the DVD itself (released in 2003) is perfect in image quality and sound. He has a long list of interesting extras. In conclusion, I recommend going to this cabaret (old boyfriend). You will never want to leave! ! (1972, 2 hours, widescreen, 32 scenes) +++++'

b'Never say, & quot; Everyone here is crazy but me? You\'ll love this scary, minimalist, low-budget and very claustrophobic thriller 1948. Inspector Richard Carlson registers in an asylum to try to find a dishonest judge hidden in the law. But before he can hit the judge, his identity is discovered and he becomes a prisoner of his own regime. And the only person who can save him is the double-crossing woman who sent him there! A thriller with sharp edges of the director Budd Boetticher ("The Killer is Loose", "Comanche Station", "Bullfighter And The Lady") who will later become famous in a series of strict and existential westerns ("The Tall T", " Ride Lonesome "," Seven Men From Now ", etc.) featuring the damaged moral solitaire Randolph Scott an ambiguous amoral environment. Personal note: In the 70\'s, I met the late Budd Boetticher as a friend. We were going to horseback at Griffith Park with his Andalusians and we made several trips to Mexico where he still practiced his dangerous and adored horse riding bulls. In life and in movies, he seemed obsessed with the role played by the male antagonist in his constant struggle against his environment. Boetticher preceded director Sam Peckinpah in themes that made him famous. Boetticher was the real thing. It\'s great to see this little gem available on DVD. (Full screen, B & L, 68 minutes, ungraded.)'

b"Stereotyped characters, convoluted logic and abundant lack of intelligence are found in & quot; Domestic disturbance, & quot; a thriller that wants to be mean, but ends up playing nicely. What begins with a rather interesting film resonates in an endless pit of incredible twists and aggravating characters who make all the wrong choices. Here is a film that covers a familiar terrain, but does not attract much interest when things go wrong. John Travolta plays Frank Morrison, a boat builder whose ex-wife Susan (Teri Polo) is about to remarry. This, of course, is unacceptable for their 12-year-old son, Danny (Matthew O'Leary), whose explosions against his parents' divorce led to being picked up at the police station on numerous occasions. Like any good father, Frank advises Danny to accept what he can not change and to welcome his new father-in-law, the rich and popular Rick Barnes (Vince Vaughn). Now, anyone who knows his thrillers can guess that if there is money involved, then there is usually a tainted past here and there; this film is no exception. The wedding goes off without a hitch, despite the presence of Ray Coleman (Steve Buscemi), a former acquaintance of Rick 's who will collect a large sum of money from his former friend. One thing leads to another, devices appear, and Rick has a murder on his hands, without knowing that Danny has witnessed the act of the backseat of the car in which he occurred. This is the first in a series of scenes that look promising but have little intensity or surprise. Judging by Danny 's & quot; Boy who shouted Wolf & quot; syndrome, it is easy to predict that no one will believe him when he reveals what he has seen except Frank, who must hold grudge to his son's abuser if there must be an action or an energy in the history. There's a little bit of cat and mouse going on, Frank is looking for the missing ray and possible clues to pass on to the police, but that does not lead to anything. The film seems more interested in showing us how stupid people can be in such situations, even if they are incredible. From the beginning, Susan stands by his side to defend him against Danny's accusations. Does he ever think that when a strange event occurs, Rick is out of the house at the same time? Does she ever stop thinking about how her disbelief in her son's statements affects her, rather than the old song-dance about her marriage to Rick? Even the police are completely helpless, ignoring everything to the end when it matters little. My big complaint with & quot; Domestic disturbance & quot; is his publisher, which has reduced the film to just 88 minutes, too short for a thriller and too long for a documentary about vengeful fathers. Paramount's advertising campaign for the film hit us with a large number of TV commercials in preview, as well as a long revealing theatrical trailer. There are scenes in both cases, one involving a car chase, the other involving a discussion between Rick and Frank in which Rick tries to buy it. These and other glimpses are not even included in the final cut and may have been more interesting than what we see here. The highlight is the standard forage, but it has the ability to generate more intensity than the rest of the film. Travolta makes a good performance, convincing us of his loving father status; Vaughn does not manage to create a sense of threat, while Polo does little more than look completely helpless. For all its attributes (which are few), & quot; Domestic disturbance & quot; adds nothing new to a used genre; his absence of lucid conspiracy could be neglected if not for his inability to generate a certain level of suspense. Note: The film was shot on the east coast of North Carolina, in Southport, but in one scene, Ray mentions that his location was a memory of Rick's childhood about family vacations in Maryland. Your thoughts, Mr. McNally?"

b"Armand Assante is one of my favorites. I liked all his movies. I was so surprised to see him in a doo-wap role, but he was fantastic as always. His emotional performance of a man who lost his wife to cancer and is now facing the potential loss of his daughter because of the same disease is heartbreaking. His relationship with his two sons also brings a reality to a parent's love for his children and the torment of his singing career. His band of the 50s and he was a great success, but were quickly removed from the limelight. Over the next 30 years, he works as a bartender and his band plays for weddings. If you like doo-wap and Assante, you'll love this movie. Nostalgia at its best I recommend taking the audio CD and reading it before seeing the movie, so you will really appreciate it."

b'For the big fans of Manhunter, I advise you not to use this DVD if you plan to own ... What was billed as "& quot;" Theater & quot; the version is actually a poorly edited version that clumsily edits two scenes that were in the theatrical release, including one of the most essential scenes, and yet contains some of the most mundane images restored from the floor of the hall cutting. These cuts are poorly made and do not make any sense to them, considering how they do not represent the release in theaters and destroy the momentum of what had been a finely edited film. I do not know if it was ignorance or arrogance, but it\'s the worst hacking job I\'ve ever seen trying to pretend to be a product. Whoever was responsible for that in Anchor Bay was an idiot and if I were Michael Mann, I would call my lawyers. The & quot; Director\'s Cup & quot; is even worse in that it includes the & quot; Non-theatrical & quot; release AND the so-called & quot; Director\'s Cup & quot; - a compilation of some interesting and uninteresting catches. In addition to a real theatrical release, it would have been a fascinating addition. But here again, Anchor Bay finds a way to ruin what should be a good product. The entire movie that has not been submitted to video post-production is stained and blurred, as if it had been transferred from a VHS cassette - and worn out. - just amazing that anyone can have the audacity to offer this kind of low price for hard earned money. I saw this movie when it first appeared in the theater and considered it one of the best of this year; and I rushed to buy the LaserDisc version when it came out. When Anchor Bay released the director\'s DVD this year, I was on the waiting list, ready to welcome the big-screen THX version. Being intimately aware of the film, imagine my disappointment. Do not waste your time. Wait for a better version to go out. As for those who want to compare Silence of the Lambs to Manhunter, they generally prefer each other and their ideas are pretty well established at this point. I\'m right in Manhunter\'s camp. For me, I enjoyed Silence, but I could never take it seriously, because I found Lector\'s portayal both superhuman and surreal and therefore unrealistic. However, Lector by Manhunter is a terrifying but more realistic portrait that intrigues me every time I see it in the way that an evil genius manages to manipulate events outside his cell by simply using a phone. This Lector is safe behind the steralized bars - and yet still manages to be a powerful presence with which to count. and edgey, and yet that flowed gracefully. Siskel and Ebert ranked it among the best films, years after its release. But for now, I\'m going to keep my LaserDisc.'

b"This is the romantic comedy by which all other romantic comedies are judged. Billy Crystal and Meg Ryan have an undeniable chemistry and exceptional timing. And, surprisingly, Bruno Kirby and Carrie Fisher, who really have good moments for the film. This movie knows no one knows how to better present Manhattan than Woody Allen and that he borrows a lot from his traditions. Including the choice of romantic pop standards. As in Annie Hall, & quot; It must have been you is the centerpiece of music for an inevitable coupling. The dialogue is lively and rhythmic with an ear attentive to the New York sensibility. And also knows how to best show New York's hippest places. Even Billy Crystal is a bit nebulous. Yet this film is an original and its style has been imitated countless times by other films in the hope of capturing some of its magic. Yet none has the upper hand. The icing on the cake was the wonderful choice to interrupt the passing seasons of Harry and Sally's relationship with the old couple telling stories of their first encounter. The way they talk and tell stories is charming and authentic and makes you smile. When Harry Met Sally is a cheerful and very very funny movie that never gets tired, no matter how many times it's seen. It's a classic. The DVD contains an additional 7 minutes of deleted footage. In this case, it is pretty obvious why it was deleted. Look at your own risk. The audio commentary by Rob Reiner seems to have been broadcast at the forefront. Do not look for a lot of happy stories or ideas about the best ideas. The commented track is quite slow and dry. The & quot; Making of & quot; Documentary is a little more fun and insightful, so the extras are not a total wash. The sound and picture quality are both brilliant and lush, so the most important part of the disc, the movie, is as enjoyable as possible. When Harry Met Sally has a lot of fun with men and women trying to understand each other and makes us laugh a lot and even cry a little."

b'MAD MAX 2: THE ROAD WARRIOR must be one of the most intense action movies ever produced. There is very little that I could add to this already popular film. Unlike the special edition of MAD MAX DVD, it is at best austere: a dolby 5.1 mix and subtitles "passable". That\'s all . The quality of the images is only "acceptable" (the dark scenes are very pixelated and difficult to understand!). No comment of director, no backstage, nothing. For a film that praises the LANDMARK in science fiction and is as influential as STAR WARS, the DVD available is a shameful disgrace. Why has nobody ever bothered to publish a special edition? We see so much "trash" coming out as "special edition" yet we still have to wait for a defensive DVD of MAD MAX 2. As you may have guessed, my review is about this most criminal offense. I rate MAD MAX 2 with an 11 (yes, it\'s a VERY entertaining movie) but the DVD really stinks. Let\'s hope Mr. Miller comes to his senses and pulls out a DVD package for the movie he\'s probably going to do. to be called back by!'

Then there are jokes about European hygiene, with huge insects crawling on our heroes when they are in the next hotel. Driving in Europe? b'This is not a criticism of the quality of DVD, cinematography, gaming, etc., but rather the essential element of what I consider to be the smartest movie of the year, even if it is not is not imperfect. * Spoiler alert * From what I read, it seems that most of these reviewers did not grasp the ambiguity of the end or, if they did, they found it too implausible. The old group (most moviegoers), not realizing the ambiguity of whether he had really done that or not, seemed to miss the last line coming back to the conversation with the director, the philosophical knot of the film, to which Leo is resistant to accepting that the nature of man is violent. If nothing else, the last line suggests that if he really did what they say, he has at least some level of self-knowledge, his craziness and refusing to live with her. Or he may have always been sane, that he was really right about what was going on and refused to accept their suggested recollections and the opinion of the director, but realizing that he did not could ever escape and decide to die of heroes Regarding what some have said, this last premise is too incredible, I do not agree. Why is it so hard to believe that a country would be incapable of something like this? During the period in which this film unfolds, most US states continue to sterilize the mentally and physically disabled. Would it be such an important moral step to turn to the experience of psychotic criminals, of people without a future, for the sake of our national security, of our way of life, of our dominance in world affairs? Of course, this interpretation of the end of the film is problematic. It would be a coincidence if the four names were really anagrams of themselves. He has dreams all the way through the film that allude to the finale, even before the explanation was suggested by the doctor (although I only saw it once and something could be missing). with Rachel, so why was there a total lack of surrealism, unlike all other sequences of this kind? The practical answer, to convince the public until the end, is not credible. The contradictions here seem to come from the fact that Scorsese revisits the same theme he explored at the end of the "King of Comedy", and the same style: one wonders if this really happened or if everything is in the mind of the character. I did not read the book, but from what I understood, Scorsese added a layer not present in Lehane\'s work, where everything is simply in the spirit of the character, similar to "The Machinist" (do not hit Lehane). : with his psychological depth and his misanthropic view of human nature, he is the heir of the great Clouzot - but probably with more success in "Mystic River". By adding ambiguity in the end without modifying some points of the plot to start, gaps in logic appear. If it were to be cleaned up a bit, I would not hesitate to classify "SI" with "Raging Bull" and "Taxi Driver". Despite this, it\'s still one of the good ones.'

b'I have been a fan of X-Men since I was 9 years old. In recent years, comics have become obsolete and almost impossible to follow (a situation that Marvel Comics has repressed lately), and despite the fact that the first X-Men movie had more than one chance, I really did not think about it. So I tried to keep my expectations low for the X-2 ... The good news is that it\'s MUCH better than its predecessor! X-2 does not need to bombard viewers with so much information (since this has been supported in the first movie), and can virtually hit the ground. We resume where the first film stopped: Magneto is in prison, Wolverine looks for clues about his past and anti-mutant hysteria is endemic. Enter William Stryker, a hate fanatic employed by the government, excellently played by Brian Cox. He sends the blue-skinned Nightcrawler mutant to demolish the White House and strike the president in the awesome opening sequence, ensuring presidential cooperation with the anti-mutant agenda. Stryker does not waste time setting up a secret strike team, and their first target is ... Professor Xavier\'s school. It looks like they have chosen the wrong time to visit, though; The children are alone at home with their "babysitter" ... Let\'s prepare ourselves at RUMMMMBBBLLEEEE! ! ! Before you know it, it\'s the total war between Stryker and the assembled mutant faction; Magneto is out of jail, Xavier and Cyclops are captured and used by Stryker, and the scene is preparing for a fight at Alkali Lake, where Wolvie might discover interesting information about his skeleton and his Adamantium claws. Fans disappointed by the lack of action in the first film will be in their glory here, as the number of fights has increased, including an excellent duel between Wolverne and Deathstrike, played by the beautiful Kelly Hu, and the Wolverine berserker rages in the mansion. Love the way he sends Stryker\'s criminals ...! Director Bryan Singer has put together an excellent cast and each character is doing well. The new additions, Cox and Hu, do a great job with their respective roles and the end sets the stage for X-3. Long-time fans will love X-Men\'s pillar appearances such as The Beast, Colossus, Siryn, Artie and Kitty Pryde, and will be on the lookout for the likes of Gambit and Franklin Richards, among others. Bad news ... ? The film starts strong but trails a little towards the end; Maybe a tighter fitting was needed. Also, given the heaviness of the movie about the characters and situations developed by the Chris Claremont comic book scribe, including the intrigue of his legendary graphic novel "God Loves, Man Kills," I was more than a little dismayed not to see him recognized in the credits. X-2 is not a perfect movie, but it\'s a big step forward from the previous X-Men movie, and a great way to start the summer season.'
