b'Ally McBeal has ended for good, even if this compilation of episodes reminds us of what was great. Focusing on Ally (Flockhart), still single, slender and crazy, the public is led into her hallucinations (brilliantly realized via an impressive computer animation), her loves, her losses and her work in a law firm that seems to embrace the \'strange. What made this show awesome was that it was so different, with David E. Kelley\'s sharp writing bringing a mix of well-placed observations on modern relationships and absolutely hilarious characters. Who could forget John Cage (McNicol), the small lawyer with a domestic frog and a craze for Barry White? Add to that Richard Fish, who seems to wallow in his own male chauvanism, "Subzero" Nelle (diRossi) and the deliciously naughty Ling (Liu) and you have a hot cast that is pretty nice of it all. Recent episodes have been criticized for not being funny enough, this may seem unfair, although there is still a tendency to be nostalgic of the old episodes proposed here. It balances remarkably well, romantic and sad, and these first episodes were truly revolutionary, paving the way for other more experimental shows. However, it would be nice to see the seasons in full because they are available in the UK.'

b"Down Argentina Way is a delicious and light musical from the early 1940s that should appeal to anyone who loves this type of movie. We get great performances from big stars, including Betty Grable, Don Ameche, Carmen Miranda and the incredible dancing Nicholas Brothers! The plot is moving at a good pace and the acting was quite convincing. The action begins when Glenda Crawford (Betty Grable) and her mother Binnie Crawford (Charlotte Greenwood) are once again on the circuit. It seems that the Crawford family has always loved horses and they run them too. Glenda sees a beautiful racehorse and she wants to buy the horse, but the horse belongs to Don Diego Quintana (Henry Stephenson), a crab who has a long and stupid grudge against Willis Crawford, the patriarch of The Crawford family. Be that as it may, Glenda and Binnie are going to Argentina after their first attempt to buy horses in Quintana. It is not long either that Glenda falls in love with Quintana's son, Ricardo Quintana (Don Ameche), who is also seduced by Glenda. The young couple tries to get Glenda Crawford to Don Quintana as Glenda Cunningham in the hope that he will love her and then not worry about being a Crawford; but that also has its complications. Meanwhile, there is a horse for the race - will Don Quintana ever leave the horse race? It's a fragile sub-plot, but the few horse races we see in this film reinforce the action; and everything is fine with me! Look for great numbers of songs and dances - remember that these intrigues were only excuses for the studio to film fabulous songs and dance numbers. According to rumors, after the audience first saw The Nicholas Brothers, they so encouraged the projectionist to redo the film to show their stage again! Charlotte Greenwood also has a great ability to play with her legs as she happily dances in another issue. Betty Grable also dances very well. In addition, this film marks the debut of Carmen Miranda's film; she sings some songs during the film and a short melody at the very beginning of the film. Carmen shines even when they do not play it as much as in later movies! The DVD comes with an extra superlative on Betty Grable's life and times. She really looked like a particularly sweet girl who did not want to live too much and enjoyed her private life the best she could. The quality of the photos in the extra on Betty Grable is excellent. There is also a common but optional comment for people who want to know what was going on behind the scenes during the filming of this movie. Awesome ! Overall, Down Argentina Way is a musical that is worth the detour. I usually reserve five stars for a MGM musical; but this time, Fox has really succeeded! Fans of classic musicals can not afford to miss this one!"

b'Whenever a film is turned towards "realism", it usually opens the door to a predictable set of signifiers: portable cameras, real locations, natural lighting system, urban dialogue and tortured theatrical methods. In only two feature films, Funny Ha Ha and the new Mutual Recognition, writer and director Andrew Bujalski reconfigured the language into something much closer to reality. His aesthetic and semi-improvised dialogue has earned him frequent comparisons with John Cassavetes, but he does not care so much about acute emotion; the characters in his films are awkward and inexpressive to the point where they can not say how they feel, at least not without having to look for it first. Mutual appreciation is no more than a refinement of Funny Ha Ha, who follows a similar group of disordered girls as they struggle with relationship problems and try to give life to their lives. And yet, it\'s just as strange to watch, because Bujalski\'s stylized dialogue mark really sounds at full speed. The charismatic Justin Rice is a musician who moves to New York just after the separation puts him in a strange place because he has to play later in the week. Once in town, Rice returns with her friend Bujalski, a graduate student, and Bujalski\'s girlfriend, Rachel Clift. Meanwhile, Rice finds a champion and more in attractive university radio DJ Seung-min Lee, but runs into trouble when he brings Lee\'s brother as drummer and tries to get away from him a little. Rice and Clift meet, and a serious break in their relationship with Bujalski, but nothing in Mutual Appreciation goes according to the usual scenario. The scene in which Rice and Clift finally express their feelings for each other is the perfect example of what Bujalski does so well. you betray both of them What ends up happening between them is completely unexpected, but quite true for who they are and how most caring people would act. But such things rarely happen on screen, and Bujalski\'s willingness to follow him makes him a singular talent.'

b'Just upstairs, with "Planes, Trains and Automobiles" and "There\'s Something About Mary," there\'s my favorite Billy Murray comedy. `` Goundhog Day \'\'. Murray (as TV Weatherman Phil Connors) is easily the only Hollywood star in the film, as the rest of the cast is far less well known in the field. Andie MacDowell was probably better known for her modeling career in 1993 than as an actress ... she does a great job as a producer of "Rita". Chris Elliot did a great job in a less boring role than he was under the name of "Larry", the cameraman (he has evolved a lot since "The Man Under The Stairs" on David Letterman). The other actor who really makes an impression is the man with the recognizable face, but what is his name (Stephen Tobolowsky as life insurance salesman Ned `` Bing! \'\' Ryerson). Oh, and scooter the groundhog. As for the story, Bill Murray is stuck in the same cold day (which happens to be Groundhog Day) in Punxsutawney, PA, covering the now famous festivities. He continues to live the same day again and again. Every day he sees the same things. Every day he meets the same people ... the man in the corridor early in the morning, Doris the waitress, the mayor of the city, etc. He decides to make the most of the situation and does whatever he wants ... only because he knows he will wake up the next day and it will be the same day again. As he is tired of reliving the same day again and again, Connors is focusing on Rita. First, try to impress him. Then, trying to really take care of her. When it finally reaches it, the spell is broken and the next day appears. I classify some of Bill Murray\'s films as classic ... "Caddyshack", "Stripes", "Scrooged", "What About Bob", etc., but I put "Groundhog Day" at the top of the list. Easy choice for my favorite movie Bill Murray. Also an easy choice for one of my first 4-5 comedies of all time. *****'

b"This is a fantastic movie, but please read other comments about acting, camera work, plot, story, etc. This review only concerns the DVD version. The DVD itself is a big disappointment. Poor transfer, no extras, no surround sound, full screen only, and no menu or chapter choice. Like other Stanley Kubrick DVDs in this white boxed series, this Full Metal Jacket is pretty much a VHS duet of the movie. I'm surprised it's not double-sided like the original commercial DVDs. Given the advancement of DVD technology on the release of this disc, it was not necessary to sell such a mediocre product, in addition to trying to incorporate as many Stanley Kubrick films as possible in a large box. before Christmas 1999. This film, The Shining, and to a lesser extent, The Clockwork Orange, all suffer from the same extremely poor DVD processing. Fortunately, soon this film will be reissued in a better DVD package, just like the needs of Goodfellas or The Shining. Until then, buy this DVD only if you are a big fan or if it is in the basket of bargains."

b'One of the most delicious films of recent years, "Calendar Girls", a distorted version of "The Full Monty", is the true story of a group of middle-aged British women who have become international celebrities when they have designed and posed for a nude fundraising calendar that has sold millions of copies worldwide. Julie Walters and Helen Mirren lead a terrific cast, with Walters as a woman whose husband dies of leukemia and Mirren as best friend who proposes the idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bthe calendar to honor her memory and raise money for the local hospital. . The risk for a comedy of "feeling good" is that it will become scathing, unpleasant or unhealthy. Fortunately, "Calendar Girls" offers an extremely spiritual scenario and exceptional performances from its very talented actors. Each of the "girls" has her own personality, so we see them not only as a group, united in this inspiring enterprise, but as individuals working on their own personal demons until the completion of the project. Women face the expected roadblocks and snafus in the form of "shocked" and disapproving voices in the community, but their belief in the rightness of their cause eliminates all these problems. This charming movie offers more authentic laughs than most recent comedies. "Calendar Girls" is comforting, touching and inspiring - and what more can you ask for a "well-being" film?'

b'Watch `` The fragrance of green papaya? is like listening to a harmonious song. There is not much dialogue in this film but you will not feel bored. I appreciate the quiet, elegant and graceful mood of the film. He uses many simple melodies and close-ups in the film to reflect the mood of the characters. The visual and auditory beauty brings you comfort when you look at it. The first part of the film takes place in 1951, it is at that time that the French authority has almost ended. The French occupied Vietnam for more than 30 years before 1954. During the French administration, the Vietnamese had been influenced by the French. In the first half of the film, Mui lived in a traditional family of children. The grandmother lost her husband while she was still a teenager and she insisted on praying every morning for her husband and remaining faithful to her. The father left the house with another woman and took all the money a few times, but the mother never resented him. Instead, the grandmother blamed him for not knowing how to please his own husband. In the second half of the film, Mui moved to a musician as a servant. The musician, who is also his master, named Khuyen, was influenced by the French and knows how to play the piano. His house has been decorated in a French style, colorful and bright. Unlike the previous family, simple, antique and all in wood. Khuyen was engaged but later discovered that Mui was very attractive after getting dressed. He fell for her and after he broke up with her fiance? and married Mui. This film shows the difference between a traditional Vietnamese family and a modern Westernized family. Not only the living environment has great differences, but also the perception of relationships.'

b'Welcome to The Rileys attracted me more and more as the film progressed; At first I thought it was a little slow, but when the pace accelerated with the backdrop of New Orleans, I was rather impressed by what he had to say. The casting could not have been better; Melissa Leo gives a remarkable performance as a guilty homemaker and punishes herself for a car accident that took her daughter\'s life a long time ago; and James Gandolfini performs a masterful performance as her husband Doug who simply can not override his grief and personal demons. Choreography and cinematography enhance the film and the musical score does an excellent job of making the film even better. Lois Riley (Melissa Leo) and her husband Doug (James Gandolfini) are still very upset even though it\'s been eight years since their daughter died in a car accident. Lois has not left home since the car accident; Indeed, Lois was so depressed that she already has gravestones for her and Doug next to the grave of their deceased daughter, a fact that gives goosebumps to Doug. Doug also has a long relationship with a waitress named Vivian (Eisa Davis). However, when Vivian suddenly dies of a heart attack, Doug is very upset and always sadder. and he suffers in silence because he does not know that Lois knew about him and Vivian for quite some time now. and still be upset by Vivian\'s death (he had wanted to take him on his birthday) and feel out of place in a very different city from where he lives with his wife, Doug leaves the convention one day and walks around a strip strip where he meets a minor call girl who has several different names, including Mallory (Kristen Stewart of "Twilight" fame). Doug and Mallory begin an unconventional relationship; she reminds Doug of her daughter. So what does Doug do? He phones Lois to tell him that he stays in New Orleans indefinitely without giving any reason to Lois; He moves in with Mallory, paying him $ 100 a day to stay with her in his very dilapidated apartment in an abandoned house after Hurricane Katrina and Doug try desperately to grow Mallory with a combination of love and confrontation that Mallory has need. Meanwhile, Lois decides to finally leave their home after nearly eight years of indoors - she is determined to drive to New Orleans and find Doug there by calling her on her cellphone. Of course, the rest of what is happening gives us a very solid story and good entertainment. I could tell you more; but there will be no spoilers here even if it may seem to have already told you too much! Suffice it to say that the rest of the plot should hold your attention. In addition, Tiffany Coty, Tara and Lance E. Nichols, will perform very well in a very brief appearance as Hamilton \'Ham\' Watkins, another convention businessman. the film.I recommend this film for anyone interested in dramatic family drama or theater in general; and of course the fans of the actors of this film would do well to add that to their collections.'

b"This delight is located at Miramont Place, Pimlico (a neighborhood in South London). When an unexploded bomb left by World War II disappears, local merchant Stanley Holloway discovers an ancient treasure trove, including a mysterious document. An eccentric university professor (Margaret Rutherford) translates the document, and this proves that Miramont Place was the site of a palace given to the Duke of Burgundy in exile by King Edward IV, making the inhabitants of Miramont Square from Burgundy rather than of Great Britain. The locals go wild, tear up their ration books and keep the local pub open all night, they have fun until the government becomes mean and begins to crack down on them. Enter a good French, who turns out to be the current duke, come to claim his inheritance and save his subjects from the iron hand of the beurocracy. Under the flag, the Burgundians defy the metro trains and force the passengers to pass the customs. The government is fighting back by cutting off their water supply, which will win in the battle of the spirits? If you're an eccentric British comedian, this movie is a classic of its kind."

Since I bought it, I watched all the episodes at least twice more, my favorites over. It's really a must have. If I could, I'd give this series a higher rating."

b'CHARLOTTE SOMETIMES is a nocturnal film, a story that gently crosses the lives of four people and with very few words about human relations, the cocoons that we turn around us for security, protection against fear hope the chrysalis becomes a butterfly or butterfly. Eric Byler must be commended for having the courage to keep this story simple - a story of four "personality disorders" and how they find the way to exist in this strange world. Michael Idemoto may be the loneliest on the outside, but the four characters seem to crave the connection and just can not get on. Eugenia Yuan is the idiosyncratic girl, Jacquelyn Kim is the woman of mystery who, with Matt Westmore, plays more a catalytic agent than a character. The four actors are beautiful, sensitive and convincing. Lighting and settings are well chosen. In all, this small independent film is a discreet diversion, which deals more with what is not said than with a simple script.'

b'This morning, I tore the retractable film with the joy of a six-year-old offender who had received a day pass at a Cadburys candy factory. I then sat down to watch it and emerged two hours later with the smile of a 51-year-old Cheshire cat on Viagra. We all know that "The Italian Job" is a 1960s classic, but what you do not know is that this 40th anniversary reissue (published on June 15, 2009 in the UK) is simply out of place ... First, print - which is GLORIOUS - as perfect as you might expect and a joy from start to finish. And although it does not show on the outer box, this is the fully restored version of the British Film Institute, which has been image-by-image cleansed (and these shots are used in the "Making Of"). also ) . One of these features is the trailer for the 30th anniversary reissue of 10 years ago, which uses the famous "van doors" sequence. Untouched - it\'s covered in scratches and has no definition - it lets you see what the movie stock looked like compared to its beautiful appearance after the restoration. There are so many scenes coming out now - like Matt Monro \'The cheesy song\' On Days Like These \'is playing and the car is crossing the Alps in the credits - when Charlie gets out of jail as he walks through the gates and Maggie Blye l welcomes in a stolen car from the Pakistan Embassy - when the three Mini Coop climb on the roof of the football stadium with the Italian cops in pursuit - that\'s all BEAUTIFUL. The BFI has also produced "Zulu", "The Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner" and "Saturday Night and Sunday Morning", which corresponds to the same standard (see my reviews). The extras are also generous (almost two hours): 1. Commentary with screenwriter Tony Kennedy Martin and writer Matthew Field2. Comment from producers Michael Deeley and Author Matthew Field3. Mini Adventures (in HD) 4. "Self-Preserving Society: Get Rid of Italian Jobs" (in HD) - introduces new interviews with actors, writers, producers, including Michel Caine, Maggie Blye , Troy Kennedy Martin, Michael Deeley, Noel Coward, director Peter Collinson, Quincy Jones on the nice score etc ... 5. Music Video (in HD) 6. The deleted scene with commentary by the author Matthew Field7. Theatrical Trailer8. Re-release TrailerThe cast was of course a mix of luck, fate and genius - Caine perfect as Charlie Croker the likely guy, Benny Hill as computer boffin, the suave but deadly Raf Vallone as boss of the Mafia and Tony Beckley as Camp Freddy, dressed dandily. But the biggest blow of all was Noel Coward as Mr. Bridger - the master criminal doing his time in Her Majesty\'s Prison Service. He has tea and scones, worries about the British economy and sees his cell covered with photos of the queen. Coward is simply priceless as he talks about the "Rule Britannia" prison cover, played behind him by a string quartet - that\'s enough to make you scream with laughter ... You see, you forget how much The Italian Job is the catty gay tailor who says that Charlie\'s pre-owned clothes could now be part of a museum exhibit, with Coward standing next to two prison guards as they handed him his two newspapers and one roll of toilet paper. The astonishment of prison governor John Le Mesurier, while Coward complains, is that "his" toilet was invaded by Michael Caine (throwing him a burglary) - the toilet of a man is his castle ... John Clive has the money Michael Caine has given him to take care of his Aston Martin DB - he has been in his garage for two years while Caine was in India. "I was shooting at old tigers ..." The owner of the garage counted fifty, "... there must have been a lot of tigers sir ..." The places in Turin are wonderfully colorful, the mountain scenes as crisp like James Bond reissues and Caine\'s freckles clearer than ever - all that - what a peach! I saw a lot of old movies in the new BLU RAY format - some were successful, some were lamentable - but they are the best. In fact, as a man who loves the medium and believes in its possibilities, I suspect that it will tickle pink Michael Caine that his films "Zulu" and "The Italian Job" both contribute to the creation of BLU. RAY as "the" format to restore old movies and keep them properly. Forward for David Lean\'s boys ... As you can tell - and if you forgive the pun - I was blown away. I loved it, loved it, loved it. Recommended - big time.'

b'Having seen this film several times, I must absolutely note Gigi as one of the most charming musicals ever made. The beautiful score of Lerner & Loewe includes songs such as "I Remember It Well", "The Night They Invented Champagne", "Thank Heaven For Little Girls", as well as the title track. "Gigi", sings with a surprising candor and serious by Louis Jourdan. The three directors, Leslie Caron, Louis Jourdan and Maurice Chevalier, as well as Paris locals, contribute to maintaining a distinct French flavor, particularly in the way the characters are linked and interact. For all those who commented on the politically inaccurate nature of history, a closer look will reveal the true feminist perspective of Colette\'s revolutionary work for the time: 1) History is a commentary on social and economic options. limited economic opportunities of women outside marriage (or prostitution elsewhere) at the turn of the century, 2) Although Gigi (Caron) never completely master her lessons and grooming, she can capture the heart of Gaston (Jourdan ) precisely because of its imperfections and 3) the most important is Gaston rather than Gigi who is forced to really transform and challenge the social conventions of the time to bring history to its resolution. Compare that to My Fair Lady, who offers a similar social comment but resolves in a more standardized way; although Professor Higgins finally realizes his love for Eliza in the end, it is Eliza who is forced to submit her will by making a reconciliation that solves none of the issues raised in the scenes that preceded this point. Really see Gigi and judge for yourself. (Make sure you only watch the widescreen version!) The full screen version is awful with whole characters cut off from certain scenes, like Hermione Gingold for most of the "I remember well" sequence.)'

Pretty much right away, I look like an art student who caresses the chin and jumped on his own importance. But watch the movie and you'll see what I mean. The best part of this movie is that it's sad, that the end is not a huge twist or a drift, it's just deeply sad, and there are not many movies that evoke that feeling in me today. I'm finished ."

b'Where is your home ? The most important place. Where do you want to say something to other people? Mac, who works for the head of the oil company (Burt Lancaster) - more interested in astronomy than the next big oilfield - based in Houston, where he does business a million dollars by phone before brunch, finds himself sent to an isolated Scottish coastal village to negotiate a major refinery project. At first, the slow pace of life of the inhabitants frustrates him - why can not he seal the agreement and go home? But then the magic of the place begins to seep into him. The things he thought were important are not really important. And the truly important things in life begin to reveal themselves. And Mac finds his real home. Funny, light (everyone wants what he wants, no one loses it) but deeply touching, this film is a rare thing - which does you good, in all kinds of ways, indefinitely. Somewhere, a phone rings, someone calls home. Where are you going to call tonight?'

b"Femme Fatale is Brian De Palma's film noir about a woman (Rebecca Romijin-Stamos), who makes bad choices by taking an innocent (Antonio Banderas) to his site. It has the iconic De Palma signature - eroticism, intelligent cinematography and a film that moves only by pure style - but in the end you will feel empty and, unfortunately, short-term for the time you have invested The film begins with a spectacular and unlikely burglary at the Cannes Film Festival in 2001, during which Rebecca and her team strive to relieve an almost naked actress of her few body protections: a gold and diamond serpentine bodice and accessories . Although visually and musically interesting, the opening scene requires many oversights on the part of the viewer - for example, ignoring the fact that a large part of the project, despite its Mission Impossible style configuration, relies on guards who search poorly. irresistible. Things go wrong and in the end, Rebecca doubles her team, gets rid of the goods and seeks another life. She finds one in a couple looking for their runaway girl, which Rebecca is so discreet for this woman. s own parents can not tell the difference. It assumes its identity, claims its tickets for America and, by fate, falls into the romantic embrace of the American ambassador who is on the plane. Life is beautiful until the paparazzi photographer Antonio Banderas takes his elusive photo, announcing his presence to the two villains. From there, Rebecca looks for the exit-left lane that brings her the most money at any cost. The story plays like a checklist of eroticism - there is voyeurism, a striptease, sad at the Cannes Film Festival. Brian De Palma does it all with style - split-screen, breathtaking angles - and it's fun to watch him in action - but that's still not enough to fill the gaps in the story. film themes in a good money, but will leave you betrayed. Despite the power of star, I did not appreciate Femme Fatale. Granted, Rebecca was not blue - fans of her X-Men role will not be disappointed. The character of Antonio Banderas presented one or two interesting scenes, but most of the time, they were mistaken in doing everything that was manipulated, without original solution. Seeing it happen with a smart breakaway would have been a much better end - but, instead, the end rested on an exaggerated trick to get out of its sad final.Pass on Femme Fatale - even if you're looking to see Rebecca in a light non-X-Men. In spite of all the pomp, it's just not worth the investment."

b'Synopsis: John Ritter plays Roy Knable, a real couch potato whose life and marriage disintegrates around his ears as he watches TV to escape all that. The same evening his wife Helen (Pam Dawber) plans to leave, a mysterious salesman named Spike (Jeffrey Jones) seems to be selling a new TV to Roy, with a gigantic satellite dish that will transmit 666 channels directly into Roy\'s living room. Yet, something goes wrong when Roy and his wife are sucked into the satellite dish and enter the hellish world of Satan TV. From there, it is urgent to survive before the time is up. About the film: Stay Tuned is probably one of my favorite comic films. I saw it for the first time in the early 90s and when I saw that it was released on DVD, I jumped on the opportunity to get it. Stay Tuned is filled with humor and slapstick, a lot of very twisted plays on classic TV. s and TV shows. Among them are Saturday Night Live, Star Trek Next Generation, Three \'s Company, WWF and classic cartoons. The comic is presented in a wonderfully delightful animated sequence that was supervised in production by legendary animator Chuck Jones (who did a lot of cartoons of Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck). The comical timing of Ritter helps to make this film. Although this film has never been much noticed, it is certainly an excellent example of John Ritter\'s comic career that lasted more than two decades. Eugene Levy ("SCTV" and "American Pie") also plays a major role in this film as Crowley, a Hell TV Exec who helps the Knables on their journey. He managed to play the adorable slimeball in a fun way. Jeffrey Jones plays the villain, the CEO of Hell TV, Spike. He is an excellent actor for the villain in a comedy, and he manages to be convincing and funny at the same time without rendering the role stupid, as happens to the bad guys in fashionable comedies these days. With John Ritter \'As the timing is comical and Pam Dawber plays the role of playmaker from the mad channel to the demented channel, this movie is great for a lot of laughs. About the DVD: Stay Tuned comes in a cardboard DVD case. It is presented in widescreen format with Dolby Digital 5.1 sound. Both the image and the sound are pretty good. I did not notice any problem with either. The DVD is translated into French (why not Spanish?) And contains subtitles in English, French and Spanish.For special features, the DVD includes a trailer, info on the distribution and a preview of the film . The distribution information is simply a list of actors in the movie. They do not even provide bios for them, making it a clear case of building content with minimal effort. The featurette is the guy they used to show on TV just before the release of the movie, with interviews of actors who are not at all enlightening if you saw the movie. This is only slightly interesting. The bad news is that the music playing behind the commentator is downright annoying in the first quarter. This DVD release is a pretty good standard. An awesome movie about a standard version of DVD. 4 stars'

b'If I did not say it before I say it again, I\'m a big fan of George A. Romero\'s Night Of The Living Dead and its aftermaths over the last forty years. Thanks to him, we really know the horrible world of Zombies and undead precisely and know how much it can be trapped, whether it\'s an old farm, a suburban mall, an underground bunker or elsewhere. an attack by the pork butchers of the living. Of course, once you\'ve created such a popular character in Horror, you get a dumb copy trying to take advantage of your original creation. Curiously, most of these types of films have had various successes, including the Italian Zombi filmmakers of the 1980s. Unfortunately, the one that triggered everything, that of 1968, due to a copyright snafu, has never had this right and it soon became clear that everyone could publish it, possess it and / or make any version of it. the plot and the title as they wish.But first, a little history: in 1998, Anchor Bay and John A. Russo (one of the men who contributed to the creation of the original \'Romero \') decided to release a version of the 30th anniversary, but instead of simply republishing the same print as all the other DVD makers, he shot and added new images with the old one, creating a new plot that is hurting only to the original film, but betrays the social commentary that was inscribed on it. the first place . A real misstep and the fans were not happy. However, when it came to finishing the remakes, at least someone had understood before that. In 1990, with the personal advice of Romero and the special effects genius Tom Savini at the helm, they realized a Night Of The Living Dead that stayed close to the original screenplay, giving these 90-year-old audiences not only a pride, but better in some aspects of gore and production values. So, after a good remake and a learning error in what not to do with a classic, could it be redone? Apparently not . In 2006, with director Jeff `` Corman Wanna-Be \'\' Broadstreet under the presidency, they decided to try again, of course without the consent of Romero, but this time with a twist: let\'s try to do in 3D! 3D? Really ? This seems like a curious idea, but it really falls flat here. Being blunt NOTLD3D is a travesty. Filmed in a non-existent budget, it must be the worst "reimagination" of a movie since the 2001 Planet Of The Apes. Of course, most of your favorite characters are here, but this time, mixed and interpreted by actors who are so stiff, it is difficult to distinguish them from real zombies. And the story is so slow and boring that it seems like a 3 hour vision of something you expect to see on Sci-Fi Channel. Moreover, while the gore factor of the 1968 original was at best minimal, 36 years later, we still do not see much, if at all, but for financial reasons, and at mid-term, I wondered why was it noted "R" in the first place. These are new intrigues, the sets are boring, and the appearance of Sid Haig, who has just been crowned by the icon of Horror (which in my opinion is not the biggest deal), is totally useless. Establishing that it was the pinnacle of selling movies. The main attraction is 3D, is not it? False. Instead of using the latest stereoscopic 3D technology (ie with "shades of gray"), they opted for the obsolete anaglyphic type (red / blue) that turns the entire film into a purple salvo. And do not expect anything for you to "jump". When it works, and it\'s rare, it only gives the depth of the backgrounds, which means your picture looks deeper, no closer. It should also be noted that apart from the backstage features, this entire disc is in 3D, which means that without the glasses, it is impossible to grasp it. There is no 2D version on the disc included as it should have been (this version is released separately), so once these glasses are there, it\'s the ultimate coaster. In short, bad movie, bad 3D, bad idea. It had already been redone in 1990 and eight years later, it had already received a gimmick that did not work either. Even as a movie alone, a flix like Day Of The Dead 2: Contagium is a better movie. Hard to suggest, even if you are a completeist like me, NOTLD3D is a dead film that should remain buried. (RedSabbath Rating: 3.0 / 10)'

b"It would be difficult to formulate a coherent film composed of disparate elements that the director and others obviously had to include in this scenario, but a commendable attempt is made, only to collapse after the first semester . A pre-Columbian ceremonial disc, gilded and adorned with jewels, was divided in two and, while half is on display in a permanent collection of the New York City Museum, the second became a research expedition to an Andean region the aegis of the American archaeologist Brooks Willings (David Keith), who is obsessed with his recovery. His wife and daughter stayed in New York but when young Diana (Camilla Belle) became a disciplinary problem in her school, the two men join Brooks in the Andean village where her expedition is based, his wife hoping to correct the distress behavioral of Diana. only to be overwhelmed by additional problems from their new situation. The continuity wavers as Diana mingles with the mystical rituals of the village, which Brooks and his wife (Nancy Allen) enjoy great marital discord, a Catholic priest portrayed with humor by John Rhys-Davies is tormented by local cultists, Expedition has developed shortages of staff and funding, among other things - too much discussion to weave into a completed scenario. To solve his many self-imposed puzzles, the work turns into foolish fantasy, including stupid special effects, in easy resolution. Keith is in wood, obviously uninspired by her role, but Belle is efficient and Rhys-Davies' timing deserves to be studied, while the acting laurels go to the stunning East Indian Roshan Seth, who easily dominates each of her scenes in the shaman part with extraordinary wisdom and magical powers. Filmed in the picturesque province of Salta, in northern Argentina, the painting benefits both Maximo Munzi's cinematography and Luis Bacalov's faithfully ethnic notation; if only one way had been seen to reinforce the stuttering scenario."

b'When Conan the Barbarian was released on video in 1981, I was one of the first to get it. The film did not lose the impact it had on me when it was 20 years old, and well ahead of all those pitiful movies of sword and witchcraft that made its appearance, including the terrible sequel Conan the Destroyer. so high in my esteem? Certainly not in the quality of acting; When you have two bodybuilders, a surfer, a sports star and a dancer like five of the main actors of this movie, then you\'re not going to have a theater class - but again this type of film does not need it . But having said that, they did a good job when the script demanded emotion. Mourning, indecision, loyalty, friendship. Everything was there. And revenge.Revenge is actually the thread of the story. For this, the co-authors John Milius (the director) and Oliver Stone must be applauded for not only daring to deviate from the path of Robert E. Howard\'s pulp books that gave the world Conan, but also for us give a coherent, tidy and pleasant script that does not insult the intelligence (unlike later). We have strong characters with whom you can sympathize and the bad guys you want to get with their own deserts. Arnold Schwarzenegger in his film debut is perfect for the role, as is James Earl Jones as the main antagonist, Thulsa Doom, who is so demonic and so powerful that he encourages a devotee to commit suicide just to prove a point to Conan. And throughout the story is a note of superior quality written by Basil Polidouris. From the beginning of the opening credits, there is a deep and thrilling percussive sound that can bring the viewer to another time and another place, and make them believe that it is the music of that time. Mako\'s voice over as the story is presented is unforgettable and I remember when I first heard it, my jaw dropped. BANG! In the theme song. Gutsy, hard and a delight.For me, the remarkable memory is the brilliant cinematography used when Conan prays his god, Crom, just before the final battle. He calls for revenge, while the camera turns with Thulsa Doom\'s tough cohorts, music in the background. Fantastic cinema is playing and can not be improved. This should never be redone because they could never do a better job. This has a great story, a good score, strong characters, unforgettable scenes, which unfortunately were missing as a result. I am not bound by any fidelity to Robert E. Howard\'s pulp fiction, so I do not care that this film has moved away from the "real" Conan world.'

b'This film is a refreshing look on romance, very European (although of American manufacture) and with a fantastic chemistry. The unique, funny and (pseudo) intellectual conversation virtually incessant throughout the film is great and the characters are believable. One could almost think that the actors were not following a script but were instead looking at it, discussing their real ideas and plans. Although there may be a bit of kitsch "we are all star dust," the character\'s reactions quickly correct any slippage of the reality of two stubborn young travelers to one another and with life. The scenes of Vienna, the Prater amusement park, the clubs and especially the caf\xc3\xa9 scene are extremely faithful to reality. With so much waste created by American directors today, it\'s great to see a little gem like this.'

b'The following story will tell you why this movie bombed the box office. While my family was visiting Miami, one of my cousins \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bhad gone to see the movie. When he went home, he told me how bad the movie was. As he spoke, it became obvious that he had taken the film seriously. So I shouted at him, "It\'s a travesty! ! He does not care about action movies in general and himself in particular! ! "I could see the light bulb light up over his head and he came out and saw it again. Needless to say, he loved the movie. As I do . It\'s not often that a big star has the courage to make fun of himself to make his fans laugh. So, if you have this film lying around in your collection somewhere, you have to see it in that spirit. It\'s parody. Comedy satire! Watch it and have fun.'

b"It is rather difficult to see these films again, because you have to understand all the reasons why this film should fail miserably. First, it's the sequel to Interview With the Vampire (though the third book in the series). The second book in the series (The Vampire Lestat) was not made in film, the producers of this film had to compile two books of history in one film. This is one of the reasons why the film left out most of the two books (read the books, by the way). Secondly, this film was a continuation of the extremely popular and successful Inteview With the Vampire. It was therefore quite impossible to repeat this formula. One of the reasons for this is that the previous movie was shot with very big stars (Tom Cruise, Brad Pitt, Antonio Banderas, Christian Slater), while Queen of the Damned was composed with only one: Aalyiah. The rest of the cast was relatively unknown (Stuart Townsend is not really known yet). All of these problems aside, the movie itself is pretty awful. If you have read the book, you will be very disappointed, mainly because much of Rice's rich characterization is lost. No story of the vampire is revealed, more precisely the legend of the twins, which is totally absent. The rest of the vampires are seen only towards the end of the film and they are never named by name. If you have not read the book, you will not be able to tell who is who. Another silly point is that the older vampires, despite their short time on the screen, dress with the clothes of the time they were made, which is totally wrong in the book. Something that others might consider minor is the lack of disappointing physical resemblance between the characters and their counterparts in the books. For example, Marius is described as a man in his forties, with long gray hair and a beautiful face. Jesse is much older in the book, with very prominent red hair, and Armand's brief appearance is completely false, since he looks more like Lestat. The only good thing about Armand's physical appearance is his age: he is much younger here than in Interview With the Vampire, because the books say that Armand was made a vampire at the age of 17 years. Lestat is the only one that really looked like his description. Stuart Townsend was very much like my conception of Lestat, even though his voice was too deep. Still, he did not look as good as Tom Cruise in this game. Physical resemblance is important because vampires are described as being very sensual and beautiful, and the movies suffer from failing to bring these literary characters to film life. I will not really start with the inaccuracies with the book; there were too many. The main freedoms (apart from the absence of other vampires) were the relationship with Marius and Lestat. Lestat was not done by Marius, as others have pointed out, and Marius, portrayed as an evil vampire, whereas in the book he is Lestat's mentor and he only kills wicked men. The end is totally different and impossible to compare and contrast here (read the books). The main reason I think this has failed is that the film sacrificed a rich story for the refractions of pop culture. The soundtrack of this film and Lestat's brief career as a nu-metal star do more than anything else. For the reasons I described at the beginning of this review, I think the filmmakers were doomed to repeat the success of Interview With the Vampire, but that's no excuse for not even making an effort. Producers try to find excuses, especially for cut scenes, where they try to explain why they cut out more footage from other vampires. In conclusion, Queen of the Damned is a miserable failure, mainly to give up a rich and exciting story for references to pop culture. As I said, it would have been impossible to repeat the success of the old vampire movie, but this movie is just too horrible to stand out."

b'I liked Saturday Night Fever when I saw many years ago and it is still my favorite movie. A common misconception is that it\'s a Disco movie or a musical (like Grease). Saturday Night Fever is a hard, sometimes rude and violent look at the world of the working class and club life in the 70s (I was a little too young at the time of the Fever release to join the clubs but it was the same in the pre-AIDS world of the early 80s when I started playing club). Violence, sex and insults are REAL ... it\'s like that (and it\'s a bit without Bee Gee)! it\'s for !!) for those in Brooklyn (and other places in New York). John Badham did a great job putting the life of a 19-year-old who lived for the dance club on Saturday night. was frustrating and was not going anywhere (remember the lines: "Your shot, you can not find anywhere else?") It was the most powerful line and sums up Tony Manero\'s life. Saturday night The fever is brutal, hard and great! ! Up there with Taxi Driver for a representation of gross character!'

b"You would think that a film with such a cast of stars would have redemptive qualities but this one does not do it. The characters are flat and provide no reason for the audience to be emotionally attached. The starlet character centered on Zeta-Jones is awful and dull, the depressive and lonely character of John Cusacks is unbelievable and impossible to attach to, Billy Crystal's news agent who tries to please everyone seems to be only present because she has a big smile. The highlight, if you can call it the love character of Hank Azaria's aliens. His character is horribly stereotyped, but at least he acts a little while speaking with an accent (even if the accent is exaggerated). Even Christopher Walken, who is good at pretty much everything is lost in this movie. His small role as a filmmaker does not even make sense - there is nothing in the film that gives clues to the end in which the Walken character plays a big role. b'Harvey Pekar\'s comic, American Splendor, has launched a new genre: the autobiographical comic book. At first glance, the daily events of a Cleveland clerk hardly seem to be the material of an interesting film. Fortunately, filmmakers Robert Pulcini and Shari Springer Berman are able to take what was funny, heartbreaking and fascinating about the life of Pekar and successfully adapting screens of the page to the big screen. Like Ghost World, American Splendor defends foreigners who do not correspond to the dominant society. In summary, the DVD contains a mini-comic that briefly tells how Pekar adapted his comic strip to a movie. The disc itself contains a captivating audio commentary featuring real Harvey Pekar, his wife Joyce, their daughter Danielle, his friend Toby Radloff, directors Robert Pulcini and Shari Springer Berman, and actor Paul Giamatti. Everyone has fun on this track because they joke and remember the film and its experiences. "Road to Splendor" is a brief update of what Harvey has done since the creation of the film. The song "American Splendor" Eytan Mirsky, which appeared in the film, can be heard in its entirety. . His voice is strangely similar to that of Evan Dando of the Lemonheads.Finally, there is a movie trailer. American Splendor has the same ironic sense of humor and melancholy as Ghost World, another great cinematic adaptation of an independent comic book. American Splendor remains true to Pekar\'s vision - he refuses to sentimentalize his life, even at the emotional conclusion of the film that is truly moving. This is one of the most beautiful adaptations of comics ever made on films because it stays true to its sources and uses its creator to transfer its story from the page to the screen.'

b"The film is a strange animal, okay, a work without genre, and Gordon sometimes seems to surpass himself, grasping the effects he is not able to achieve. The various styles, moods and genres give the film a slightly garish and amateurish look, but in the end (perhaps consciously from Gordon), this clumsiness works in favor of the film. The Singing Detective is a remarkably ingenious, fresh and daring work, almost childish in its lack of pretension, and easily one of the most original American films of the last twenty years. Most importantly, it features the painful, distressed and bitter pulp editor, afflicted by Robert Downey Jr.'s psoriasis, at the head of which the film unfolds (more or less) and Downey gives an inventive and powerful performance. huge talent Despite Downey's praise, Gordon's film ran into a wall of critical resistance, a real consensus of contempt. This may be due in part (at least in the UK) to a penchant for Potter's original television series; but it may have been due even more to the fundamental incompatibility of Potter's idiosyncratic and scathing vision with traditional (critical) tastes. Anyway, the film has once again tragically failed to find its audience. Like his previous adaptations, Gordon respected the source material without reverence, and as a director, he has a rare gift: the ability to merge his own sensitivity and talents with his subject at a fundamental level. In the case of The Singing Detective, it was a somewhat less homogeneous fusion; Potter's vision (his strange blend of musical fantasy with a dark psychological realism) was so surprisingly original that it required another sensitivity at least as strong and eccentric to merge. Gordon does not yet have the surrealist gifts to embrace Potter's vision, or to move to the next level (David Lynch could be the only director capable of that). He is a competent director from all points of view and seems to have the chance to have a natural rapport with the actors (perhaps why so many good people want to work with him). Yet Gordon is not a visionary director, and it was a visionary scenario. Fortunately, he had a visionary actor at a career peak to take over, and Downey wears the day. The Singing Detective is not a masterpiece; it is flawed and fractured and sometimes thin, even easy and sometimes redundant (especially in pseudo-black sequences). But it's an imaginative and intrepid film, an admirably eccentric work that manages to do something like justice to a brilliant writing. Full of inventive delights and heartfelt touches, he leaves most of the recent American movies in the dust. Yet both in the United Kingdom and the United States, it has failed so poorly that many people (including myself) have missed it, suspicious of the stench of failure. In this case, the bad smells did not come from the film, but from too corrupt and jaded critics to recognize a work of art when they saw it. (Excerpt from Keith Gordon's True to the Muse: Life on the Fringe, by DOGVILLE VS. HOLLYWOOD, by Jake Horsley)"

b'Seeing this musical on a New York stage is an unforgettable experience and I went to see her four times. But seeing it on film is a totally flat experience. It just does not work on the screen for me. Although you have a cast of talent, the incredible energy and electricity that went through the scene were not found here. The musical is a carefree story based on a village and wet environment, filled with the edge. Since I lived in New York for 30 years, I immediately felt at home with this hidden world that the average person can not imagine. But spending two hours in a movie theater, watching this depressing and depressing story unfold, is a dark experience. The musical numbers all seem forced. People are not very friendly. They are all too dramatic and intense for the comfort zone and the reason the film bombed, is that Central America probably could not understand why the people in this movie did not pay the accursed rent - and avoid all the drama and problems! This film worked very well in the big cities where there were people who could identify with this story of tragedy and AIDS. But even for someone like me who knows this world very well, which takes place in the village where I lived, it is a depressing and depressing experience with very few optimistic feelings. I could not sympathize with drug addicts and prostitutes or any of the electrified musical numbers. They should have gotten a new cast for the movie version and open it up more in the dark and still wet world around this film treatment.'

b'"The Exorcist" by William Friedkin is a landmark. The cultural psyche is still recovering from its arrival on the scene more than thirty years ago. It\'s a masterpiece that will continue to last long after many horror movies have been forgotten. Actress Chris MacNeil (Ellen Burstyn) asks Father Damien Karras (Jason Miller) for help after his daughter Regan (Linda Blair) begins to behave strangely. Realizing that something is wrong with the girl, Father Lankester Merrin (Max von Sydow) is summoned to do an exorcism. It then follows a terrifying battle between the forces of good and evil, which pushes all actors to their physical and spiritual breaking points. Words can not effectively convey the power of the "exorcist". "It\'s a film that tirelessly attacks the senses and does not apologize. The genre entries that followed had no choice but to follow his example, as he redefined alone what the audience understood as a cinematic horror. Although Linda Blair rightly receives a lot of attention for her excellent work, do not neglect the equally powerful performance of Jason Miller as Father Karras. It gives the film an important human element that keeps it rooted. Without Karras\' bow, "The Exorcist" is just another punch that is trying to win quickly with thrills. Truly revolutionary, "The Exorcist" is an amazing work that has dared to test the limits of filmmaking. No serious discussion of the great cinema is complete without mentioning it.'

b"There are those who criticize JFK, claiming that Oliver Stone ignored the facts and rewrote the story. True or not, it completely misses the point. Stone himself stated that his intention in making the film was to get his audience to question authority and think for himself. The film is presented as a POSSIBLE explanation (a combination of two separate theories) for the unusual events that led to the assassination of Kennedy, and it actually raises more questions than it solves. The casting is phenomenal. Award-winning cinematography and editing are revolutionary to say the least. Despite your opinion of JFK's politics, the film is one of the very few that I would say perfect. That's why I'm a filmmaker and every second you spend watching it is worth it. You will never forget it."

b'First of all, I want to inform you that I am a big fan of Recess. So, that comes from a fan\'s point of view. So, do you really want to know what it is? If you\'re a new fan, and you have not seen all the episodes, then this is an excellent DVD for you! If you are a parent and consider it just a whimsical entertainment for your child, I would suggest it to you, but mostly because the DVD and episodes are hilarious, but can also convey good messages of friendship and trust. I know most kids like this because my younger cousins \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8b(about 8-12 years old) also love the cartoon and can relate to the characters with them at school. I hope this will help you!'

b"The stories of Dumas have been filmed so often, but it's always a joy to see them. This new version of Count Monte Christo is no exception. It has serious flaws and errors, too numerous to list. For example: modern lines of language, totally unbelievable interpretations (as other commentators have mentioned), very amateur characterizations (the Count turns his locks and his old love recognizes him by the gesture rather than by his appearance almost unchanged). None of these things really disgusted me. I just sat down and enjoyed. The opening scene set the tone and the photograph generally showed beautiful settings. The end was incredibly sober, but as I had just watched a wonderful fight and fencing scene in a lush setting, I did not care. background music and noises. I hope you read the book, if you have not already done so. No film has ever made the story of Dumas telling justice. The version of Three Musketeers with Michael York as D'Artagnan has come closer.If you just want to entertain, this movie can match your mood. I saw him three times now."

After talking with a trucker because their Jeep breaks down in the Utah desert, the terrifying fun begins. As in Duel de Spielberg, malevolence arrives like a big truck. The trucker named Red (JT Walsh) agrees to give Amy a lift for the nearest payphone while Jeff stays with the car. Now, it\'s easy to wonder why Jeff would let his wife go with a stranger into an 18-wheeler, but put yourself in the same situation and you\'d probably do the same thing. We will seek help, the other remains with the car. Amy disappears, never showing up at Belle \'s Diner, where she had to meet Jeff. Customers have never seen it. And when Jeff continues Red\'s Rig, Amy is not found. Even worse, Red says he has never seen Jeff before in his life. What happens now is to find the woman. "What a great excitement the cast gives, especially to Russell as a nervous, ready to step into the shoes of her husband who let his wife lose her loving hand on this lonely road when a trucker said: Come with me , I can help you. Russell turns out to be an obsessed husband who let his wife go. He becomes totally focused, almost obsessively so as to know why this city has never seen his wife, the lips are closed and you certainly have the opinion that it is CreepVille, Utah. What a fun ride. You will have sweaty hands everywhere.'

b"Robocop 2 is probably the most underrated and hardest criticized suite in history (in conjunction with Predator 2, released the same year). Because of a few missing elements from the first and a slightly more caricatural approach to violence, critics and the public were not thrilled and opinions and feelings about the franchise collapsed with the just terrible. of a good movie however. Robocop 2 always has the same sense of wild humor, the cynical social commentary and the pathetic character of the first film. It is a hyper-realistic vision of a America populated by a gun-loving psychopath, a corporate democracy and a poverty-stricken addict delivered to them by hawkers who believe they are the second coming of Christ. to be the typical way to describe it. Completely on the top would be more appropriate. Empire Strikes Back director, Irvin Kershner, engages in so much sadistic violence, deafening gunfire, endless destruction and loss of life that the film asks you not to take seriously. Cartoonish than the original. I do not think it's very fair. I read Miller 's original script when I was in high school and it' s quite different and, I say, inconceivable. Robocop 2 himself was not Nuke Lord Caine, the psychotic hippie with illusions of Godhood. His name was Kong, a psychotic policeman who practically killed everyone. Sgt. Reed and the old man died and there was not much humor. Screenwriter Walon Green has been hired to handle the script and much of what appears on the screen is actually his job. The original ideas of Frank Miller have practically remained as a frame for the whole film and part of its history has been recycled in Robocop 3 (do not blame it either). Miller was visibly upset about this, but he was still good enough to be featured in the movie (watch him play Dr. Frank), though he vowed to stop working in Hollywood for fear of profit. Until Robert Rodriguez is engaged on his graphic novels of Sin City.Verhoven may have left but Irvin Kershner strives to deliver the same mix of gaiety and magic and in fact he succeeds. The fascinating score of Basil Poledouris is also gone (she returns in Robocop 3), but the new composer Leonard Rosenman creates a wonderfully heroic and optimistic theme that is better suited to the film than Poledouris' morose and tormented score. This time, you really must feel Peter Weller walking around this Robosuit. He had to weigh a ton and he would sweat bucket loads inside. There is a special scene in the film where Murphy is tortured into near-death / destruction, which is very difficult to watch. But this leads him to make new skin and to put himself at the head of these new insane directives. The piece where he gives lectures to Little League children and scolds young people playing with the leaking fire hydrant (after citing a very suspicious philosophy) is hilarious.Robocop 2 is a great movie. Despite some problems with the script and the story and some slightly outdated stop-motion effects, it's a brilliant sequel that meets expectations. Listen to the unspoken. I do not know what kind of movie they were waiting for. And thank you for not smoking! The DVD is a 1.85: 1 widescreen anamorphic widescreen with vibrant colors (take a look at the chrome of Robo's armor) and Dolby 5.1 sound. I am a little sad that there are no comments such as comments because I would have liked to hear what Kershner has to say about the film. And there are deleted scenes I know who have visited Murphy in his grave and some more details on why Caine is so strange. We can only hope that in the future ..."
b'Do not be fooled by the first two reviews published by Amazon on this page. This DVD is the authorized version and the quality is fantastic.'

b'This 30th anniversary edition features the original movie Night of the Living Dead and features a new soundtrack and new scenes. As far as I\'m concerned, the original movie was perfect as is and it was not necessary, but I decided to stay open and give this edition a chance, knowing that the new material was written by John Russo ( who co-wrote the original film), and Hinzman\'s photography (and acting) (which also helped to create the original). I was completely disappointed. The new scenes include a new introduction, various scenes of zombies scrolling and killed by hicks and a new epilogue. The various scenes sometimes interfere with the unfolding of the film, the makeup is less effective and some of the new extras are terrible. They do a decent editing job in the new scenes, but they are still noticeable (for example, the modes are not quite correct). The new introduction and the epilogue are ridiculous. The intro simply states that the leading zombie (played by Hinzman) was a criminal when he was alive. This removes from one of the movies the most effective elements: the zombies could be your neighbor or a close friend or relative, but they will still try to kill you. Hinzman is obviously older in the frontal shots (the profiles are correct). When he starts attacking two gravediggers, one of the "actors" begins to flee and then realizes that Hinzman was supposed to catch him first, so he goes back to the coffin and bends down so that Hinzman can catch him! ! ! The fact that they have not taken a second shot shows a lack of care. The epilogue is an interview "a year later" with a preacher mad of fire and sulfur, who survived the carnage. He is stuck in the middle (spoiler warning) of the scene where Duane Jones was killed and the end credits showing the hicks throwing his body! ! Talk about interfering with a very effective ending! You have the opportunity to watch the original cut (on a great copy), but you can watch it with the new soundtrack! The old soundtrack consisted of library music, but it worked perfectly. At best, the new soundtrack is mediocre. Sometimes it does not even fit the mood of the scene, for example, being frenetic when the action is more calm and depressive. The booklet contains mostly interviews with actors talking about how new scenes have been added and how old fans will love the new (fake) version. There is a fun commentary track, but you get the same people (as well as others, including Romero) giving the same information on the commentary tracks of the very superior Elite Millennium Edition.'

b'I wanted to enjoy this movie so much. I kept hoping that in a way he would "get up" and get on his feet. Unfortunately, this has never been the case and, in fact, has given way to a weird nothingness somewhere in the middle. Basically, this is a cynical paranormal writer residing in a hotel room where all sorts of bad things have happened over the years. And really? That is just about everything. Yes, there was so much to work on in the story. It could have been deeper, the plot more involved. The characters could have been so much more than them. This film is a hodgepodge of often nebulous clusters that are never attached. It moves at the pace of snails and you wait for something that never happens. The end is incredible and artificial. b'Interview With A Vampire was an excellent film, beautifully made from an incredible idea. The vampire Lestat (wonderfully played by Stuart Townsend) decides to come out of retirement, which is actually a sleep of several hundred years. It gives a great overview of the world of vampires - you know, hate light, garlic and all things sacred. love the darkness, the necks of young, attractive women of blood and the eerrr "Nu-Metal! "But what annoys him the most is that he is immortal. I mean he does not age at all, seems to have unlimited financial resources - yet he is so bored with life. It seems to me to be a sort of spoiled vampire! So, he thinks that if he can totally provoke all the other vampires, then maybe they will get so angry that they will get him out of this eternal misery - and who better than the Queen of the damned - or Aaliyah to us? . How does it provoke them? Well, he becomes the singer of the most important and controversial Nu-Metal band in the world. Hey, I would definitely be with all the other vampires. There are interesting aspects to this film: how he became a vampire and how he reacted is quite fascinating. In addition, everything is done with typical Gothic colors and images. The monologue of his thoughts is filled with a comical irony and is delivered in a wonderful way. Some of the subtle interactions between the characters are also hilarious. Aaliyah looks amazing in her role as queen of all vampires - she really has a presence on screen and what a tragedy that her acting career and musician\'s was interrupted. The conflicts between vampires and vampires that cross the film are also quite original. Unfortunately, none of the effects are particularly dramatic. Overall, although the idea is good, development and history are too weak to make a memorable film.'

b'& quot; Coffy & quot; (1973) made Pam Grier a star, & quot; Foxy Brown & quot; (1974) clearly shows why Grier became a star. & quot; Foxy Brown & quot; simply distil Grier \'s star qualities and use them to their full potential, and by star quality, I do not just refer to his generous bosom. In & quot; Foxy Brown & quot; Grier is a mad raped, raped at all costs for revenge, it does not only gnaw the scene, it erases it. But that\'s exactly why we love Grier. She is beautiful, sensual and she can get completely fucked! As far as I\'m concerned, she is the original action hero of the screen and this vehicle best represents her star acting skills. Unlike & quot; Coffy, & quot; & quot; Foxy Brown & quot; does not give Grier much of a chance to flex his acting muscles, but he puts Grier aside: Foxy ransacks apartments, beats hostile lesbians, tears eyes, burns men, emascule (literally and figuratively), and even shoot guns from her perfectly coifed afro. & quot; Foxy Brown & quot; It is a classic cult movie for the same reasons. & quot; Coffy & quot; may be the best movie, but & quot; Foxy Brown & quot; is more pleasant. So how does it work? Foxy Brown & quot; price on DVD? Well, the record is an absolute revelation. Since the beginning of the film, it did not seem so good. The transfer of the first image used for the videocassette and the laser disc was atrocious, with yellowish tones of flesh, excessively saturated colors, dark, dark interiors, ruined compositions and terribly raised edges. The new anamorphically enhanced widescreen transfer is bright. The compositions are properly preserved with a 1.85: 1 aspect ratio, more distracting leeway and a bit of image information is added to the sides. The interiors now reveal woodwork, earth-tone wallpapers and brown curtains, unlike the previous transfer that made almost all black or dark brown. The flesh tones are finally natural and the colors of the film are reduced to an understandable level of saturation, but do not worry, the modes of the 70s remain a bright kaleidoscope of the flourish. The sharpness is nice; the enhancement of the edges never comes out in his ugly head and the sky of the film is finally blue. Finish the olive tree and the yellow light. The grain of the film is visible in some dark scenes and there are some defects of source. Considering that it is a low-budget film produced in 1974, the source element is almost virgin. The compression on the disc, however, is not so perfect. Some dark and shady areas and dissolved bottoms are frequently subject to tiling artifacts, but for a retail price of just $ 14.95, who can complain? The extras include the amusing theatrical trailer ("Foxy has guts: no if, and or buts!") And an insightful commentary track by director Jack Hill that repeatedly describes the difficulties of working with AIP (American International Pictures) about this film, which he claimed to be one of his worst performing experiences. The monaural sound on the record is commendable; the dialogue is always intelligible and the bass level makes Willie Hutch\'s score as funky as it was 27 years ago. Jack Hill created Pam Grier his own sub-genre with & quot; Coffy & quot; and & quot; Foxy Brown & quot; and when she left him after the sadness of 1976 Friday Foster, & quot; no one took his place ... no one could ever do it. & quot; Foxy Brown & quot; is the ultimate Pam Grier action vehicle, a classic blaxploitation and an excellent DVD! If you have only seen & quot; Foxy Brown & quot; on videocassette or laserdisc, you have not seen & quot; Foxy & quot; at all .'

b"This film is about a million times better than the recent Red Dragon remake. The film's real conflict is Will's (William Petersen's) tenuous understanding of his sanity as he tracks down a killer who is about to strike while dealing with a killer he has already caught. While Brian Cox's Lecktor will make comparisons with Anthony Hopkin's version in subsequent films, Cox interprets the psychopath as a real threat - a murderer who will kill. Hopkins is also great, but I always felt that his reader was like an animal that would hit only in a very provoked way. We see Cox and Petersen as equals on both sides of the fence, with little difference between them, aside from Petersen's knowledge of good and evil. This thriller is one of the best."

b'I am a long time follower of Smallville and every year there are always fans (including myself) who mark the current year as Jumping the Shark. If you go through my profile, you will see that my critics of the old seasons start with enthusiasm and become more critical over the years. Even if I will not comment on season 8, the trend seems to be confirmed when you compare season 7 to the previous 6: they are quite great compared to this brothel. on this year. Smallville always has great comic stories, but lacks development and internal logic in his own world. The authors jump from one plot to another without any stimulation, so you get dramatic events that change life and are completely forgotten by the next episode. There is a shocking twist involving the new Daily Planet Editor which has been shortened when it becomes interesting; the return of Clark\'s biological mother, Lara, lasts just one episode; Bizzaro appears and is quickly defeated - twice; Clark travels in time and space to save his baby on Krypton in five minutes. Sam Jones finally returns as Pete Ross and is wasted in a horrible product placement. Supergirl is introduced and barely developed before she struggles with the clich\xc3\xa9 of amnesia and disappears for most of the season. Why not settle on 2 or 3 scenarios and develop them correctly? And do not blame the writer\'s strike, which cuts this season by 2 episodes - the problems were obvious before the strike happened. Speaking of outside influences, several characters leave the series this year. The sudden departure of Kristen Kreuk to film Street Fighter leaves his already weak character a rather anemic farewell - fortunately, she will return briefly in season 8 to equalize. Another character I will not spoil will die of a noble death and we will miss him. This is the departure of Rosenbaum who is the real kicker. Not only does Smallville\'s best actor not return, but he has an ambiguous and unsatisfactory end. Barely seven years of amazing work. There are things that Smallville did well this year - the return of Brainiac and the screenplay of "Veritas" bring a sense of continuity that is sorely lacking in the series. But overall, there is a lack of coherence that seasons 5 and 6 have tried to have, and the show has no heart now that Kent\'s parents are gone. Whether you need this season or not depends on whether you have bought the first six and you absolutely want the complete collection.'

b'"The Necklace Affair" may be based on a true story, but it is also an exciting historical novel, "The Necklace of the Queen," by Alexandre Dumas, who certainly had more than the "Three Musketeers" . \'\' in his sleeve. Dumas tells the identical story of Joseph Balsamo (aka Comte Cagliostro), Jeanne de la Motte Valois, Cardinal Rohan, but the great diamond scam, although the filmmakers give no credit to Dumas (I see that the book is available) on Amazon.com, and I highly recommend it!). The costume designer, Malena Canonero, deserves praise for the bands of silks, satins and lace jabots that beautifully recreate the opulence of the 18th century court of Louis XVI. The settings are also beautiful. I found a lot of the music shocking, however, as the composer insisted on giving it a modern beat at times, and also used a mishmash of Mozart\'s Requiem, among other things. I find such cuts and rearrangements of a bar here; a bar, both lazy and a little cheat. In the featurette, the director explained that he wanted to make the period "accessible" to the modern public. Such "accessibility" not only insults the intelligence of the modern audience but also weakens the film. Because the story is so strong, I nonetheless enjoyed the film. I was particularly impressed by the performances of Jonathan Pryce as suave cardinal, Adrien Brody as Jeanne\'s scruffy husband and Simon Baker, who is particularly endearing as his loving love. All are credible and move well in their silks. Although Hilary Swank is an excellent actress, I thought she misinterpreted this role. She looks a little uncomfortable in her costume and moves more like a woman of the 21st century than the 18th century. These reservations aside, I will keep this film and I will probably watch it.'
b'I was so happy to find this piece for about a dollar and a half at a garage sale. Now I can download the Riftrax and listen to the former professionals of MST3K.'

b'I do not usually use the space provided for product reviews to comment on the condition of a particular product, or to draw attention to a less reputable buyer. In this case, however, I will make an exception. The DVD I received today, sold via Amazon LLC, the one listed as "Passport to Pimlico" (Remastered Edition), is obviously a homemade work. The outer label is a color photocopy, that of the DVD itself is in black and white, for the sake of God. Flip the DVD and you can clearly see the group that the home recording is doing on a recordable DVD. The manufacturer, A2ZCDs, seems to be a professional equipment, with an important catalog, an attractive website, etc. But I do not know why this sale was not among the third-party suppliers. (At least, it comes from Amazon, it\'s easier to come back.) But more importantly, is home-based DVD making simply not good, illegal? Is not this a piracy? My assumption when I read the word "remastered" is that the print is made from an existing negative, or cleaned significantly; I certainly expect the studio, the filmmakers or at least the film historians to participate in the production of the record. Maybe the one who manages A2ZCDs has done some work of this kind on his home equipment, but that does not excuse the general public. years ago. Perhaps nobody owns the film and we all have the right to copy and sell it as well. If so, my apologies to A2ZCD. I think, however, that buyers should be aware that they are not receiving any merchandise that reflects in any way what most of us who collect films view as "remastered" or even professionally produced. I have a Panasonic DVD recorder and I make my own DVD movies that I recorded on TMC. In my wildest dreams, however, I would never be able to sell them. Maybe that makes me an idiot. If so, at least I am honest.'

Even saying that, I could never recommend anyone to see it. It only encourages the man to continue. Uwe Boll, undoubtedly in my mind, is the most talented director I have ever seen. b'"These are the continuous travels of the USS Enterprise" in Blu ray. Ok, we all know what Star Trek is about, so I will not go over the plot.
