b"This 1955 version is one of those smaller Akira Kurosawa films that are forgotten in favor of his greatest films like & quot; Rashomon & quot; and & quot; Seven Samurai & quot; but it's still worth seeing. The great Toshiro Mifune embodies an industrialist from Japan after the Second World War, who slowly gets mad at the idea that a nuclear war is being prepared and tries to convince his family (and his mistresses) to flee Japan with him. The obsessive portrait of Mifune is a matter of great tragedy, especially as he argues in vain with his family eager to leave and Takashi Shimura, the leader of samurai in & quot; Seven Samurai & quot; , is also effective as a counselor who is trying to help redress the situation. The film captures the Japanese fear of the atomic bomb, a subject that Kurosawa will also address in his masterpiece, & quot; Ikiru & quot; , very well and with the greedy family getting closer to a delusional patriarch, evokes King Lear & quot; , a tale that the director would come back several years later in & quot; Ran & quot; . It is a short film of one of the greatest directors of the world, but very good."

b'I was anxious to see this film version of H.G. Wells\' classic novel, the producers claiming that it would remain true to the location and the late Victorian era of Britain. low production values, poor currency effects, sub-par action and "endless walk scenes". Suffice to say that my passion for romance and courtesy had been right and I had to see this film for myself. Basically, I was aware of small defects and did not expect a lot of production. the honesty that I enjoyed the movie despite the flaws too numerous to list here and that have already been covered by critics much more eloquent than me. The montage of scenes and events would confuse a viewer quickly loses the plot as the film switches between the scenes of the narrator in Woking and his brother in London. at one point the brother is supposedly in a London street, then suddenly he attends the Elfinstone ladies\' attack on a country road and runs to their rescue. Much has been said about the meeting between HMS Thunderchild and the Martians while the brother escapes England with a "paddlesteamer". left aside. There is a highly publicized scene where the legs of a tripod are heading towards and above an artillery battery, which is probably the best effect in this film and shows what could have happened. There is a really terrible dialogue between the characters. I challenge anyone, for example, not to end up watching the exchange between the Elfinstone ladies and the brother as they "discuss" how they will escape from England. I also awarded the James Doohan Award for the worst Scottish accent we have seen since Brigadoon, when the narrator converses with a soldier at Horsell Common. On the other hand, when you watch the interaction with the actors trapped in the ruined house, as well as the meeting of the dead woman\'s narrator on a London street, you sadly remember what it might have been. filming 2 stars which is generous and for the following reasons.The music is fantastic.It is refreshing that the film is faithful to the events of the book and made the effort, albeit poorly, to place the book in Victorian England and no other version updated in the United States. Unfortunately, due to cost constraints, the British-style buildings are digitized and define the Monty Python style in a Washington state field to represent Woking, Shepperton or London. I liked the design of my 17 year old daughter who watched this movie was not at all impressed, but she was intrigued by the configuration and location of the film. As a result, she made the effort to read the novel and, to my surprise, read it from start to finish. The irony is that H.G Wells has conquered another young admirer despite the very poor quality of this film and I really appreciate it. Should I however recommend this film to a friend? Unfortunately not if I wanted them to stay friends.'

b"Anyone who reads these reviews will have seen the TV production and will know it thoroughly. I will therefore limit my criticism to the quality of the DVD image - or rather to its absence. Too bad that what was once a beautiful and memorable TV movie has become a dilapidated shadow of his former identity. It is painful to see if something that has a special place in your heart is treated so badly. For years, the only version that millions of people had seen on TV had such a pale color and low contrast that it almost seemed to have been shot in black and white! If that's what you're used to, the & quot; restored & quot; the version on this DVD (and the one shown on TV the last 3 or 4 years) seems slightly better, but it is barely restored. Just watch a deleted song in the extras section to see how beautiful and bright the original production was: clean, crisp, immaculate, with very saturated colors. The time and money had to be spent to bring the rest of the film to the norm. It is morally wrong to put a defective product on the market and then have the nerve to charge it. As many of our parents probably told us when we were young, & quot; Everything worth doing is worth it! & quot;"

b'COME EARLY MORNING Have you ever seen a movie and thought about it later, but not as a documentary, but simply as a piece of cinema that seems to have been removed from real life? If you\'ve ever felt this, there\'s a good chance you\'re watching this one here. "Come Early Morning" is a wonderful little film made wonderfully by Joey Lauren Adams of "Chasing Amy" and featuring the great Ashley Judd and, of course, Jeffrey Donovan. The film follows Lucy Fowler {Judd} on her journey through her thirties, waking each morning beside a useless man after another. She is also dealing with a father with whom she desperately tries to spend time, even if it seems to be indifferent to her. So the story tells that she is a desperate and confused woman who only seeks love and acceptance. Of course, you could say that his problems with men stem from his relationship with his father. Yet she eventually meets at least one decent man named Cal Percell {excellently portrayed by Donovan} who seems to want a relationship with her despite her problem. It is this relationship that drives the film, although the time spent with his father and his roommate adds an interesting dynamic. The great thing about all this is how it all ends. Writer / director Adams proves that all this time spent with Kevin Smith has paid off because it\'s a wonderful first film. His direction is excellent but it is his writing that makes this film so good. As I said, this has to be one of the most real movies I\'ve seen in a long time. I like the fact that she did not romanticize the main character and her problems, things do not end as you wish. This film has an end that is probably what would actually happen, how bad is it? Even those who have not grown up in a small town can relate to what is happening in this movie. Ashley Judd, of course, is great as the lost thirty-year-old tries to find her way. And you know that Jeffery Donovan is excellent as a guy who should have been the one for her. Laura Prepon of `` That 70\'s Show \'\', the celebrity is as good as the roommate and Judd\'s best friend, she even finds love. In addition, Scott Wilson is awesome in finding a religious father who seems as helpless as she is. In fact, the entire cast is awesome and deserves all the credit of the world. Apart from that, the film was also very well shot and for such a limited budget, it seems that the film showed the whole city, even if it was not the case. a moment and a wonderful start for a filmmaker. To those who look like this, I say spread the word and see it again now. And for those who have not seen it yet, I recommend this as a purchase but I guess you can try a rental. It\'s a wonderful movie with a big cast with real problems that everyone should be able to understand. I would love to go see this movie, but everyone can see it, if it\'s not your thing, but for those who like this kind of movies, you\'ll love this movie.'

b'The Banks family needs a new nanny for Jane and Michael. Fortunately, we get on the wind in the form of Mary Poppins. She is everything kids want, fun and magical. But while she takes them to chalk painting and tea parties on the ceiling, their father is less happy. Can we see it at the end of the nose? Ok, so this movie is really just an excuse for song and dance numbers. It\'s always great! The plot is thin, and you lose the place in the middle of some fantastic scenes. Of course, part of this is due to the fact that the film is based on a book that is nothing but short stories. Yet this film is more about pleasure than anything else. And that has it in spades. What child would not have liked to imagine that they could do all that Jane and Michael do in this movie? It is said that Walt Disney has poured everything he had learned to make this film, and it shows. Many of the special effects are remarkably resilient today. There were some that I still did not understand before watching this special edition. And the music! Any Disney fan knows these songs by heart. And you can not help but find yourself singing "A spoonful of sugar", "Jolly Holiday", "Fly a kite" or "Chim Chim Cher-ee" for a few days after seeing it. Those who want to own a large DVD of this movie will not be disappointed by this set of two discs. Disc 1 presents the film in all its splendor of screen. I can not see how it looks better. The soundtrack has many different options, but home theater mixing will amaze you. It\'s fantastic . There is also a commentary track featuring Julie Andrews, Dick van Dyke, Karen Dubice (Jane) and Richard Sherman. Watered are comments from other archives, including Disney itself. You will also find contextual information to read while watching the movie. Disc Two presents a new documentary about the film, a deleted song and more about music with Julie, Dick and the composers. And be sure to watch the animation "The cat who watched a king," a tale adapted from one of the last books in the series. make it and how much they respect Walt Disney. The fact that this film lasted 40 years shows his genius. With this set, it will be appreciated by future generations.'

b"I would not go as far as the previous reviewer saying it's a kind of liberal conspiracy film (and if so, I'd hate to hear what people are saying about movies like Ferngully and Once Upon In Forest). That being said, however, I can not give this film a better rating. The CG animation is of a quality far inferior to that of the cover (more in line with a Saturday morning cartoon than a feature film). I do not think I found a single joke in the whole movie, and more than a few scenes were so rude that I preferred to watch them instead of watching them. The images are often dark and disturbing (the woman trying to decapitate a cat with a chainsaw comes to mind), and the peaceful outdoor scenes look very fake. The animation has several parts that are notoriously mediocre compared to a good movie CG (or even decent). In addition, humans are deformed almost beyond recognition. In short, there are many good CG titles, but it's certainly not one of them."

b"Gregory Peck beautifully plays the role of squadron commander of a precision bombing squadron during the Second World War. Play & quot; General Savage & quot; Peck 's role is that of a new commander with strict military discipline beliefs to make the most of his men and to make them understand what was missing with their former commander. The script itself is entertaining with uninterrupted philosophies and suspense. I would recommend this film very strongly as a training video for people in professions where leadership is the key to success. Keep a close eye on the fact that General Savage incorporates strict discipline with temperance in his interactions with his men. With respect, he also won the trust of the troops. This form of leadership is almost non-existent today. However, it's literally, & quot; proven fight & quot; ."

b'This film begins with a simple question from Richard Lobb of the National Chicken Council: "In a sense, we do not produce chickens, we produce food. This allows to produce a lot of food in a small space at a very affordable price. Let someone explain to me what\'s wrong with that. "Well, this movie explains very well what\'s wrong. The first point is that it is not good to treat animals as if they were mere objects *. You will see chickens and oxen on their knees in their own droppings. You will also see hens in their cages, unable to even bear their own weight. Animals are kept all the time in the dark, including for us. It was very difficult for filmmakers to get pictures of the interior of these hen houses. The second point, related to the previous one, is that our food can easily be contaminated by E-coli, because of the excrement of animals. wear on their skin. This is how food poisoning can happen in the slaughterhouse. Barbara Kowalcyk, the mother of a 2.5-year-old child, has had the most horrific experience anyone can experience: the death of her child. .. The reason: eating a hamburger "We trust our government to be protected, but we are not protected at the most basic level," she says. This is not an embarrassing truth - although this film was produced by the same company that brought us the documentary with the same title. It\'s a nasty truth. Can we do something about it? Absolutely. "You can change the world with every bite". Go to organic matter. Better yet, connect again with the source of your food, what you eat, what you put in your mouth! The best thing to do would be to get involved with a local farmer you know and trust.'

b'The publication by Criterion of Spellbound of Alfred Hitchcock presents a slight defect. 74 minutes after the beginning of the film, we have a view of J.B. (Gregory Peck) holding a razor blade, while hearing the line of Brulov (Michael Checkov) on the big screen \'Are you Mr Brown? "Then we cut to Brulov for his next line," Oh, I thought it was you. \'Simple, no? Well, the Criterion DVD cuts the razor\'s blade too early, then picks up Brulov\'s images, cutting his second line, while crushing his own! st! Then we get the 2nd line correctly. In other words, the images of Brulov\'s line "Oh I thought it was you" are gathered twice! ! So far, I do not know if the Criterion disk is the only affected version. If the problem does not bother you, then Criterion\'s version of Spellbound is the version to collect (excellent extras and image quality). And if you can still find it somewhere (since it\'s now Out of Print) do not hesitate to buy it, it\'s still a very good record and these extras really make this DVD a true collector\'s item. Just do not throw this old VHS tape!'

b'I love the Murder She Write series and I was really looking forward to the release of the show on DVD. I have both season 1 and season 2. I love watching the episodes themselves, but I am very disappointed with the quality of the DVDs themselves. The problem is to use both sides of the DVD to store the episodes. If two-sided DVDs were researched before presenting this beautiful show on the less expensive double-sided format, we would not have had as many DVD games to jump. I really hope that they have chosen the road of better quality and not the cheapest route.'

b"Marcel Carne's Children of Paradise succeeds at so many levels that it rightly deserves to be called one of the greatest movies of all time. Carne filmed the film piecemeal during the Nazi occupation of Paris. His film was officially supported despite the occupation, while the Nazis wanted to show that they were friendly to the arts. This created the ironic situation that Carne was taking money from the government to support one film a day and channeling aid to the French resistance at night. An actor was supposed to be a Nazi collaborator. He mysteriously disappeared during the shooting and had to be replaced. Despite all these obstacles, Carne has managed to recreate beautifully the Paris of the nineteenth century. In this way, the film itself is a triumph of the creative spirit. The title refers to the poor, who could not afford seats so high in the theater that they were almost in full thrust. And yet, it was the real audience. the actors played for. The story is a series of lives that intersect one way or another around the bohemian, Garance (played in the fashion of Mona Lisa by Arletty). Beyond, the film also revolves around the Parisian theatrical life of 1840: the actors, the public and all the intermediaries. Garance is almost a courtesan: she moves comfortably between four men who love her, seemingly indifferent to any of them ... finally, she falls in love with the mime Baptiste (Jean-Louis Barrault) .... but Baptiste is married to another woman after missing his chance with Garance years ago. Will they meet? In the end, we, the viewers, are as much the children of the gods as the children of paradise, which the title calls the theater audiences in the film. Indeed, the opening and closing credits are played against a theater curtain. We are the spectators in the gods and the actors occur for us living their lives: to love, to live, to die ... to feel both pain and joy. Carne's film lasts more than three hours, but never lags behind. The stories intersect and can not be adequately described in a simple magazine like this one ... Four men like Garance and, in a way, their whole life intersect around the theater. Cinematography is incredible. There is a crowd scene at the end of the film that resists everything that has been filmed: it's just beautiful. Baptiste is lost (in many ways) in a moving mass of humanity. This scene alone is reason enough to see the movie. I suspect it's a movie that people like or hate. The long length can discourage many people, but it's a shame. The film is not for those who want instant gratification. Instead, it's something to enjoy and enjoy. If all this seems too serious, rest assured that this is not the case. Children of Paradise is a tragedy in some ways, but it's also a Shakespearean comedy. It was a movie made for a company like Criterion, and they do it in their DVD edition. The two halves of the film are presented on individual disks, so that the film never suffers from compression defects or other problems. The restoration is impeccable: we will never know that this film is almost sixty years old. The audio is mono but very clean, without hissing or static. Criterion also included supplements, previews, filmographies, trailers, etc., but the real pleasure is the movie itself. It's timeless."

b'I want to start by saying that this is the best Blu Ray version I have purchased to date. The packaging is beautiful with its rigid "souvenir" aesthetic, and the extra bonuses alone are worth the meager asking price. Seeing real images of Linda Blair (in full makeup) on the set is invaluable and certainly surpasses all the extras of previous versions. On the important things .... THE FILM. I must say that this has become my favorite movie of all time. I am not a horror lover. I have some favorites of the genre ... but I opt more for the comic and / or the fantastic. I like to be lifted laughing, or be completely removed from reality.You ask, "Why, in EARTH, do you consider The Exorcist as your favorite movie? ? "Simple, it\'s a modern parable, and it\'s one of those rare films that really produces the desired effect on every image." The Exorcist "as a horror film is a bit myopic. This is a spiritual drama, a psychological thriller and a supernatural story ... all together in 37 years later, they are still the same and as relevant today as ever. that we live now in a society that is, as Blatty says in the documentary "Fear of God," "completely jaded and depraved." Nothing here seems shocking and the 14-year-olds now see this film as "laughable." is a pity, because there is much more than pea soup and spinning heads here, it\'s really about the terror of the unknown ... the fear and trepidation involved in all metaphysical things and This is the mystery of faith and its ability to triumph in the end. pictures, sounds and history ... everything concurs here. It\'s incredibly well written by Blatty. Friedkin\'s sense of documentary realism serves the plot well. The acting is excellent with a casting that could not have been more perfect. Dick Smith\'s make-up is revolutionary, not only with Linda Blair, but also with Max Von Sydow who was in her 40s or 40s at the time. Owen Roizman \'s use of varied light textures and, of course, his masterful and emblematic photograph of Merrin\' s arrival, is also remarkable. I had the chance to see Fathom\'s show on September 30th and to see this movie on a big screen with digital sound was fantastic, I have to say that it plays better and provides more disconcerting sensations when looking at home. .. in the dark. That\'s the really scary angle in this movie ... it reminds us that no matter how safe we \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bthink we are (even at home with all the lights on), there\'s nothing but the real evil do and nowhere else. will not show up.'

b"Let me start by saying that I like & quot; Oh My Goddess & quot; and I was really expecting the release of the DVD of the series. It's very kind, funny and easily one of the most charming and romantic series I've seen. I am very happy to be spending time with Belldandy, Keichi, Skuld and Urd. That being said, I am shocked and disappointed that they split the series into two DVDs, each sold separately. The episodes are very short, totaling just over an hour per DVD (I think it's 82 minutes for flight 1 and 62 minutes for flight 2). There are no additional features included. Yikes! It's a lot for two and a half hours of viewing. I have a hard time believing that Animego can not do more justice to this great series or offer more value to its customers. The six parts & quot; Moldiver & quot; OAV has managed to find its way on a DVD at a good price. How disappointing Oh My Goddess & quot; could not do the same thing. I am sad to say that it is an excellent series to rent (but not to buy)."

b'Ripe is not a sexual exploitative Lolita movie, as the supersaturated key art suggests. Instead, it is a difficult and off-the-wall exploration of female sexuality and age, imaginatively directed and well-acted through its three tracks. The script sometimes becomes rough and brutal with many independent films, but the film is visually stunning, and the accumulation of little moments is delicious - when Violet discovers adult magazines, for example, or when the hangman who takes the sisters has to explain the rules. And the final scene with the two sisters is devastating, a strange amalgam of suspense, family drama and psychosexual tones. .'

b"The Iron Giant is a free adaptation of a magnificent book of the same title, by Ted Hughes (written in the late sixties). In the book, the giant's origins are unknown, and he is initially buried under the ground before being attacked and finally befriended. The enemy of the book, who becomes the common enemy of humans and the giant and the cause of their alliance, was a giant creature resembling a dragon (as big as Australia !!) that the giant eventually thwart. , staged during the Cold War and presenting a magnificent portrait of the atmosphere of the 50s, the enemy is the US - and our tendency to fear what is foreign, to shoot first and ask questions later . I think it's finally deeper. Of course, the original author might have had such an allegory in mind when he wrote the original book, since the dragon of outer space eventually destroys and wraps a large part of the planet in the darkness. , almost like a world war. But in this case, is their alliance with the giant supposed to mean an alliance with military technology to prevent a world war? In the film, the robot is just a simple robot of space, which human beings can choose to make a friend or establish themselves as an enemy. In any case, it is without a doubt one of the best animated films of the United States. States in the last decade (and one of the others is by the same director, Brad Bird)."

b"I do not remember the last time I was entertained by a movie that I watched it three times in 24 hours. STILL CRAZY took me out of my average, somewhat starchy existence, and took me back to my college years in the 70s, when I was in a part-time group. Do not be fooled: this film depicts the chaotic, extravagant, egocentric, authoritarian and irresistibly dysfunctional behavior of rock musicians. The antics of the characters - even in the middle ages, as they try to revive their career - have brought back a plethora of memories. I too remember concerts that went wrong; members of the group shouting chords together during a song; the frequent & quot; artistic & quot; disagreements of impromptu jam sessions in the barns, garages, empty rooms of the school; and the thrill of connecting with an audience (usually a drunken audience). Buy this movie ... rent this movie ... see this movie. It's more than a comedy; There is a very real human component that transcends even the tumultuous world of the music industry. You will laugh, you will erase an occasional tear, and you will be completely amused. The flame is still burning. God bless the rock 'n roll!"

b'I was surprised that the editorial critics of this film treat it as another film, which is certainly NOT the case. I would describe it in different ways: as the film John Waters gave him the left hand to do; as a great sending of intense and heartbreaking dramatic dance films like Red Shoes, which stands out from the concept of "camp" without giving up the experience to stay consistent with the attitude; like a comedy that, if you get the joke, you will sometimes knock out laughing. There are times when I did not know which movie I was in, as the plot was about Flashdance and then Cinderella. But that\'s the kind of movie it is; he embraces operatic emotion and high melodrama, and although he recognizes the ordinary, he never becomes so. And it communicates magnificently the essential madness of all integrated and inclusive subcultures. (The incessant exhortations of the old guard to the hero not to engage in "crowd motions" are both absurd and quite typical of these subcultures, where the most sensible question is always that of knowing a strange and intense film, a film that keeps you constantly on the sidelines, and asks if you should take it seriously or as a kind of filmed comedy dream (think Rocky Horror Picture Show). cool is that you never have to decide, you can enjoy new aspects in multiple views.'

b"Ridley Scott's alien must be considered one of the best thrillers ever put on celluloid. He ranks there with such films as Hitchcock's Psycho and Tod Browning's Dracula (1931). Alien is pretty much a haunted house classic, but instead of an old Victorian-era mansion, we have a giant, dark old cargo ship and the endless darkness of space itself. - This film is really a film B in the soul - with a very tense and intelligent scenario, and an exceptional direction of Ridley Scott. From the long opening sequence of Nostromo filling the screen, the public knows that it will be treated to an exceptionally shot film. Ridley Scott has always been known for his artistic direction and the biomechanical aspect of the Alien sets contributes to the feeling of horror and horror. This helps that Scott and his crew decide to engage the famous surrealist Swiss HR. Giger to design the look of sets and creatures. Anyone who has seen Giger's work can easily see his influence in Alien's scenography. Giger's final design for the main creature will be one of the best creations in film history. To this day, everyone knows what to imagine in their heads when someone mentions the words Alien and film together. The group of actors chosen for the film is excellent from top to bottom. Captain Tom Skerritt Dallas is a solid base on which the other characters are turning. The slow descent of Veronica Cartwright's character into hysteria - quite appropriate to the situation she and the rest of her teammates face - is like a barometer of the growing fear that runs through the entire movie from start to finish . The position of the cast must be Sigourney Weaver. The fact that this is her first major role in the cinema bodes well for what the public could expect from her during her career. His character of Lieutenant Ellen Ripley is about the antithesis of Lambert in Cartwright. Where Lambert slowly descended into paralyzing hysteria, Ripley slowly took control of the situation and became the de facto leader after Dallas. The general tone of the film owes a lot to the past. But instead of constant fears and red herrings, Scott slowly accumulated tension and dreaded long, slow shots of empty corridors and holds. For a movie that is considered one of the best horror movies ever made, Alien does not have many dark areas where the monster suddenly pops up. The monster will skip well-lit and spacious areas. Scott also used Spielberg's trick, which was to prevent the creature-monster from being on screen for a brief moment. It is only toward the very end of the end that we see Giger's Alien creature in all its splendor. This new edition of Alien dvd was finally accompanied by re-released scenes that add even more shock and horror to the film. I agree with Scott 's reasoning to delete the scenes. It slows the roller coaster, faster pace in the last part of the film. But in the comfort of his own home theater, these re-edited scenes are easier to integrate. The look of both the original film and the director's cut has been remastered and looks great, especially on a progressive scan compatible DVD player and a dedicated widescreen HDTV. Sound and music have also received a remastered 4-star treatment to better utilize the growing home theater systems. Alien is the most performing entry of the Alien Quadrilogy, though Aliens is a more exciting film. Alien takes the scifi horror genre and sets a standard that many still have to reach to this day."

b'The most recent burglary by a professional thief and his team goes terribly wrong and the organizer of the flawless plans gets more than he negotiated. He is hijacking a NATO military policeman (Tamzin Outhwaite who wears his British accent) after the chaos (and saves his life too) and embarks on an urban car chase in a familiar setting. History does not make much sense (why steal money from casinos in Romania?), But the first part of "7 Seconds" is fun with decent car stunts and a little humor. The actions are confusing, and you do not know where these running cars are going, but at least the stunts themselves are not bad. In the middle section of the film, boredom sets in, which stops the actions and begins to introduce superfluous characters, plus a twist of unnecessary plot. We do not need to see Wesley Snipes enter the station and put a briefcase on it. Or in fact, we do not care about the contents of the briefcase; and we do not even want to know if anything (whatever it is) is real or not. We want thrills and action, or fun dialogues. With the exception of a few martial arts stunts and slightly amusing jokes between Snipes and Outhwaite, "7 Seconds" does not have much to show, especially in its second part, where the film presents another sequence of stunts involving trams, but it\'s often tainted with criticism or criticism about live movies, but some are pretty good, offering 90-minute entertainment like Jean-Claude Van Damme and Dolph Lundgren\'s movies. b'The Crucible, based on the game of Arthur Miller, is an entertaining, if not always accurate, version of the events of 1692 at Salem Village. Having read many books on the subject, I still can not say for sure what led to so many men and women being accused of witchcraft and that it seems that so many girls are afflicted. One may wonder why it is only the females of Salem, and not the males, who seem to suffer from cries, catatonic states, hallucinations, & c. In any case, a conclusion that I could not the case Abigail Williams played by Winona Ryder whose advances are denied by the groom John Proctor (Daniel Day Lewis). The Proctors are also much younger in the movie than they were in real life. John was sixty when he was hanged. Elizabeth would have been in the mid-forties at the time of the trials. Pregnancy saved her from the hangman\'s rope. The film retains a good deal of precision in her treatment of the slave Tituba and her share in the case, as well as accusations against some "troubled cities" such as as a good nurse and Giles Corey who was pressed to death for refusing to testify. The scenes in the courtroom were the most dynamic and exciting, and recalled the period paintings of old books depicting trials with harsh and puritanical judges who showed accusing fingers. The film also did a good job of capturing this stifling and repressive scene of the 17th century and the costumes were of the highest quality. The best performances for me came from those who interpreted the different ministers and judges, especially Bruce Davison Danforth. Although it is not a perfectly accurate film, it still manages to capture one of the most significant events in American history. Reviewed by Tim Janson'

b'This film begins quickly and quickly plunges the viewer into a very strange world, with dialogue and actions that make it difficult to follow. Fortunately, the pieces begin to fit together and do it with dramatic use of surround speakers and lots of onscreen action. The basic premise of the film is that technology has been developed to allow a crime to be seen before it happens, so that the police can intervene and stop the crime before it happens. Just as this crime prevention system is poised to spread nationwide, something is happening that changes everything. The character of Tom Cruise, a policeman by the name of John Anderton, is suddenly immersed in a situation that threatens his very life. His search for the truth provides the basis for this thrilling action film.'

b'Some people in Germany have accused the film of trying to "render harmless" the crimes of the Third Reich. It could not be further from the truth, and I will explain why. Bruno Ganz plays Hitler the man. Hitler the man who loves his dog, who is kind to his secretary, who loves his friends and who spits at people he thinks betrayed, who tells those he cares to save himself, as he prepares take cyanide, shoot yourself and then be burned. He\'s a guy who, as long as he does not talk about Jews or world domination, would not be so difficult to live with. ALWAYS, it\'s still Hitler\'s monster. Being a vegetarian does not exempt him from being directly responsible for the death of millions of people or throwing the entire world into the war. Hitler, the two-dimensional monster, is inseparable from Hitler the three-dimensional man, and this is what this film reminds us of every time it hurts you, even if you know it and the film reminds you he was a monster. All the monsters of history - past, present and future - were and are human beings. We like to imagine Hitler as some kind of inhuman monster, but he was only human. Too human. That\'s why this movie makes people uncomfortable; it reminds them that the leader of men who seems to be a friendly man can turn out to be a monster if the right questions are never asked or ideas are never challenged. The warning is uncomfortable: you can not trust any ideologue on the face value. Not one, never. And / this / is the real import of this film, if "Never Again" has to have some sort of real meaning next to a slogan. If I were a history teacher, I would show this film followed by / Schindler\'s List /. Both are equally true, and equally important aspects of the story: all this horror comes from mere humans.'

b"Among the many interpretations of this piece that I saw on stage and on the screen, it's the best - a strong affirmation given the many excellent actors attracted by the powerful characters of Tennessee Williams (eg, Katherine Hepburn and Sam Waterston). John Malkovich seems to be born to play Tom, the artist torn between family duties and adventure. Malkovich's intense and punchy style is an ideal match for Williams' play, in which text and poetry dominate. His performance in this role is the most convincing of all I've seen, and avoids the trap of allowing Tom to become too gloomy and self-absorbed. Joanne Woodward is also perfect as Amanda, who, although deceived, narrow and even silly, reunites her family with her unique blend of courage and desperation. Karen Allen and James Naughton also capture what I think Williams had to imagine in the characters Laura Wingfield and the gentlemen, and both generate real chemistry in the pivot scene with the glass unicorn. It is a must for anyone interested in American theater."

There was no pleasure in this movie at all. The story made no sense, the actors were very stiff and none of the characters seemed to care about the other characters. At one point in the movie, Christian Slater says, "I just killed my long-time friend," in the same way that you would say "I just spilled my coffee on a pair of stained pants, that I was about to to throw away" . I guess that could sum up the whole movie. The actors did not seem to care, the director did not seem to care, the publishers did not seem to care, in fact the only actor who really seemed to do a decent job was the animators who animated the film. After watching this movie, I felt very sad for Christian Slater. His career must be completely over now. I\'m depressed . It\'s time to look at Madagascar and cheer me up.'

Features the wonderful Michael Caine in mind. The late Peter Collinson brings to life what could have been, despite his intrigues, a routine film. Collinson is in a way a cult director who died relatively young before he could fully fulfill his promise as a director. I would also recommend his classic cult psychological thriller, Straight On Till Morning, which became available on DVD last year. Although embarrassed by the editing conventions and visual conventions of the mid 70's, Morning does more than bend to the explotive movies of the time. Completing the film is a commentary track featuring the film's original producer as well as a number of great extras. It 's great to have this minor classic finally restored to its good aspect ratio. The DVD transfer is pretty good and although the quality of the print varies a bit, it's really good overall."

b"This is not the Superman version of Christopher Reeve that we know and love, but it is rather close. What pleased me the most about this version of Superman is Lois Lane's deeper relationship with Superman and how real she is. For me, the STORY should be as important as the cool graphics, and Singer nails it here. Lois Lane is Superman's love for his life, as well as Lois's ... both are inseparable. Although left and Lois passes to another man, love is still there. So, of course, there's the battle going on between Lex Luthor and Superman, so it's like having two good stories in a movie! There is an emotional chemistry in this movie that is undeniable. You can actually feel what Superman goes through throughout the movie, both good and bad. I must have seen this film 5 times since its release ... I give director / screenwriter Bryan Singer a big boost for an engaging, moving and well written story."

b'Director Jon Reiss and producer Tracy Wares take us on a world tour of graffiti in "Bomb It". The film supports graffiti more than against him, but he interviews people whose mission is to rid neighborhoods of graffiti as well as graffiti artists on 4 continents. There is an undercurrent of these issues that should decide what we are looking at in public spaces, a provocative but not really the center of the film. "Bomb It" covers many things in the history and scope of graffiti art, but wisely, because we can see that graffiti artists are not all alike. Graffiti has evolved over time and its purpose is different in different cultures and subcultures. "Bomb It" begins by interviewing Cornbread, a Philadelphian whose campaign to label everything with his nickname in 1967 could make him the first modern graffiti artist. The film avoids the "who did what" debate but follows the progression from the simple to the more elaborate lettering that led the graffiti transformation from a lower-class anti-cultural movement to a broader artistic movement. Graffiti writers in New York, in the 1970s and 1980s, talk about their exploits before the city begins to aggressively clean graffiti on public property. Other cities whose artists are featured are: Paris, France; Amsterdam, Netherlands; London, United Kingdom; Berlin, Germany; Barcelona, \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bSpain; Cape Town, South Africa; S\xc3\xa3o Paulo, Brazil; Tokyo, Japan; and in Los Angeles, United States. I have always thought of graffiti as a means of frustration, of energy, but above all of the irresponsibility of young people who attack what they perceive as the status quo. Now I have learned that graffiti has a different meaning in different cultures. In South Africa, graffiti was a tool for political change. In Los Angeles, he was part of the Chicano movement and took the trap of a lifestyle in some neighborhoods. In some cultures, the focus is more on the creation of works of art in public spaces than on counterculture. Unsurprisingly, these artists have a less adversarial relationship with communities and the law. The fact is that graffiti and vandalism have a profound effect on the rate of more serious crimes. And many of the interviewed artists portray themselves as extremely selfish people who give themselves hope to others because their lives are not what they would like. On the other hand, it can not be denied that graffiti is sometimes an improvement over dismal and decaying buildings, or that artists are talented, or that some opponents of graffiti are politically undeclared. "Bomb It" is an introduction to graffiti and its controversies showing us art, ideas and differences of opinion. The DVD (Docurama 2008): There are 3 featurettes and a comment on the features. In "Behind the Scenes" (14 min), director Jon Reiss talks about the genesis of the project, filming in different nations, editing the film and some themes. Extended sequential sequences (15 min) are 3 sequences, 5 minutes each in England, Brazil and Japan, where we can watch creations created in an accelerated time. There are also "extended interviews" (26 min). The audio commentary by director Jon Reiss and producer Tracy Wares is constant and informative. They talk about what they did and did not include in the film, their intentions and more details about who and what we see.'

b"Well, if you have not seen this, you are going to do something big. This is one of the funniest films ever made - certainly the best of the abbot and the costello, and it is not nothing. But there are also Bela Lugosi and Lon Chaney Jr., both in the roles that made them famous and have both played them quite directly, making it a classic. Often imitated, never duplicated."

b'As for the plot, here\'s what the back of the box says: "Edward Carnby (Christian Slater) is a private researcher specializing in inexplicable supernatural phenomena. His business plunges into the dark corners of the world, searching for the truth in the hidden vestiges of ancient civilizations. Now, the greatest mystery of his past is about to become the most dangerous case he has ever faced. With the help of his ex-girlfriend, archeologist Aline Cedrac (Tara Reid), and his fierce rival, government agent Richard Burke (Stephen Dorff), Edward is about to learn that it\'s It\'s not because t means it can not kill you! "According to the character of Carnby, the fear of the dark is what keeps us alive. Unfortunately, the fear of crappy movies does not prevent us from praising them. Despite the horrible reviews, I decided to give in to the temptation to rent Alone In The Dark (I had a free rental, so I thought there could be no loss). It was even worse than I expected ... First, creatures that are liberated from the depths of darkness - or any other clich\xc3\xa9 object in history - are pathetic CGI dino-beasts. Something interesting, scary or just "cool" about them? Nope . Just useless computer-generated monsters that fail to entertain the public in any way. For two, the acting is horrible. Seeing Tara Reid on the main credits of the DVD made me roll my eyes, but seeing her try to play the role of archaeologist in a sci-fi action movie just made me laugh. Christian Slater is the only decent mid-actor, but that is not enough to cover the rest. And for three, the film is terribly boring, with few action scenes. Oh, of course, some unknown bumps here and there, creatures flashing across the screen, and a little gore is included. But the real action? Very little . The small amounts of action he has included are the reason why I gave two stars to this worst. I hate to see a movie suffer, but this one deserves it. In conclusion, do not make the same mistakes as most of these critics by praising the movie, knowing how terrible it must be. Just trust the ratings on this one. This will save you money and time.'

b"I can not really tell a joke. A bad joke is not funny, no matter who says it, but someone like me can make a bad joke. You have to tell a story as well and, in the case of a well-filmed film, be interesting. The problem with AntiTrust is that it's not a very well-written tale. It's nice to watch, but has no electricity or soul. Milo [Ryan Phillippe] is a computer genius. Upon leaving college, he plans to start a business with friends in a garage, just as their computer heroes did twenty years ago. They plan to make their mark in cyberspace. One day, apparently unannounced, Gary Winston [Tim Robbins] asked Milo and his best friend to come to work for his giant multinational company. It seems that Winston is about to launch a computer program that will revolutionize communications, but it needs some good geeks to make it operational. The friend, a wise young man, decides to stick to his original plan, but Milo gets sucked. With his girlfriend Alice [Claire Forlani], he packs his bags and moves to Portland, Oregon, where Winve de Nurve is located. It does not take long for Milo to suspect that Winston will literally kill to get what he wants. Breakthroughs in programming the new product always seem to happen just after the mysterious death of a brilliant programmer. One of the problems of the film is related to the casting. Tim Robbins is just like Winston, making him look and act like Bill Gates, it's a bit scary. Ryan Phillippe, however, I can not buy any kind of genius. He has done a good job in the past, playing roles of sociopath [Cruel Intentions], psychopath [The Way of the Gun] and party party [54]. But a computer scientist? I do not think so. Rachael Lee Cook is just as incredible as Lisa, another programmer. Claire Forlani, who could be a star someday soon, is fine like Alice, but it's a role that falls short of her abilities. AntiTrust belongs to the paranoid thriller genre. It is the one in which only the hero has understood a diabolical plot. Until the end of the film, the other characters are almost always blind to the truth and tend to believe that the hero is simply stressed. The rear window of Alfred Hitchcock is a classic example of this type of film. To succeed, the film must bring the public to care about the protagonist. This must relate to it This does not happen in AntiTrust. Milo is too bland and lame to interest us. It's one of those cases where, if we're dealing with someone, it's the bad guy, Winston. At least he is quick-witted and somewhat humorous. You know that a movie is in trouble when we start looking for the bad guy."

b'This is a very well done and beautifully shot suite. The opening sequence and sequences with snipers indiscriminately shooting at the fleeing crowd were very memorable and well executed. However, I was completely confused by the simplicity with which the father could access his wife who was supposed to be in quarantine. I know there are often loopholes in the logic and suspensions of disbelief in many movies and I am guilty of succumbing to some of them. But for me, it was very obvious. To shout loudly, the US military was completely incompetent or the filmmakers did not think it would be so blatant for the public. Who in their good spirit does not put the mother in quarantine with at least a guard at the door and even less a nurse or a technician who monitors her? ? ? ? ? ? Instead, the installation was deserted. It was too simple for the father to access with a pass card or not. If a person was still alive 28 weeks later without any symptoms in a quarantine zone in the real world, that person would be locked up and the video would be monitored 24 hours a day for days or weeks to find out how survived and how she was "immune" against this virus. Such precautions would never be taken lightly, especially when you\'re dealing with a virus that has virtually wiped out a whole country! If they did not have strict protocols, we would have been eliminated like a race a long time ago. The suspension of disbelief in this film really prevented me from enjoying a rather good movie.'

b'I think it\'s a horrible video. The first 57 minutes teach you things like: -What is vibrato? How to make hammers, tear off, trills-A (G) major arpeggio is the root, then the 3rd, then the 5th, now I repeat \'or something like that, it just plays an arpeggio. Big whoop. diminished chords (he plays them with very little explanation, except that one has a 5th dish and the other has a 5th fold - at that time he says that if you want to know more you should buy a book!), here\'s the thing ... these are all EXTREMELY BASIC. These are things that anyone who plays the guitar for over a year or two must know for the most part. Maybe not inside and out, but it does not teach it inside & amp; Out.For most of the above, he gives only one example with very little explanation at all. None of this specifically concerns gypsy jazz. Oh, but for the last 2 or 3 minutes, he plays a gypsy jazz tune. He could have taken exactly the same video and played at the end a Yngwie Malmsteen song and call the video "neoclassical soloing" and it would have been like "valid" as calling it a gypsy jazz video! , I imagine that someone who wants to enter Gypsy Jazz already knows how to make hammers and stops.If they do not, they must continue to practice for many years before hoping to tackle jazz Gypsy Man Who is this video? Paul Mehling does he know? There is no theory in this video at all ... NOTHING He does not tell you when to play the scale and the trills, etc. it shows you, or how they relate to chords, or whatever, there is no review of the rhythm placement of solo notes (that would be the SWING part of the gypsy swing guitar). There\'s no review of what Django\'s scales preferred to what chords, nothing at all. & quot; There is no dissection or tearing of the Djangos style, as another critic has suggested. Nothing of the kind . Nor is it an introduction to jazz improvisation in my opinion. The sad thing is that this video could be so much more. Paul is obviously an excellent player and knows the style. He does not teach it well though. There are many excellent guitarists who do not make good teachers. Paul seems to be one of them. Someone should tell him! I am now going to eBay to sell my video to someone else. I highly recommend to anyone trying to enter this style the hotclub website for basic course information, and Stan Ayeroff \'s book & quot; The music of Django Reinhardt 44 classic solos of the legendary guitarist with a complete analysis MelBay pub, ISBN: 0-7866-3388-3'

b'I had already used Jillian\'s "30 Day Shred" DVD and wanted to change my routine. A friend told me about "No More Trouble Zones" and I decided to give it a try. NMTZ is definitely harder than Shred 30 days! I like the variety of movements and this workout requires more repetitions with lighter weights. It is also good that you can choose to read the entire workout or select different segments from the menu. Each segment lasts about 5 to 7 minutes and focuses on certain areas, such as the abdominal, chest or trunk. The biggest disadvantage for me is that I use this DVD 2 to 3 times a week for about a month, and I have not seen any noticeable difference in my "problem areas". I\'m already in very good shape - I\'m also running 3 to 4 times a week and I\'m paying attention to what I\'m eating - but I was hoping that this workout would help me strengthen myself a bit more. I will stay there, though! I also warn you that if you prefer a training without impact and low impact, this DVD is not for you. When Jillian says, "You should feel like you\'re going to die," she thinks ...'

b'This film was not the subject of rave reviews when it was released in cinemas and, although it did respectable business on the circuit of the art house, it never made a big commercial noise. has strong distribution and strong supporting actors who have always been a hallmark of British cinema.But his popularity is not only due to these factors, but rather to his generosity of spirit.It is not deep.It is not sophisticated.It is the world\'s cinema of daily struggles and serene triumphs in the face of adversity is the comforting food. I repeat throughout the cinema, not just in gay cinema. The scene is not explicit but tender and affectionate, charged with trial and error (like so many first encounters) and overwhelming. We see then the contrasting impact of the meeting on the two boys - Granny growing up in trust and Ste struggling to reconcile her sexuality with her status as "one of the guys" and scared that her father and brother are discovering him. The main motive of the film is "coming soon" and visually the film is subtly subtle.The producer Tony Garnett was a major television producer and there is a slight impression of television on the images, especially the scenes of the dark area but the scenes will be enlivened by a rainbow and brighten the area with window baskets, etc. It is never a pure delirium of social realism and the sense of unreality is sometimes quite deliberate. The main actors are not guys in the Hollywood sense. k idents in looks and aspirations, making it an easy-to-understand movie for gay teens. Also note the suggestions that Sandra has a gay side - the closest relationship is not with her boyfriend Tony but her work partner Louise. sexual predator and presents itself as quite butchish and with a hint of sexual ambiguity. Her challenge to the prejudices in dance that appears in the last scene is obvious and more than just a lioness defending her cubs against prejudice. Empson, a teenage girl in trouble Leah, whose fixation Mama Cass is the excuse of a glorious soundtrack music. It\'s a celebration of the exit. It is an open and charming heart. and love to assert.And that counts for a lot in my book.Consult it because it says that two groups often make fun of moviegoers and blue-collar workers .It\'s a pleasure'

b'The "Prisoner of Zenda" of 1922 is certainly one of the best silent films ever made. His main actors knew better than moving too much and there was obviously a very competent director in Rex Ingram. Even if the plot, the costumes and the sets are straight out of an operetta, the players are mostly natural, which shows that the advent of sound is not the result of a good action. Even Ramon Navarro, Hentzau\'s wicked Rupert, is much more than a beautiful face as he turns his role into an animated tour de force. The photo begins in the mansion of English Rudolph Rassendyll. on the extremely beautiful eyes of Lewis Stone, a 43-year-old veteran who looks, in many other ways, to a rather ordinary middle-aged man in good physical condition. But of course, Stone\'s histrionic talent is nothing ordinary and, in addition, he has all the charm that made him love as Judge Hardy about 15 years later in the series "Andy Hardy". Rassendyll decides to attend the coronation of his cousin Rudolph of Ruritania [of which he could be the twin] and finds his relative as a disorder dispelled. Lewis Stone plays both roles, needless to say. The weak king has an ambitious but evil brother, Duke Michael, who plots to seize the throne and kill Rudolph. On the eve of the coronation, the duke arranges for his brother to be drugged so that he is not able to attend the ceremony. As a result, the King\'s loyalists persuaded Briton Rassendyll to take his place for a day and prevent Michael from following his path. Rudolph has a beautiful fianc\xc3\xa9e played by the bright Alice Terry. The couple is not very useful to each other, but it is a popular princess that could serve to reinforce the unstable position of Rudolph. However, Rassendyll and the charming girl are taking each other at once and, feeling an unexpected change in her, the princess no longer sees her role of future queen as a mere duty. Of course, the plot thickens and there is another woman involved, played by the seductive but less natural actress Barbara La Marr. Rudolph Rassendyll can not return to England after the coronation but must stay to help save his endangered royal cousin. There are also a lot of skull games and sword games. All this gives rise to a fascinating film and it is a revelation to see how much a younger and more juicy version of the old Judge Hardy is effective in the scenes of love. Pretty sexy! It is probably no coincidence that the actor who played the dual role in the next "Prisoner of Zenda", Ronald Colman, looked a lot like Lewis Stone.'

b'When I saw the trailer for & quot; From Hell & quot; I was naturally ecstatic. Based on the graphic novel of the same name, written by Alan Moore, I had high hopes for this one. Judging by the previews, it seemed like the Hughes brothers would do justice. But alas, as the cinematographic adaptations of books often go, they slaughtered them. Let\'s start with the character of Johnny Depp, Inspector Abberline. They go from an honest and hardworking detective who slowly develops feelings for a young prostitute to a clairvoyant addicted to opium who falls head over heels in love with the aforementioned prostitute (Heather Graham). And speaking of Heather Graham, could they have made a more horrible choice for a 19th century prostitute? The other prostitutes in the movie look as they should (ugly), but Graham remains like a sore thumb. As for history, this butchery is typical of Hollywood movies. The book focuses on the character of Jack the Ripper more than anyone in the story. In fact, it was revealed in Chapter 2! That made it so fascinating: the book went into the killer \'s head and tried to explain the motives behind his horrific murders, in addition to the obvious evidence presented in the film. He deconstructed and analyzed a really twisted mind and tried to convey how, according to Alan Moore, "The human experience went to the end ... then passed." The film turns into a typical polar, leaving you guessing until it is revealed at the very end.Anyway, I have been talking for a long time.See the movie if you want - for pure entertainment you will probably enjoy it. if you want a richly textured and fascinating, albeit fictitious, story about one of the most notorious serial killers of all time, read the book.'

b'While 1952\'s "Singin \'in the Rain" is unquestionably the most successful musical film, I think this classic from 1949 is a perfect illustration of what MGM produced during Hollywood\'s Golden Age, when the talents were at their peak. Co-directed by 25-year-old Gene Kelly and Stanley Donen in his first feature film, the film has endless energy thanks to the remarkable choreography of Kelly and Donen, the seamless blend of Leonard Bernstein\'s music with Les compositions original works by Roger Edens, composer of studio music, and the exuberance of the performers. Written by the esteemed team of Betty Comden and Adolph Green, the decreed plot is limited to three sailors - Gabey, Chip and Ozzie - in 24 hours. New York City and the women they meet and romance. Based on a subway poster, Gabey falls in love with Miss Turnstiles and spends her time looking for her. Ozzie, who suffers from phobia, finds a love affair with Claire, a student in anthropology, while the shy Chip focuses on the visits despite the persistent attentions of the aggressive taxi driver Hildy. The closest story to dramatic tension is in the deceptions around Miss Turnstiles, who is not the big celebrity Gabey presumes to be an aspiring ballerina named Ivy, who has to work at night as an exotic dancer at Coney Island. . is obviously at its best when it is centered on the musical sequences - starting with the actual places used for "New York, New York" by establishing the energetic arrival of the sailors, continuing with the elaborate number "Prehistoric Man" at the Museum of Natural History and hopping through the set of titles with the top six singing and dancing at the top of the Empire State Building. Everyone has a chance to shine, although, like Gabey, Gene Kelly clearly dominates with his gracious athleticism. As Chip, Frank Sinatra eclipsed, sings especially in front of Betty Garrett, which admirably contains her Hildy brew. Although it is hardly credible as an academic type, Ann Miller manages to impressively exploit "the prehistoric man" and the face of Jules. Munshin mostly provides comedies like Ozzie. When she dances rather than deceiving Gabey, Vera-Ellen dazzles Ivy, from the fantastic "Miss Turnstiles Ballet" to her superb duets with Kelly on "Main Street" and "A Day in New York Ballet". . The only negative note is the condescending attitude towards Lucy, the roommate with the sinister voice of Hildy (played with enthusiasm by the original Gladys Kravitz of "Bewitched", Alice Pearce). The color-saturated cinematography of Harold Rosson was very well maintained in the print transfer on the 2000 DVD, although the only extra is the now dilapidated theater trailer.'

b'"Elvis: it\'s like that" captures King Presley at an interesting crossroads of his career. With his real talents largely wasted after many years in Hollywood, Elvis found himself stolen from "The King of Rock and Roll" by The Beatles and The Rolling Stones. This documentary, shot in the summer of 1970 while preparing for an engagement at the International Hotel in Las Vegas, finds Elvis ready and able to demand his throne! The documentary shows him at the age of 35, in shape and size, and has a lot of fun! See Elvis having fun - it\'s a joy in itself! Elvis had a keen sense of music and his craft. He was expecting a lot of people he was working with; and he knew exactly how to make the most of everyone. It is obvious here that Elvis enjoyed working with his band and his backup singers; and they enjoyed working with him. Elvis criticized in a sweet and funny way. When his group struggles with the central part of Bridge Over Troubled Water, Elvis comments, "If that\'s the way it is, it\'s okay, but we do not need to point it out. `` The concert sequence itself proves that Elvis could very well have been the most hardworking show-business man. It also proves that Elvis had "that" - that indefinable and often indescribable X factor (or in his case, factors) that makes the difference between an artist and a superstar. Elvis was a superstar with a major "S" - with a powerful combination of charisma, sex appeal, musical sense and showmanship. Elvis\'s charisma, in particular, burns the scene quite enough. Elvis does everything to please his audience. During a long rendition of "Love Me Tender", he goes out into the audience, embracing as many women as possible and shaking hands with as many men as possible. He sings a Greatest Hits Medley largely for laughs (change the lyrics to "forget the past, before I give you a # #"). In the middle of the concert, Elvis is just beginning, delivering powerful interpretations of "In The Ghetto", "You\'ve lost that feeling of love" and "Polk Salad Annie." "" Its expanse, made super-charged and super-moist \'\' Suspicious Minds \'\' will probably leave viewers as exhausted as Elvis at the end. At the end of the credits, we see Elvis greet other celebrities after the performance. Sammy Davis, Jr., clearly amazed, remarks, `` Man, you woke up and you never stopped! When he is congratulated on a wonderful show, Elvis modestly responds, "Well, it was a sweaty show. The DVD Special Edition includes two versions, but keep the latest edition restored and ignore the original version of 1970. The theatrical version of 1970 contains testimonials of useless fans. The restored version contains other Elvis images in action. "Elvis: it\'s like that" is the way Elvis must always remember!'

b'If you have never seen a movie to come, this is the one you need. One of the most critically acclaimed gay movies is a sensitive, thoughtful, tender and sweet story with a superb score of Mama Cass. The film, directed by Hettie McDonald and based on the script of gay writer Jonathan Harvey, portrays the relationships of people in a large real estate complex located east of London (I was physically there). Especially for the British of the low-income working class, the film revolves around three families, all broken homes. Ste, coming from a father and a family brother Jaime, a mother and a boyfriend family; and Leah, a British black girl with her mother. The story is the development of a love affair between two boys, Ste (played by Scott Neal) and Jaime (played by Glenn Berry). They live next to each other. They are both 16 years old (also in real life to maintain accuracy). It is also the story of Leah, sometimes drug addict, struggling, dropout. She is a catalyst with her obsession with the music of Mama Cass, she constantly sings her songs and makes a lot of noise around the apartments. I read messages in this chat room about her, without understanding why she is the movie. His character contributes to the greatness of the film.Ste was beaten several times by his father and brother. He takes refuge with Jaime. Jaime\'s mother, Sandra (superbly performed by Linda Henry). She loves Jaime very much and left her husband because of physical violence. She is a tough, intelligent, caring and loving woman who runs the local bar / club in this apartment complex. She feels sorry for Ste and takes her away. Ste must sleep in Jaime\'s bed or in a couch. Then Jaime kisses Ste.There is a trip to a local gay bar, no more kisses in the woods. Sandra discovers that her son has lied to him about his love for Ste. She is informed by the school principal that Jaime is being teased and is called "fag". And the film arrives in its last moments. Mama Cass\' s music is played late at night when it is high and almost fallen from the balcony of the building, and Ste discovers that Sandra knows them. Better manage a pub in another part of East London, she says goodbye to her boyfriend and gets ready to spend the night with the girls. Ste, Jaime and Leah are getting ready to return to the gay bar. The last scenes of the film Ste and Jaime dance (on a music of Mama Cass) in an open space of the buildings while the tenants gather to watch something, some in a tumult. Sandra goes out on the balcony next to Leah, looking down on what\'s going on underneath. One of the best scenes I\'ve ever seen in a movie is the extension of Leah\'s hand to Sandra (the symbolism is so powerful). By the way, Sandra and Leah fight like cats and dogs throughout the movie, they improve in the last moments. They both joined Ste and Jaime in the dance, and Sandra finally accepts her son\'s sexuality. It\'s a very powerful film and the title is very appropriate. Glenn and Scott both said in interviews that they received thousands of letters after the movie to ask if they were gay. Glenn disappeared from the screen and Scott did minor things. The language is difficult to understand sometimes. There are websites with slang dictionary used by the working class in Britain. Someone put a scenario for a sequel on the Internet, it\'s pretty good. This is a `` GREAT \'\' movie'

b"It is a film that speaks more of redemption than pure race problems. Kowalski lives in a part of Detroit, where he is retired and a veteran of the Korean War. He is a gruff old man who despises everything and apparently everyone. His community is totally Hmong, with the sole exception of him. We see him with his family and interact with his neighbors and then, as you have seen in caravans, his relationships with local youth. He begins a relationship with Thao and Sue, young Hmong neighbors for whom he builds an affinity. Totally politically incorrect, Kowalski spits racial and ethnic insults in almost every sentence. He's a bit ready, especially since he's become a widower, but he loves his car and his house and wants his world not so much changed. Kowalski calls everyone, and he does not care about the type of riding he gets out of people. It mainly shocks Whites, Blacks, Hispanics, Asians. But you see youth gangs from different ethical perspectives and their own racism. Tho and Sue are like the ones you hear about in the news, kids who have problems meet them, just because they live in those areas. Kowalski gets to know the Hmong and him. He defends his house, his property and his friends. Realism, although surreal, has an impact on our senses when you see the results of the fights. Sometimes this leads to more of the same thing. Kowalski, however, is a figure of redemption, it impacts all who know him, but the greatest impact is on the spectator of Gran Torino. The extras on the DVD are good, more about the car than about the company. Wish there is more about downtown issues and gangs to complete our love affair with big muscle cars."

b'"Lost Highway" is not as linear, and therefore satisfies our narrative desire, as "Mulholland Drive" because it seems indeed too difficult to be strange. But David Lynch is one of the only directors to understand the strangeness of dreamlike cinema. Like Hitchcock, he fully exploits this situation, but in the manner of classical surrealists, and I think this film can be better experienced in a real theater. The terrain of this film is even more deeply unconscious than "Mulholland Drive", because its ultimate subject seems to be the act of watching a narrative film itself, such as a truth channel of our society: pictures of scenes of crime. That\'s what makes it interesting. It is so open that it allows each viewer to interpret his or her own interpretation, because the "surface plot" mixes with its own interpretive clues. In my opinion, Fred Madison believes he was convicted of murdering his wife on the basis of the images contained in the last videotape with Ren\xc3\xa9e (Patricia Arquette); in the first act, the most important line is his statement that he does not like cameras, because he prefers to remember things in his own way - not necessarily as they did. "This whole first part of the film is the way Fred remembers his life before being incarcerated, and takes place in a second - after being hit in the face by the police officer who made the arrest. To believe in the mysterious tapes that preceded the murder is his way of trying to convince himself that he did not do it - that the Mystery Man (Robert Blake as wifekiller - ironic, huh?) Did it. The second part, less effective because of its lighter tone, is Madison\'s way of escaping the reality of the electric chair. The light above his cell flickers and probably buzzes because someone is being executed, triggering his fantasy of flight by physically becoming another person. Yet even in this young man\'s life, Renee returns (double ...?) And is free to start a life with her without the memory of her marriage, but learns the sordid truth about her life ... Mystery Man shows up again, this time helping to commit a conscious murder of his former pimp - and allowing him to be filmed to convince himself that this murder (which Fred was able to commit before the movie started) was right. But who the hell knows ... The plot? I have mapped this film after seeing it for the first time, and there are too many doubles that we can not trust as spectators, be it physical reality or mental projection. Each of the interpretations is opposed to the other - like the Moebius tape that Lynch claims the film embodies. It\'s more like a puzzle structured around themes, mostly a subtext involving photography - a picture of twins, porn movies, scary video tapes that appear on their steps like evil calling cards. Make sure to receive a version of this movie in letterbox format. Lynch\'s visual compositions are based on horizontal angles all along, and there are many extreme close-ups in which the tops of the heads are truncated (for some malicious intent, I\'m sure). Cinematography is great, and the soundtrack (not the music, but the atmosphere Lynch is always meticulous) is as important as the images, just like in Eraserhead. "And after watching a particular scene from this movie, you\'ll be very careful about sharp-edged glass tables for the rest of your life ..."'

Deny (10/10) Reminds me of my ex-boyfriend denying he was really gay. This is one of my favorites. `` You are not fooling anyone but yourself. \'\' If true.09. Viva Forever (10/10) Superb! Beautiful words and melody. Say goodbye to true love ... I can relate to this deeper than many other songs here. This song gives me chills, it\'s a haunting song. One of their best. "Ladies and gentlemen, we hope you enjoyed the show! `` Overall, this album is as good as the original with as much spice as the previous one. Geri, Emma, \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bMel C, Mel B and Victoria all have equal voices on this one and they all have incredible sound. b'OKAY ; Let\'s be clear about something. This is a work of fiction. He is well designed, smooth and attractive in his message. But it\'s fiction. However, let\'s be clear about other things as well. First of all, many of the points presented here are true. Which ? Well, I will avoid spoilers but suffice it to say that people often ask me if I am an atheist. No, I say, I do not deny the possibility of a superior being. But I deny the church. This story clearly shows how organized religion systematically destroyed the best messages, but corrupted them with greed, thirst for power, and cruelty. Groups of men made human choices and wrote human words to describe a system that would keep them in power, and this story looks at that. It looks at the little-known facts surrounding the so-called "Holy Bible" ... the idea that what we know as the Bible differs greatly from what it once was. Etc. I do not seek to destroy faith, nor does this story. We hope this will encourage the viewer / reader to think about THEIRSELF. It\'s a fun story, well interpreted and well photographed, drawn from a well-written and enjoyable modern fiction work. I hope that if nothing else is thinking, and maybe people will start to see formal religious institutions such as Christianity for what they are ...'

b'I have never written a review before, but after trying this video, I felt compelled to warn others about the misleading nature of the title of this video. I have a lot of neck and shoulder pain and this video just makes things worse. Anyone with severe muscle tension needs yoga with a lot of stretching for these narrow areas - this video is NOT it! The video begins with pumps and several charging positions that require a lot of the neck and shoulders (like the board and the dog down). This is a fast-paced video - it\'s more like a powerful yoga flow, definitely not something that will "save your neck and shoulders"! ! ! ! ! It alternates very quickly porting positions and there is almost no stretch in this video! She does not explain poses at all and moves too fast. This video is for advanced power yogies and certainly not for beginners or anyone with any type of pain. I am not a beginner, but I have a lot of neck / shoulder pain and this video is completely inappropriate. There are other reasons also why this video is annoying (but they are much less important): sounds like a kind of voodoo music), background sets are nauseating and it is very false. is excellent! This video allows you to choose from different sequences depending on the type of pain you have and you can choose whether you want an active stream or a more passive stream.'

"Do not invent it Held by the Psychlos, he manages to learn to read, fly planes, use firearms - all in a remarkably short time.
