b'Every year, when Christmas arrives, I like to have friends to sip a cup of sip (a powerful Nog Egg recipe available on request), put some good Christmas music, light candles, prepare delicious sausages and pick in my humble but sufficient cinema and watching a wonderful holiday favorite. This year, I\'m going to watch Die Hard and for me, Christmas would not be complete without that. John McTiernan (Predator and The Hunt for Red October), a classic action movie that spawned three explosive sequels, never seems to age, no matter how much hair, clothing and portraits of cocaine addicts California fashion can boast. Die Hard follows John McClane (Bruce Willis) at his wife\'s (Bonnie Bedelia) Christmas party in a West Coast skyscraper. He is a New York policeman whose wife and children have moved to the west as he takes a great opportunity and fits. Obviously, they have marriage problems, but they are minimized. The building is empty except for the group that organizes the Christmas party on one of the upper floors. "Terrorists" led by Hans Gruber (Alan Rickman) take over the building and chaos ensues. Gruber\'s plan would have worked well if John did not leave and slowly began to release each of his servants, while warning the local authorities. The film makes its appearance and the film explodes into a classic of action ... and also a Christmas classic. He may be as likeable and convincing as John McClane and Bruce Willis surpass all other heroes of the action by making John not only intelligent and funny, but easy to understand with very little drama. It\'s an effortless performance that I can not compare to Harrison Ford as Indiana Jones. Intrepid little remarks coupled with a cynical look on his face make John go from good guy to what every boy dreams to become in these circumstances. It \'s fantastic and it\' s kitsch, but it \'s forgivable because it\' s a holiday movie and, more importantly, action is always the priority in Die Hard. On the other hand, Die Hard \'s grandeur is completed by his formidable and accessible antagonist, Hans Gruber. Even after discovering that Hans is not here as a political terrorist, but simply as a thief, he loses absolutely no credibility when he responds to Holly McClane\'s criticism by saying, "I am an exceptional thief, Mrs. McClane and as I\'m moving for the kidnapping, you should be more polite. "Although we know that Hans is capable of committing ignoble acts, he sees them in reality as mere means of achieving a more or less justifiable end. His disposition is almost humanitarian and you imagine him as a gentleman outside the context of the crimes he commits in the bow of Die Hard. In the end, Hans is a pure sociopath that even the public is brought to sympathize with. I would have liked him to go if his opposition was Van Damme, Segal, or Stallone ... maybe even Arnold. The support cast is another huge force and helps to highlight the humorous innuendo of the film. The cops and feds are all fun and rich characters, especially Reggie VelJohnson, Sergeant LAPD Al Powell. The bad guys are purely chaotic thugs with just enough variety to do a little more than John\'s body count. The performance of William Atherton as a journalist is also noteworthy, as is John\'s limo driver Argyle. Even editions for television versions deserve to be appreciated where the expletive is replaced by wonderfully light little curses such as: * melon farmer * and * bad mother cruncher *. Of course, these make it both fun and accessible to all and Die Hard is one of the best examples of hilariously edited TV movies. But this is of course not what makes it an excellent movie. I would say that Die Hard is the greatest pure action movie ever made. Yippie-ki-yay * muddy funster * ... and happy holidays.'

b'Put my two cents: The girl who went through the time was on my watch list for a while, but I never took the time to check until yesterday. The quality of the animation remains high everywhere. The characters are beautifully drawn by hand and the backgrounds carefully rendered (mainly hand-drawn). The use of computer animation is minimized and occurs primarily when we see a "jump". The characters are strong and friendly. Makoto is your typical clumsy teenager. A chance meeting followed by a (almost) horrible accident allows him to cross the time. Rather than using this ability for what is called "evil" (I would skip and invest heavily in some titles ...), Makoto uses the ability to make his life and that of his friends better. However, it begins to cause unforeseen and disastrous circumstances. And that\'s about the moment the film goes from light and rather comical to completely dramatic and sad. I will not divulge any event or spoil any plot for you, but let\'s say that I was moved at the end of the movie (but not really with tears in my eyes!). 2/3 of the main characters are expressed by a first vocal actor. This will show you how in Japan they take the voice seriously and do well (rather than the majority of American dubbing companies that have a core of 5 or 6 full-time actors that they MUST match a main character of each series) or movie - often not the best match for the character). So the story is strong with a little sci-fi, the characters are nice and well portrayed, the voice play is beautiful, the animation is beautiful ... why did not you see him yet? If you\'re not a fan of anime, this could be a good movie to help you change your mind.'

b"The classic tale of demonic possession, based on William Peter Blatty's bestselling novel. Linda Blair is Regan MacNeil, a twelve-year-old girl with a truly malevolent spirit. His mother, Chris MacNeil (Ellen Burstyn), agnostic, seeks the help of a young Jesuit psychiatrist, Father Damien Karras (Jason Miller, may God leave his Irish soul!) Who has his own demons and who is tormented by the recent death of his mother and his loss in the faith in which he sought refuge. After confronting the demon within the girl (and himself), Karras, though skeptical of demonic possession, is allowed by the church to help during the exorcism. The priest chosen to perform the ritual is a mysterious and old Jesuit Father Lankaster Merrin (Max Von Sydow) who has already seen such a diabolical work. While the two clergymen face the devil, a police detective, Lieutenant William F. Kinderman (Lee J. Cobb), finds links between death and desecration in the local Catholic church. William Friedkin brilliantly directed Blatty adapted the script (receiving an Oscar for his efforts) and produced. The distribution gives extraordinary and delicate performances (Burstyn, Miller and Blair have all been nominated for the Oscars) and the special effects are breathtaking and continue to fury, with veteran actress Mercedes McCambridge providing the voice of the entity Maleficent. (The film also won the award for Best Achievement in Sound). The theme behind much of Blatty 's work is obvious, his philosophy being, if there' s all that evil there, why is there so much good? Metaphorically, everyone fights his own demons, and even in his last moment of selflessness, Karras regains his faith and gives his life heroically to save this innocent child. How can this be more meaningful? A truly terrifying, captivating and ultimately touching film about faith and human fragility."

b"This story caught my attention immediately and held it for the entire movie. The film is based on the life of John Nash. He was a brilliant mathematician who became famous as a young man for his work in economics. The film spans decades and begins when John Nash arrives at Princeton University. Russell Crowe does an excellent job as Nash. The game required the transformation of Nash, a healthy young man, into an aging schizophrenic. Alicia, Nash's wife is played by Jennifer Connelly. She is very convincing as a smart and strong woman who realizes that her bright husband is very disturbed and lives in another world. A special and charming scene comes to mind where Nash and his future wife look at the stars. He tells her to think of different shapes or different animals and is able to look at the night sky, with its millions of stars, and connect them in some form. I wish there were more scenes of this kind and perhaps a little glimpse of Nash's family and childhood. John Nash was finally awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for mathematics, which is a consolation, but the illusions were something I will not forget. I came out of this film with a lot of compassion for John Nash. Schizophrenia is really a horrible mental illness. This film deserves to be seen and I believe it will stand the test of time."

b"& quot; Return of the living dead & quot; is a hilarious horror / comedy inspired by George A. Romero's classic & quot; Living Dead & quot; movies. I saw this film when I was just a little child and I liked it. It's pretty much like Camp 80 that horror movies get. The premise of the film is a beautiful tribute to Romero. Apparently, the movie & quot; Night of the living dead & quot; was based on a true story, and it was concealed by the US government. The bodies of the zombies were sealed in oil drums and scattered. Two workers in a medical supply warehouse find one of these drums, accidentally punch it and release a gas that brings the dead back to life. Coincidentally, the warehouse is right next to a cemetery. The rest is written, and the film presents some of the funniest moments in the horror film's history: a corpse raging in the warehouse, a zombie head hit in the park with a baseball bat, a zombie who commands more paramedical & quot; like he's ordering pizza. And most importantly, an 80s hard rock soundtrack. This is one of my favorite party movies because it makes everyone scream (even non-horror fans). It's sometimes bloody, but the comedy hides the elements of horror. The DVD in question is a little light on the extras, except for a fun documentary, but lukewarm. But the big advantage is the best picture and sound quality I have ever seen this movie. The DVD really makes the difference. Get a copy and see what I mean, you will not regret it."

b"As this movie is out of print, it took me a few weeks to find a copy. However, once I did, I felt like I found the Holy Grail horror movie. The story revolves around a scandalous affair led by a bored housewife (Julia Cotton) and her brother-in-law (Frank Cotton). Julia and her husband move into Frank's old house after Frank's sudden death. Of course, Frank did not really disappear. Instead, the evil brother-in-law found a cube-shaped puzzle. Once opened, the puzzle opens a portal on the world of the Cenobites. Cenobites offer the ultimate pleasure, but at a high cost. Able to escape the world of the Cenobites once a drop of his brother's blood has spread to the floor of the house, Frank returns like a corpse, needing parts of the body of living beings to complement each other. new. Frank uses his past relationship with Julia to convince her to bring him new victims. With each victim, Frank becomes more complete, but also more impatient. There are several scenes of prefiguration, praying mantis and nasty spider with Julia as she goes to the bars and picks up random men for the massacre. Of course, finally, her actions bring out the suspicions of her adult stepdaughter and her husband ... The film presents the introduction of the Cenobites, who are among the most frightening cats since the Xenomorphs of Alien. As the film progresses, we learn more about these beings, their origin and their purpose. Of course, the end leaves everything in suspense, which leads to several sequels. I highly recommend this film to those who like to watch the first horror movies made by those who are now considered masters of the genre."

b'For the big fans of Manhunter, I advise you not to use this DVD if you plan to own ... What was billed as "& quot;" Theater & quot; the version is actually a poorly edited version that clumsily edits two scenes that were in the theatrical release, including one of the most essential scenes, and yet contains some of the most mundane images restored from the floor of the hall cutting. These cuts are poorly made and do not make any sense to them, considering how they do not represent the release in theaters and destroy the momentum of what had been a finely edited film. I do not know if it was ignorance or arrogance, but it\'s the worst hacking job I\'ve ever seen trying to pretend to be a product. Whoever was responsible for that in Anchor Bay was an idiot and if I were Michael Mann, I would call my lawyers. The & quot; Director\'s Cup & quot; is even worse in that it includes the & quot; Non-theatrical & quot; release AND the so-called & quot; Director\'s Cup & quot; - a compilation of some interesting and uninteresting catches. In addition to a real theatrical release, it would have been a fascinating addition. But here again, Anchor Bay finds a way to ruin what should be a good product. The entire movie that has not been submitted to video post-production is stained and blurred, as if it had been transferred from a VHS cassette - and worn out. - just amazing that anyone can have the audacity to offer this kind of low price for hard earned money. I saw this movie when it first appeared in the theater and considered it one of the best of this year; and I rushed to buy the LaserDisc version when it came out. When Anchor Bay released the director\'s DVD this year, I was on the waiting list, ready to welcome the big-screen THX version. Being intimately aware of the film, imagine my disappointment. Do not waste your time. Wait for a better version to go out. As for those who want to compare Silence of the Lambs to Manhunter, they generally prefer each other and their ideas are pretty well established at this point. I\'m right in Manhunter\'s camp. For me, I enjoyed Silence, but I could never take it seriously, because I found Lector\'s portayal both superhuman and surreal and therefore unrealistic. However, Lector by Manhunter is a terrifying but more realistic portrait that intrigues me every time I see it in the way that an evil genius manages to manipulate events outside his cell by simply using a phone. This Lector is safe behind the steralized bars - and yet still manages to be a powerful presence with which to count. and edgey, and yet that flowed gracefully. Siskel and Ebert ranked it among the best films, years after its release. But for now, I\'m going to keep my LaserDisc.'

b'All 3 movies are nice, sitting on the edge of your seat, but most people already know the stories. The first of 3 films, The Bourne Identity presents both excellent video and very discreet channel tracking in audio. The sound mixers have done a great job using all the surround channels and do not allow the soundtrack to mask the different foley effects in the front or rear channels. Of course, in all this excitement, your subwoofer will have a good workout. The video transfer is pretty good without video noise, aliasing or artifacts. This movie started all the franchise and it was a great start. My only question was how Bourne was shot in the back in the first place. This question has never really been answered because amnesia is usually caused by severe head trauma and not by two bullets in the back. The second film in the trilogy, Bourne Supremacy, was much more appealing to me, I remember a friend, and a professional photographer, mentioning that it made him seasick. Blu ray video was excellent in all respects, but I also noticed a much less significant use of directional audio. Rather than putting money into more discreet sound montages, the producers reinforced the soundtrack that enveloped almost the entire sound stage, front and back. It\'s not that the soundtrack does not match the movie, it certainly does, and creates an exciting atmosphere for the Bourne movie, but more attention to the 5.1 soundscape for the crazy effects would have been nice. , the Bourne Ultimatum, completes the package with the same strength in video transfer. I did not notice any weakness in the video transfers for the 3 films, but again, in the Bourne Ultimatum, you would think that with all the excitement, the use of the front and back faces would be more important. I was disappointed that, just like the Bourne Supremacy, they simply increased the audio levels of the soundtrack, which would obscure any foley effect. I\'m not saying that there is no use of discreets in the last two movies, but not as much as what could have been or how it was used in the first Bourne Identity. To save $, they only increase the level of the soundtrack and it\'s a shame. During the fight scene, things are thrown, broken glass and all sorts of troubles that could easily have been directed to the left or right, front or back. So, on this score, I was disappointed.However, it is an excellent collection to have and the enthusiasm and pace of the 3 films are just excellent. There are a lot of deleted scenes and other short films as well as comments without loss of space for previews and announcements for other movies. It\'s really worth it. Fortunately, this review has been helpful and, if so, please check the "Useful" button, so I know I\'m on the right track with my comments for you. Thank you .'

b'From time to time there is a film that has hardly ever been advertised or even a decent release for the general public, alas the purgatory of limited series and art films. However, in the case of Equilibrium, I am more surprised to see why this version has never been released more widely. Seeing the movie, honestly, I had no other expectation than to see artillery games and martial arts as the star of the film. While this factor has been entertaining, the real star belongs to the finely crafted storyline that pays homage to novels such as "Brave New World," "1984," and "Fahrenheit 451." History places the viewer in the post-apocalyptic world of the future. Having suffered the after-effects of the Third World War, the survivors were forbidden to form a new society that would rid them of the greatest faults of humanities, emotions. Controlled by a drug, which cancels such senses, the future is a utopia without war, but enslaved to those who hold the power and establishment created. Art, music, literature, all this is forbidden and the penalty for committing such crimes is death. The most feared protector of the establishment is the Cleric. A group of men trained in the mind and body to be the perfect killing machines and children posters of their ideals. One of these clerics, who even executed his own partner for reading a book of poems, begins to see the world in a new light when he misses his usual dose and feels a flood of emotions that he had never felt before. While trying to maintain his duty, he finds the cruel sadism of his appointed task almost more than he can bear it. In a desperate search, he tries to find resistance and put an end to the madness he has preserved. Christian Bale, playing the Cleric, gives incredible depth and emotion to a role that did not require any. In this, he makes the film even deeper. The cinematic style and editing, borrowed from filmmakers such as John Woo and Tsui Hark, bring enough freshness while adapting these styles. The art direction is creating a claustrophobic world of sinister lies. Although the scenery of the city is not so impressive and are obviously effects of CG. The music is sometimes dark and mingled with the pressing conflict that follows, and then it\'s a fast-paced techno score that sets the pace for the shooting without fail. In all, Equilibrium is a science fiction fan dream come true, but it\'s also a movie that can also be enjoyed by fans of classical literature. Although the end may seem too simplified, I found it actually deeper and more interesting about humanity in general. But most will be delighted at the end of the ten-minute shootout, with an impressive duel at the sword. The balance contains strong language and violence and is recommended for ages 17 and over. For once, style and substance clash with celluloid.'

b"It is about one of the films most loved by the affections of the foreign cinematographic scene. Tati has provided a brilliant link between the best of what the era of silent film and modern film had to offer. This is a relatively simple story about a clumsy man on vacation on the French coast. But repeated screenings, especially over the years, open more and more treasures that were not yet recognized, like a classic novel. I would be surprised if someone comes to this movie the first time he looks at it. I certainly do not have. But the repetition of visits over the years will give you an appreciation of this film that borders on the cult. Every member of my extended family loves this movie, and everyone has their own reason. Some like it for its ability to perfectly capture a foreign time and place, making it feel as if they had escaped to the French coast for the afternoon. Some like Hulot's clumsy but endearing romance attempts. Many like funky funky gags, no matter how many times you've seen them. But no matter what a viewer likes most, everyone will feel a connection to the character of Hulot (and, in turn, Mr. Tati) who will last a lifetime. With this DVD, I can finally feel safe to lend my beloved granular VHS copy. A classic film by every sense of the word."

b"When I was ten, my mother's uncle gave me his copy of Cornelius Ryan's A Bridge Too Far. It was a very special gift from him, since he was deported to Germany to work for the Reich during the Second World War and never recovered mentally from what had happened to him. At the time I got the book, he was living in a small village, a few miles west of Arnhem, on the south bank of the Rijn River. Over the years, my interest in World War II and Operation Market Garden began to grow, and every time A Bridge Too Far was broadcast, I watched it. The scenes depicting the drops of paratroopers and the assault on the Waal River were the ones we remembered most. That, and the great score of John Addison. I finally bought the DVD and have watched it a few times since. I must say that every time I watch it, the film improves. Especially with the subtitles: first those that specify where we are. Without these, one might wonder where the viewer has been brought from one scene to another. Secondly, because English is not my first language, I was able to understand some of the dialogues better. (Finally, I understood what Liv was trying to say in Dutch =) The widescreen option is fantastic. You really get into the battle scenes and to see all the extra footage ... For example, when John Frost's battalion enters Arnhem, you see people riding a bicycle in the background, which you can not see in the pan and scan version.But with such support as DVD, and also with the 25th anniversary movies last year, MGM and United Artists missed a great chance. It's a shame that the only extra is the original trailer. I really would have liked to see additional images included on a second disc. The Dutch Broadcasting Company (NOS) must have a lot of file sequences, I remember that the information broadcast often spent time on the shooting of the film, like reconstituted excrement. In addition to these images, the studio must also have additional images. They could even produce a new documentary on the filming of this film, including interviews with lead actors and Sir Richard Attenborough. And what about images and original notes about the battle? Despite this, it's still a must buy if you're in war and / or classic movies. After 25 years, this is always the case and it is always a pleasure to watch. Buy it and in the meantime, keep hoping for a special DVD edition. I give 4 stars to this DVD, but if they had included additional material, it would easily get 5 stars!"

b'This film has always been one of my favorites. I have three copies on VHS (two backups replace the one I usually watch). I ask all my friends to watch it, and most like it as much as me. It\'s stupid, completely inept and totally hilarious. I put it with Richard Elfman \'s "Forbidden Zone" and John Paiz\' s "Crimewave" (aka "The Big Crimewave") as one of the three greatest cult movies of all time. The problem is that no one has ever heard of this movie. I could not believe my luck when I came across the DVD! ! ! I thought I was dreaming. I was tempted to buy three copies ... just in case. First, I watched the scenes and extras removed, which was pretty good. It seemed strange, because I had already seen a lot of deleted scenes (they are part of my VHS versions). Then, when I sat down to watch the movie, my heart was broken. Someone, in his infinite wisdom, has decided to censor almost all nakedness, and many others have been shortened or are completely absent. I guess this version of the movie may seem a bit morose, because the missing scenes may have slowed down the film a little bit, but the scenes that were happening were all irrelevant. The ineptitude of this film is what made it special, and editing it to a more "professional" version is a limit blasphemy. After seeing this edited and censored version, I wish I had never bought it at all. I wish that did not even exist. Thank you my god for my copies of the VHS. Anyone who has decided to censor and edit this film should be disconcerted. Thank you very much for destroying one of my favorite movies. I only give him two stars because the extras are cool.'

b'As other commentators have said, I was anxious to watch an authentic adaptation of H.G. Wells\' classic novel. And the comedian will not have Oscar nominations. I also wonder if the original 3-hour version would be better for watching stories. In this 125-minute version, there is a lot of leap from one sub-plot to another without proper scene development in my opinion. The Martian "red weed" appears briefly in a few scenes without any explanation. On the positive side, I thought the tripods and handling machines looked pretty cool, the sound effects are pretty good and the musical score is beautiful. Unfortunately, this is not enough to overcome the otherwise poorly executed production. If only the CGI was at the forefront of technology and the color filters were eliminated, it would be a good movie, but not great. If only ... ..'

b'I imagine this odd little exercise of Bill Zebub, a low-budget schlockmeister, owes a lot to his inspiration for the South Park team\'s "Team America" \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bpuppet epic. After a long comic "warning" at the beginning of the film, "the plot" essentially tries to parody many Hollywood movies, politics and religions, and inject as many disturbing images as possible of sexually mutilated Barbi dolls. "Actiing" is provided by a variety of "action" toys that are handled (disordered) by hand and via green screen overlays. A bit of that is fun, but ultimately, the concept is out of breath and Zebub\'s macabre foreboding with vilely S & M images perpetuated on female dolls becomes quite frightening. However, the basic concept has some ingenuity that makes this satirical film more appealing than most ostensibly more serious Zebub efforts. I would recommend not to buy it (or not at all) at a minimal (used) price, because the content would probably not result from multiple views.'

b'Ah, Gargoyles, finally, have a well deserved DVD release. This series is really excellent and has the honor of being one of Disney \'s most mature animated series to date. The series revolves around a group of living gargoyles, which are stone in day and night. Due to a curse inflicted upon them, a small group of these creatures are stuck in stone for a thousand years before being woken up in Manhattan in 1994. Like all the supernatural beings of Manhattan, they naturally decide to fight The crime. It may sound corny, but in the hands of a formidable team of writers, the series becomes much more than a story of "fighting the crime of non-human superheroes". Instead, Gargoyles becomes an interesting story with an attractive storyline and good characters. This series is helped by its ability to take risks - the first episode ends even with what is essentially a mass murder. The show also addresses issues such as gun control in a fairly mature and realistic way, while managing not to be too moral or preachy. For example, the gun control episode "Deadly Force" (disgracefully omitted by Toon Disney because of the presence of firearms and firearms, despite its strong message against the inexperienced game with such weapons and the release of the DVD) sends its message without the characters say: "The weapons are bad, mm\'kay? The series also has a narrow continuity rarely seen in American cartoons; the effects of the previous episodes and the episodes have a well-defined order - unlike some other Disney characters at the time, episodes Gargoyles were generally to be broadcast in the right order. The series is also full of references to Shakespeare (and other things, the first episode of season 2 contains, of all things, a Kafka joke that I did not have * years *) .Gargoyles is really the one of the most interesting and unique cartoon series in Disney\'s safe. This DVD is a great buy for long-time fans and highly recommended for new people curious to know what it is. The first season beautifully showcases the rest of the series and gives the viewer an idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bwhat the show is all about. I\'m already looking forward to future versions of the rest of the series.'

b'If anyone doubts the temporal quality of celebrity, just think of Douglas Fairbanks for his point of view. In his day, the fame of Douglas Fairbanks was unprecedented. He and his wife, Mary Pickford, were considered the royal family of the United States. Today, his wonderful action movies are not only watched by moviegoers, and his face and name are lost to the youngest generation (if Jay Leno\'s interviews are just clues, our youngest Americans seem proud). for the name of the vice president, let alone a silent actor like Fairbanks). What Douglas Fairbanks should disappear from memory is extremely sad. "The Mark of Zorro" is a good example of the kind of film that Fairbanks specialized towards the end of the era of silence and was extremely popular because of the dynamic presence of its star. There is really nothing to compare with Fairbanks since his departure from the cinema. No star of action, because it can get closer to his grace and power in an action movie. If you doubt me, buy this DVD and see for yourself. Watch Fairbanks jump over tables, jump over high walls to ride a horse, jump from a table to a cornice near a ceiling, and so on. And it was not just that he was able to do these feats, he was doing them without effort. The pure grace of man was really exciting. He never seemed to empty anything. I realized this as I watched Zorro\'s mark during a scene where Fairbanks lifted one leg and took a galloping horse to rest as easily as if he were descending the ladder. It seemed so easy, I went back and watched the scene again to make sure I had seen what I thought I saw. Yeah, he did it - smooth as silk. Then there is his acting. In this film, Fairbanks plays a duel role: Don Diego, a bland young noble, and his masked counterpart, Zorro. His interpretation of Don Diego is subtle and effective. His body seems shapeless and soft. His manners are distracted and indecisive and vaguely lost. He hates the sword and constantly wipes his face because of his great fatigue. "When his love is declared" It\'s not a man - it\'s a fish! "She hits the nail on the head. Yet when he dons the mask, his body and manners are reborn. His body is supple and full of movement, and his smile, that radiant, radiant smile that radiates pure happiness, is almost as devastating as his blade. Finally, there is the artistic design and scenery of this film. Fairbanks loved these period pieces and spared no expense in research and detail. His care, his financial investment and his dedication to craftsmanship are really revealing. All this has a beautiful "deep" feeling. By the way, this review is based on the release of the Kino DVD of this movie, and like all versions of Kino, this edition is just great. May God bless Kino for being one of the best companies that conserves and markets silent films. If you have taken the trouble to read this review, please purchase this movie. If you do, Douglas Fairbanks will again be popular and famous, at least in your heart.-Mykal Banta'

b'The MILL CREEK ENTERTAINMENT multi-film packs are reasonably priced and of good quality. These twenty transfers of unrealized public domain films range from very good to sometimes equitable - none is improbable. The "legendary detectives" of this DVD pack are all derived from the 1930s and 1940s. "The Shadow" was a half-hour radio series broadcast on 31/07/30. Originally only the narrator of mystery stories, in 1937 "Shadow" Lamont Cranston (now portrayed by a young Orson Welles) had become an integral character in every broadcast episode. The 24-year program ended on Boxing Day 1954. The three Shadow films shown here were first seen in 1937, at the peak of the popularity of the radio show. Bulldog Drummond was created in 1920 by the British author Herman McNeile, who published under the pseudonym `` Sapper. The stories of Drummond were directly influenced by the "black" detectives then popular in American fiction and are considered the precursors of James Bond. The half-dozen films in this set that feature this character all date back to the late 1930s. "Dick Tracy" was a cartoon crimefighter animated by the imagination of Detroit newspaper artist Chester Gould, in October 1931. Gould worked on the bands until his retirement in 1977. 76 years after the creation of the series, other artists still produce these stories. In comics, police inspector Tracy seduced his future wife, Tess Trueheart, for 18 years, before marrying her on Christmas Day 1949. During this period, Tracy in the square jaw ran into legendary crooks. such as BB Eyes, Flattop Jones, Pruneface, Haf and Haf, 88 Keys, Mr, Crime, Sphinx, Pearless and Faceless Redrum. from 1935 to \'48. In the movies, Tracy was mainly portrayed by Ralph Byrd (from 37). Byrd stayed with the series until it ended after a short series on early television. "Sherlock Holmes", the most famous fictional detective of all, was created by Scottish author and physician Arthur Conan Doyle. The stories of Holmes were published in various British magazines from 1887. Over the years, Conan Doyle tried more than once to kill the character, but the public clamor made him reconsider. Doyle wrote four novels and fifty-six novels with Holmes and Dr. John Watson, his friend and cohort in the adventure, until the death of the knightly author in 1930. MILL CREEK\'S SUSPENSE! 20 Movie Pack would make a good companion for this set of DVDs. The numbers preceding the previous titles are from 1 to 10 votes per poll found on a film resource website. (5.6) Bulldog Drummond Returns (1937) - John Barrymore / John Howard (5.7) Bulldog Drummond Escapes (1937) - Ray Milland / Guy Standing (5.9) Bulldog Drummond In Africa (1938) - John Howard / Anthony Quinn (in a role minor) (6.0) Drummond \'s Peril Bulldog (1938) - John Barrymore / John Howard (5.9) Drummond\' s Revenge Bulldog (1937) - John Barrymore / John Howard (6.4) Bulldog Drummond \'s Secret Police (1939) - John Howard / Heather Angel (5.5) Dick Tracy, Detective - Morgan Conway / Anne Jeffreys (5.9) The Dick Tracy Dilemma (1947) - Ralph Byrd / Lyle Latell / Christopher Kay (6.1) Dick Tracy Meets Gruesome (1947) - Boris Karloff / Ralph Byrd (6.0) Dick Tracy vs. Cueball (1946) - Morgan Conway / Anne Jeffreys (7.0) Dressed to Kill ("Sherlock Holmes") (1946) - Basil Rathbone / Nigel Bruce (6.1) ) International Crime ("The Shadow") (1938) - Rod La Roque / Astrid Allwyn (5.3) Shadow Strikes (1937) - Rod La Roque / Agnes Anderson (6.5) The Shadow: The Avenger Invisible (1958) - Richard Derr / Jeanne Neher / Dan Mullin (6.8) Sherlock Holmes and the Secret Weapon (1943) - Basil Rathbone / Nigel Bruce / Lionel Atwill (6.0) The Sign of Four (Sherlock Holmes) \') (1932) - Arthur Wontner / Ian Hunter (6.4) A Scarlet Study ("Sherlock Holmes") (1933) - Reginald Owen / Warburton Gamble (7.0) Terror By Night ("Sherlock Holmes") (1946) - Basil Rathbone / Nigel Bruce / Alan Mowbray (6.1) The Triumph of Sherlock Holmes (1935) - Arthur Wontner / Ian Fleming (as Dr. Watson) (6.9) The Woman in Green (`Sherlock Holmes\') (1945) - Basil Rathbone / Nigel Bruce / Hillary Brooke'

b'This is an interesting movie to discover when you are surfing on channels, but not a DVD to rent or own. What can you say about a movie where the hero massacres hundreds of people but can not save his wife or be burned to death and yet manages to save a cute puppy. It\'s not so much a science fiction movement on a futuristic \'Orfordian dystopia\' as it is a recipe for how to make a sci-fi movie about a futuristic `` Orwellian Dystopia. "Watching this movie was a lot like playing Trivial Pursuit. It was more pleasant to try to choose the different ingredients of the recipe than to watch the movie. Take Fahrenheit 451; add considerable aid from 1984; just a pinch of Brave New World (the "injections"); add lots of Matrix special effects; add enough shoot \'em up action with a variety of weapons (for more flavor, stir in a samurai sword fight); and just a slice of beef cake with a Christian Bale scene without his shirt. Mix well and cook in a crematorium (this future company incinerates not only books but works of art and social misfits) to 451 degrees until everything is done, then apply a delicious deep-glaze of existential depth (many characters are looking at each other). The corners of their eyes and two of the characters quote Yeats "He wishes the fabrics of the sky." Top with a maraschino cherry of a happy ending (like the one from Fight Club) and you have Equilibrium. the premise of the film is that after an apocalyptic war, all mankind is run by a single government in which a figure of Big Brother maintains total control and total compliance. In order to prevent conflict, all feelings and sensations are removed by constant monitoring and medication injections. People who violate the dictated norm are tracked down by "clerics" and eliminated by incineration. The character of Christian Bales is one of the "clerics". "He is a single father of two and his wife was cremated. He is a great cleric, but as the film progresses, he begins to doubt what he is doing. In the end, he searches for underground resistance leaders who are literally forced to live in a secret room. filled with a clutter of paintings, books, old toys and bric-a-brac (not unlike a modern teenager\'s room). Inspired by a young woman he has in custody and a cute puppy, he joins the resistance. In short, after a career of killing and cremating people, they will remain drones without emotion and will not kill each other. The character kills people and blows things up so society can be free to express their emotions and everyone starts to kill themselves and blow things up.'

b'That\'s the first thing I want to say about the 2012 "2012 Blu-ray Release," The Extraterrestrial: "It\'s back, in its original form. b"In the 1960s, when filming was still an art form, puppeteer George Pal created what was considered a true classic, The Time Machine. Selected as his hero, the famous Austrian actor Rod Taylor, playing the role of Herbert George Wells, the director accurately portrays an adventurer, but in a bad mood, a gentleman, who works with inventions and aspires to a more peaceful century. . Using what has been hailed as the best special effects of this date, Pal launches Taylor in the future. Stopping only to observe the changing eras where the war is waged with better and more sophisticated weapons, Wells finally arrives in the land of the Eloi. Here, he meets the beautiful and sensual Weena (Yvette Mimieux) and his people. During their brief time together, Weena lets Wells learn that despite their idyllic paradise, it's not without dangers. In this future, it was the Morlocks who became the masters of the world and stole Wells' time machine. Deeply committed to eternity in the future, Taylor engages in a battle against the Morlocks, which will result in a story that he will later tell David Filby (Alan Young) and his Victorian friends. The film is superb and despite being redone several times, has never been equaled. H.G. Wells would have approved. *****"

b'The Italian work of the 60\'s is well known to the British public, for whom the film is also regularly broadcast on television as the James Bond films, The Great Escape and the Queen\'s speech. Negative criticism of American viewers is as much the result of the lack of cultural context and the lack of knowledge of many actors. The film has aged well and offers a fun, if instead of stained rose, snapshot of the British culture.The cast of 60 "includes Noel Coward as Mr. Bridger, the crime genius, and Michael Caine as fop Charlie Croker. The British public will recognize a host of well-known actors in cameo roles, including Benny Hill and John Le Mesurier. The stars of the film are without a doubt the cars. Pleasantly, the array of 60\'s supercars including a Lamborghini Muira, E-Type Jaguars and Charlie Aston Martin eclipse by the three Mini Cooper\'s who lead the Italian police on an incredible chase through Turin. Remy Julienne and her stunt driving team produced one of the most amazing and well-known films, at least for the British public. It can be said that this rate even more as one of the best car chase sequences and especially since the stunts were actually filmed on site in Turin (and Coventry in the case of the sewer scenes) and cars with minimal changes.There are many memorable moments in the movie beyond the Mini Cooper sequence. Benny Hill\'s big wife was obsessed with Professor Peach in the Turin tram and the end of the hanging was trotting in my head. The extra features of the DVD are good but not really remarkable. The documentary "Making Of" provides a number of interesting points of view on the film. The commentary track is a bit surpasses but deserves a listen. There is really only one scene removed, the car balloon "Blue Danube" rather amazing on ice. In summary, this is a true British classic with an excellent cast, score and script. A glimpse of the 60s in London, a fantastic distribution (at least for the British public) and the superb car chase scene make it a good buy. The Hollywood remake, while not a bad film in its own right, shares only the title, a scenario based on a gold holdup and the BMW Mini updated with the original.And for all those who Ask about the original Mini, they are really small and so much fun to drive.'

b'28 Days Later is such a well-managed movie in terms of suspense, role-play and meaning that every time I watch it, I am more and more convinced that it will become a classic of science fiction. This is not the case of the "sequel", which could be well staged by Fresnadillo, but it is not well structured as a narrative and does not lend a valuable "message" to the public. 28 weeks later, they frequently make the mistake of insulting our intelligence. How can you explain that the husband of the woman who survived and who is being held in a health facility can have access to the room where there is no guard, no doctor, no soldier or vigilant staff ? There are no cameras, in a situation where the re-emergence of the virus is feared and possible, after the diagnosis made by the medical staff of the victim. In fact, this is the key event causing the virus violation. In addition, the film is so focused in the bloodbath, the vampire biting and running, that no meaningful dialogue is possible, preventing anyone from understanding the chaos. And what can you say about the helicopter used as deadly power to decapitate dozens of vampire zombies? The least I can say is that the scene is the pinnacle of sensationalism. And by insisting on the meaning of the film, why is something as valuable in the story as the possibility that the survivor or her children have the key to the treatment of the virus is simply lost in favor of a terrible, pessimistic and fatal end? Is it the bait for another sequel, parallel to the "Alien" series? Meanwhile, we end up with a "suite" that does not properly honor 28 Days Later, regardless of whether Boyle is among the producers.'

b"I did not know that Ganz had what it took for me to see him here as Hitler. Alexandra Maria Lara, her young na\xc3\xafve secretary, is also very good. Cast is excellent. b"Werner Herzog is the perfect and unique incarnation of the always worried, irreverent, dissatisfied and unconventional director who likes to walk on the razor's edge and likes to expose the limit situations just before reaching the boiling point. has been signed for novelty and original proposals, characterized by unexplored territories and unimaginable stages.In this case, we are witnessing the clash of the two civilizations, visibly differentiated, the ancestral aborigines and the Western way of life, where the myth and progress collides like the inevitable crash of two trains moving each, in opposite directions. A company will set up in the middle of the Australian desert, to explore and exploit the uranium reserves. But they will be confronted by ancestral tribes who oppose them because they will interrupt the dream of green ants. A film dedicated to Herzog's mother, with intriguing and pointed reflections, when this case will be discussed in the Supreme Court, through a very interesting essay, where the happy ending will be absent. The final sequence will invite you to think and reflect."

b'I saw this film about a month ago at the local film library. About eighty minutes later, I discreetly looked at my watch and was dismayed by the realization that the film was not even half finished. Celine and Julie go boating? There was no water, let alone a boat, so far. Where was this weird story with repeated scenes over and over again, and when was it going to end? I am a patient movie viewer but it was too much. A number of film critics, whose opinions I usually respect, have practically built religions around their appreciation of this film. I wondered if this could only be the case of the "new clothes of the emperor"? Almost two hours later, it was over and I emerged from the theater and told myself that I could have seen two real cinematic masterpieces at the time I lost my time on Rivette\'s film ... But in a way, it was not over. The effect of the film persisted. It was not just an intellectual riddle that I had to face, the film was under my skin. The scenes are constantly repeated in my head like a strange dream. Their pace was different from anything I had encountered before. Celine and Julie never complied with any of my expectations - neither did Jacques Rivette. In two separate scenes of the film, C\xc3\xa9line and Julie present themselves to men who, without knowing it, believe they meet the other woman. In each case, the two women completely subvert the worlds of men, digging holes in their rigid convention. Throughout the movie, Rivette was doing the same thing with me. Everything about the film, from its "intrigue" to its subtle handling of reality through its rhythm, forces you to abandon your expectations (or to be unhappy trying to retain them). You must relate to the film at your own level, as with a child. Only then can you enjoy it? I do not know exactly why the movie had such an effect on me but he says something of his power that, more than a month later, I still think about it. In recent days, I have had this growing desire to see `` C\xc3\xa9line and Julie go boating \'\' The ideal circumstance for a first meeting is definitely in a theater where you risk turning it off. Now that I\'ve crossed this Rubicon, I\'d like it to be available on a Region 0 or 1 DVD, so I can lose another three hours.'

b"& quot; Back to the future & quot; can be the most enchanting comedy / adventure ever. The film is a sci-fi tale about a young man who accidentally traveled in the 30s to 50s. While less important science fiction films would focus on the concepts of temporal paradoxes and material, & quot; Back to the future & quot; Focuses on open eyes, charming characters and a lot of good humor. The story begins with Marty McFly in 1985. Marty is a hopeless loafer with two dorky parents and a mad scientist best friend. Doc Brown, a friend of Marty, has developed a plutonium-based propulsion machine made from a DeLorean sports car. After a successful test, Marty accidentally transplanted in 1955 and was stranded there, he left his extra plutonium in 1985. What happens next is a series of wonderful surprises as Marty interacts with 1950s city-dwellers seeking the younger version of Doc Brown, but what is even more surprising and magical is Marty's relationship with his teenage parents. The film takes a young man 's point of view on his losing parents and makes him realize that at one time his parents were also optimistic and frightened. He finally meets his parents for the first time. The film also suggests the idea that you can go back in time and help your parents when they need it the most, as Marty certainly tries. While the film is a game of heart, there is plenty of action as Doc Brown designs an exciting project to bring Marty back into the future, with lightning, numerous visual effects and a high-tech gliding race. & quot; Back to the future & quot; is the most perfectly balanced mix of science fiction, comedy and adventure. It is a film suitable for children of the 80s and 50s."

b'"I know who killed me" is a small horror release conceived as a sort of "return" vehicle for Lindsay Lohan in early 2007. Needless to say, the film did not succeed in this venture. Away plays the role of Aubrey Fleming, an attractive, but relatively naive, high school student who is the prey of a crazy serial killer of torture who manages to cut a few limbs before miraculously escaping from his clutches. When she wakes up in the hospital, she thinks she\'s a girl named Dakota Moss, a kind of fictional alter ego with a life straight out of a sweet porn novel. Lohan slightly dressed as she writhed in slow motion, performing pole-dancing on a loose tape joint. Is Aubrey, herself a writer of fiction, just a victim of repression, a wild and free spirit so obsessed with being a "good little girl" that she has allowed her true nature to remain buried? in his subconscious? years? And is the trauma she suffers simply the vehicle through which this true nature can now be put forward? Or is there another less purely psychological explanation - say, symbiotic twins? - for this sudden change of identity? No matter the answers to these questions, because this depressing incursion into sadism, dismemberment and the supernatural hocus pocus is poorly written, interpreted in an amateurish way and completely devoid of thrills or common sense. In fact, the story itself could have had some validity if it had not forced the public to wallow so much in gratuitous annoyance. However, every time we start developing the slightest interest in what is happening, we are subjected to another wave of stomach bleeding. Yuck.'

I wanted to see the machines, the drama, the tension of people struggling with disasters that took them away, the triumph of honest people over the impersonal malevolence of nature, and all the good things that the original had in abundance, with a camp and humor that did not take themselves too seriously. The original was about adventure first, with the accessory "romance", and it is an important point, rather lost in this film. This is a "growing" teen movie that uses the Thunderbirds as a cover. b'Carole Lombard was a beautiful, intelligent natural blonde, Screwball\'s greatest actress, best-paid actress, Clark Gable\'s wife and one of Hollywood\'s most powerful women in the 1930s until her death This beautifully restored DVD gives us a glimpse of Carole Lombard and the effect she had on the audience of the 30s. It was her only Technicolor movie she ever made. So sit back and watch her natural beauty and acting genius evolve on the screen. Fredric March as co-star adds to this adorably humorous film. In summary: Hazel Flagg (Lombard), a Vermont girl who suffers from radium poisoning (terminal). New York Jounalist (March) speaks about it in a newspaper and wants to take advantage of this event to increase the popularity of its magazines by sponsoring Hazel. Bringing him to New York City and presenting him with the "Keys of the City" status and VIP raises a lot of public awareness. Hazel discovers she has been misdiagnosed and continues to thwart the scam. Meanwhile, Mars begins to fall in love with Hazel and he wants her to rest and be comfortable until his end comes. As you can see, this has a strange aspect of events, which is the main ingredient of the "SCREWBALL COMEDIES" of the 30s. Prove "Nothing is sacred"! ! ! Extras include: 2 first silent Lombard movies and personal Gable & Lombard movies. This is a "LIMITED EDITION" DVD to collect.'

b'Spoilers in front, but again, who is not familiar with Casablanca, even if we have not seen it? I\'ve watched \'Casablanca\' again and again since I bought the Special Edition DVD, and is there a movie that you can watch over and over without ever having enough? And does a film attract a wider audience? Everything seems to be as close to perfection as possible. But what is the particularity? Is it his great mix of genres, never equaled by another film? When we think of "Casablanca" first, we remember it as a romantic film (well, most of us). But again, it\'s also a drama involving terror, murder and flight. We can call it a character study, centered on Rick. And there are some moments of comical delight, just think of the pickpocket ("This place is full of vultures, vultures everywhere!") Or the elderly couple the last night before their emigration to the United States (`` What watch? `\'). But \'Casablanca\' is not only great as a whole, it is always up if we divide it and look at lines of dialogue, scenes or performances alone. Is there another film that has more dialogues than "Casablanca"? I\'m thinking of Pulp Fiction, All About Eve, and Sunset Blvd. "Come on too, but I still think that Casablanca surpasses everything. And not only is the dialogue great, it\'s unforgettable, especially by Humphrey Bogart ("I was misinformed") and Claude Rains ("I\'m shocked, shocked to see the game going on here"). Many scenes have become part of the film\'s story; The duel of \'Die Wacht am Rhein\' and \'La Marseillaise\' is probably one of the biggest scenes ever shot (the only one I can think of that would be Hynkel and Chaplin\'s Globe \'s The Great Dictator\'), and the last scene is probably familiar to the few who have never seen Casablanca. Am I the only one to be absolutely convinced that the film would not have become what it is today if Rick and Ilsa would have been in a relationship? About the performances: So much has been said about the singularity of the chemical composition of Humphrey Bogart and Ingrid Bergman as Rick and Ilsa, the tremendous turning of Claude Rains as Renault, performances of Peter Lorre (one of the 10 most great actors of all time) like Ugarte and Sydney Greenstreet as Ferrari and about Dooley Wilson stopping the show as Sam. I\'d love to point out here two other performances, one that is not mentioned as often and that is ignored : Conrad Veidt as Major Strasser had a really difficult task here, because his character is the only evil one, but still Strasser is not a one-dimensional character, and it took more than 50 years before another actor gives an impressive performance (maybe even more) as a Nazi, Ralph Fiennes in \'Schindler\'s List\'. But why no one ever mentions S. K. Sakall, who embodies Carl, the merry server of Rick\'s Caf & oacute; Follow & oacute; Rican, is beyond me. He has much more time on the screen than Lorre, Greenstreet and Wilson, and probably about as much as Veidt, and it \'s a joy every time he is on screen. I just like his reaction when the pickpocket (`` The vultures everywhere! \'\') The accidentally hits, or the reaction to the newspaper `` What watch \'\'. Or how he says he gave Strasser the best table, "being German, he would have taken it anyway." His performance is simply neglected. Is there a weak link in "Casablanca"? Each film, so close to perfection, has one or two minor defects, so we can find them in "Casablanca" too, if we really make efforts. So, yes, one might wonder how much gibberish makes sense for transit letters. It can be emphasized that Paul Henreid, although his performance is certainly good, does not come close to the size of his co-stars. However, the film is so close to perfection that I am almost ashamed to try desperately to find less than perfect elements. Whatever the upcoming movie, how many suites will spill over the screen and how much scrap it will have to sit, something is certain if we want to see a great movie desperately: we will always have Casablanca!'

Apart from the commentary track and short films, few things are interesting or interesting for the adult. The real problem with this new edition "Big Top" is that it is not very different from the "60th edition". There is a different music video, adding a feature and losing others. b'Web sites that analyze the positive and negative reviews of major critics have a positive score of at least 95% for Ratatouille, which puts it clearly at the top of the 2007 films. Is this the best movie of the year? No, but it is the one that attracts the most, because almost everyone will consider it a positive experience. The ratatouille follows R\xc3\xa9my, a curious rat who aspires to be more than a garbage thief. Remy\'s keen sense of taste and his taste for food draw him into the culinary arts. By stealing what he can from an elderly owner who enjoys cooking shows and books, R\xc3\xa9my becomes a loyal member of one of France\'s most famous chefs, Auguste Gusteau. After Remy has learned that Gusteau has been dead for years and has watched rebroadcasts of his television program, the little rat begins to be guided by Ben Kenobi by the spirit of the deceased chief. which was taken over by a naive capitalist who uses Gusteau\'s image to sell frozen burritos and corndogs. Using a young cook as a support, R\xc3\xa9my tries to rebuild Gusteau\'s reputation and make his restaurant to his glory. The resulting action is an often charming story of a rat so dedicated to achieving his goal. Many laughs are found when his family comes in search of documents, and the chief antagonists (the owner and a food critic) create real moments of danger. Remy is really a movie "hero", someone dedicated to a cause that, according to him, will make the world better. Although lacking the heart of Toy Story movies or the comedic genius of the first Shrek, Ratatouille continues the trend of the revival of animation that has provided some of the best films of the last decade.'

b'What can I say about this "story" not inspired by Bret\'s first novel? The adaptation of the film does not contain the scenes and tone that I felt had made the book so captivating and memorable. (The dead boy in the alley scene, the snuff movie with the minor girl ...) We can not say that this movie is based on the book - it\'s rather inspired by the novel. Despite this fall, the film deserves to be watched by any fan of Bret Easton Ellis - if only to satisfy his curiosity. The movie contains neither the depressing one-liners nor the confusing minor characters that make the book so interesting The Sisters of Clay, Spin) The film gave the impression that Julian was the protagonist, while I still felt that the novel was to see the events unfold before Clay\'s eyes. One of the most endearing parts of the novel is Clay\'s "flashbacks" before he leaves for school. The movie only talks about that at the beginning, and the flashback is about Blair, not his parents, who were the subjects of the flashbacks I found most interesting. The lunch scene between Clay and his father is pure genius. The detachment between father and son made me cringe. This scene is not included in the film at all. Unfortunately, film adaptation to books is almost always lost in "translation". "American Psycho" is really the only one of the films adapted from his books that, in my opinion, captures the tone of the book while compacting it in an inaudible story without losing Bret\'s style, thanks to the fact that Bateman himself is the narrator.Everything, "Less Than Zero" is not really a bad movie. Just a bad adaptation. It captures what was both awesome and forgettable of the popular film of the 80s, and matches any entertaining teen drama from that era (including the extravagant consumption of cocaine by the miners, New Wave, where Are They Now\'s future star) , James Spader). There are moving moments, but it seems that the film has tried to find a conclusion to which the book did not succeed (and had a reason not to do so). After all, Julian does not die in the novel, and Blair certainly does not return to Camden with Clay (Morrissey would not be proud). allusion also: how much Clay is upset, apathetic and lost now that he has changed and acquired a new perspective, while his friends, unfortunately, have not done so. And a serious complaint: Where is the Disappear Here panel? It is an integral part of the novel \'s imagery and is absent from the film (unless I miss it). All: If you\'re a fan of Bret\'s books, give a shot to this movie. It\'s worth a look at once, but do not be upset if he\'s just trying to capture the mood or purpose of the novel.'

b'When I came across Across the Universe, it seemed a bit esoteric, even with the Beatles\' musical pedigree. But from the first minute, when Jim Sturgess sings "Girl," everything makes sense. You must really respect how much of the Beatles\' musical legacy has been incorporated into this effort. Lennon, McCartney, Harrison and Starr have made some of the greatest music of the 20th century and besides being a good film, Across the Universe really highlights that. The power of songs comes to life at every turn. Imagined in an original way with a beautiful artistic direction and a cinematography, Across the Universe skilfully weaves the Beatles in the socio-political context of the time when the songs were written. Hats off to the director Julie Taymor and the team who thought very well and the excellent cast that sings all better than you would expect. This is quite an achievement, since it could have been disastrous or badly done. The actor Sturgess makes me think of a young Paul McCartney, but this is where the resemblance to the Beatles ends. for today\'s audience. It\'s a film that comes from the heart that every fan of the Beatles should watch and that the curious of the music can discover.'

b'First of all, I want to thank all the critics here. It was their critics of this beautiful movie that tempted me to buy it (that and the fact that the director also did "Breaker Morant" - one of my favorites). I am a big fan of this kind. I loved "Dances with Wolves" and "Jeremiah Johnson" and really enjoyed "The Last of the Mohicans" and "Last of the Dogmen", but none of these great movies compare to the absolute. realism portrayed in "black dress" .This is a simple story set in the early seventeenth century ... a story of a French Jesuit priest who was commissioned by his canoe superiors to a Huron post 1500 miles away (with help the Indian Scouts and an interpreter) and help convert the Huron to Christianity, thus saving their souls. In this movie, the protagonist is not a superhero who makes no mistake, shows no weaknesses, can shoot and pull out any living man. On the contrary, he is only a young priest full of self-satisfaction, ignorance, fear and doubt. But despite that (or because of it), his bravery is really unmatched. This is a story of people fighting for their lives every day against the breathtaking hardness of nature and other Indian tribes. It is also a story of conflict between two very different cultures. This is shown with a strange subtlety, but the effects are devastating. `` Black Dress \'\' goes where few movies have been before or since. It\'s an Oscar-winning film like I\'ve never seen it before. Cinematography is dark, cold and unforgiving, just like history. Between 1 and 10, I give this film a solid 9. This is really one of my favorites.'

b'Lewis Gilbert \'s masterpiece in 1983, a sensitive and emotionally satisfying adaptation of Willy Russel\' s intelligent and insightful two - character game. Gilbert and Russel team up for the wonderful "Shirley Valentine," but their work in this film remains unmatched.Michael Caine gives one of the most memorable performances of an illustrious career, disappearing in his Frank character, and Julie Walters is as beautiful as Rita / Susan, David Hentschel\'s music is perfectly appropriate, Frank Watts\' cinematography is inspired, the screenplay is both touching and honest, but the magic of this film lies in the interaction between the two characters. This film shows the journey towards self-awareness embodied by education, as the character of Rita / Susan evolves from hairdresser to student, intellectual, diligent and finally very different from the beginning of the film, but undeniably and only Rita . & quot; The best gift we can give to another is the love of learning, and I think it\'s one of the greatest stories s love never devoted to celluloid. The end could be & quot; as inevitable as tragedy, & quot; according to Willy Russel, the relationship between Frank and Rita made their emotional journey interesting and we are all richer for their trip.'

b"If Daniel Barenboim is not the greatest living classical musician in the world, he is certainly the most versatile. During his career of more than 50 years, his name is associated with many famous recordings of opera, symphony, small ensemble and solo piano. With the last half of his career marked by the distinction on the podium, we can forget that he is still an accomplished concert pianist. Here, we are treated with both talents when Barenboim conducts the Staatskapelle Berlin and plays the five piano concertos of Beethoven. In the accompanying booklet, we find that Barenboim recorded these works for the first time in 1967 at the age of 24 under Otto Klemperer. Now he revisits them 40 years later on the occasion of his 65th birthday. The challenges of serving as conductor and soloist are undoubtedly considerable, but Barenboim, fully played from memory and without score, makes it easy and natural. Although he is fully engaged in his role as a soloist, Barenboim never loses the command of the orchestra. Sometimes his direction is in the momentary freedom of a gesture of the left hand. At other times, it is the subtlety of his nod or the speed of his eye. The Staatskapelle is perfectly in tune with these nuances and their game is always at the rendezvous and without hesitation. Among the many highlights: the wonderful piano-clarinet exchange in the Largo of the first concerto, the Rondo Vivace's narrative of the fourth and all the beauty and majesty of the Emperor. The performance was recorded in front of a live audience during a three-day piano festival in Bochum, Germany, in 2007. The concerts took place in the Jahrhunderthalle, which presents an architectural design from an old steelworks. The minimalist interior with high ceilings and exposed steel beams gives up the traditional elegance that adorns many concert halls (and the stifling pretext that accompanies it). Aesthetically, the Jahrhunderthalle is a place of comfort and clean lines of sight above all else. The sold-out audience appreciates and respects the music. They are often in sight, but rarely heard (even between movements) until their applause at the end of each job. They are intelligently (if not formally) dedicated people who know classical music when they hear it. Some of the performances took place during the daylight hours, allowing the large back windows to cast a beautiful natural light on the audience and the performers. more enlightened by soft stage lighting that showcases musicians and their instruments where it's needed and without difficult shadows. The 1080i Blu-ray image is almost perfect. Skin tones are natural and attractive. The color of the instruments and the dress of the public is exact, without bleeding. The ivory keyboard is correctly exposed and balanced with a lot of resolution to distinguish the keys. The black levels are strong without losing any detail in the folds of the musicians' jacket. The close-ups reveal the polished brass of the French horns as well as the fine grain of the basses and the violins. Barenboim is rightly the center of attention and one can see the delicate frizziness of her hair and the sweat beads that start to glitter on her forehead by the third movement of each concert. The PCM 2.0 audio track is clean, but the piano is not rough above the top C. On the contrary, the DTS HD-MA 5.1 track, by opening up the surround of the rear channels and a wider sound stage, delivers a magnificent sound warm and spacious, devoid of any discordance in the upper register. The piano is correctly centered while the sound integrity of each orchestral instrument is presented with distinction according to its location on stage. The full program runs around 3:20. There are no supplements except for a handful of trailers from other versions of Medici Arts. An interview with Barenboim, rehearsal footage and a brief history of the venue would have been good, but unfortunately, opportunities were missed. In the end, this is the only thing missing, because it is, in any case, a most appreciated release and another great achievement for one of the most distinguished artists of music classic."

b"This is an unusual film Merchant / Ivory dedicated to the Indian community of Trinidad from 1943 to about 1954. It focuses in particular on a young teacher, who marries a woman, steals his clever father, and lives in the countryside , just wanting to write books. However, he has to make a living, so he becomes a masseur, who is not a masseuse, but a healer. He also writes a book on Hinduism, which he publishes himself. He becomes known as Mystic Masseur and develops a country as a result. His book and the following books are quickly bought by a now adorable public who reveres him as a pundit. A brief career in politics soon follows, only for him to discover that an adoring public can become inconstant. The film meanders, just like the life of this expert. With world-class cinematography and exceptional performances from all the actors, it's a very good film, although unusual. Those interested in other cultures will find this film interesting. If you are not so inclined, deduce a star from my criticism."

b'I admit that I have never seen Mario Bava\'s films. I only recently entered Italian cinema with the films of Dario Argento and other Giallo. Until now, I had never tried a bava. So, hearing about this movie and being intrigued by the premise, I took the DVD. The premise of the movie is that four criminals rob a payroll of pharmaceutical companies during which the leaky driver is killed. The three other murderers flee to a parking lot where they take hostages, one of whom is killed to flee. Subsequently, to avoid being spotted by the police in a familiar car, they retreat and take more hostages this middle-aged man and a sick child. At this point, the movies were a violent crime movie. When he gets into the car, the film is mainly focused on driving criminals and their hostages. What is good about the film despite minor flaws is that even in its form (neither Rabid Dogs nor the re-edited Kidnapped have been completed with the support of Bava because of the circumstances that earned its "lost" status until \'to recently) suspended suspense thriller building his tension slowly. As tensions mount in the car and victims plead for their lives, even criminals start to turn against each other. One wants to rape the woman as a hostage, while another goes along with what happens when the leader is more concerned with getting to their destination. There are moments in the film that seemed great to me in a transgressive way, namely that the new movies could not even get close to the head. And in the end, I do not want to spoil it, but if you get so much into the plot, it will certainly surprise you. I was totally blown away by the movie. One thing is also the feeling of anger that infiltrates each image. This is a brutal film to look at sometimes with his portrait of a world that is vain and arrogant in the face of the critical situation of the hostages (especially the child). For me, it\'s a movie that can almost be compared to one of my favorites, Ran de Kurosawa. Unfortunately, I only saw the Rabid Dogs carved on the new record of Anchor Bay. It also contains the edition of Lamberto Bava Kidnapped more in line with the intentions of his father that I will look into the future but which has been disabled for the score of the synthesizer (I love the harpsichord and the organs in Rabid Dogs.) And did not want to watch the movie so soon after seeing it. Another recommendation from me, which is worth the detour.'

Non-Israeli hostages returning home - A Catholic nun insisting on staying with the rest of the hostages. All these memorable scenes, which I was eager to see again, are GONE! Although the raid itself seems largely intact, but the scenes are so dark, I had to rely on the memory of the TV version of the film to find out what was going on. All in all, great movie, bad DVD! b'Currently, this is the only version of Nobody\'s Fool available on DVD. The fact that you have a Paul Newman double header at the same price as a single title is just a bonus. Add to that a young and final role of Philip Seymour Hoffman and Oscar-winning Jessica Tandy, and you have a must-see movie and a treasure to own. I like Richard Russo\'s books. I like the Mohawk, Nobody \'s Fool and Pulitzer Prize winner Empire Falls. This latest book has been translated into an HBO mini-series, Empire Falls, which also includes, surprisingly, performances by Paul Newman and Philip Seymour Hoffman. However, Newman won only an Oscar, best actor for his role in The Color of Money in 1986. However, Newman has a charm as casual as Sully in Nobody\'s Fool, which remains my favorite of the two. Rating: Five stars.P.S. I am not a big fan of "Fat Man & Little Boy". Unlike Nobody\'s Fool, the historical drama does not have the charm and humor I prefer for repeated viewing.'

b"This workout was great. I finished it about 15 minutes ago and I can really feel it now. The workout is divided into 5 segments of 10 minutes, which is a format I love because it means you can break it down for a shorter workout and even if you do, you do not feel like an eternity because of the change. segments. The general idea is to do strengthening exercises followed by stretching to lengthen the muscles. Segment Overview: Arms: This was probably my least favorite segment. I prefer the arm segment over 10 minute solutions to a perfect body. There was about 6 to 7 minutes of work on the arms and 3 to 4 of the stretching of the arms. He felt rushed and the tracking seemed a little off the mark. Moreover, I did not find it very difficult. For this segment, you need light weights. Weight: This segment was excellent. They claim that you need a chair to do these exercises, but if you have strong enough thighs and a good balance, it is not necessary. These exercises make you feel your thighs, mine began to shake like crazy at one point and are really effective.Glutes: I think it was the most difficult segment of the DVD. I really like the fact that they have dedicated a segment specifically to glutes, a lot of video through them with thighs and I do not think they work very hard. In this segment, you will work hard, and a chair is an absolute necessity. I had to take several breaks during this time, but I can not wait to work on the full segment.Abs: I'm glad this segment was short because, even if it was a good job for the abs, Was a bit boring You put your feet on the wall and you stand in a sitting position (do not think it seems difficult, nor did I do it for about 8 minutes), then make variations from there. Not my favorite workout, but effective, I really felt my abdominals get tired. Stretching: I like it a lot when DVDs have a long segment dedicated to stretching. That said, it was not my favorite stretch segment. I wish the stretching was a little shorter and there was more stretching. It ended and I still felt the need to do other sections to feel really extended. But the stretches they have done have been good and there is something to say to hold them so long and your body will really relax. Overall, I definitely recommend buying this video. It's a really effective workout and I certainly liked all the segments to keep doing them even though they were not my favorite. I also really liked the fact that they had two instructors, a man and a woman, and that they showed simpler variants of many movements, including when it was better to rest if necessary. One of the things I have not mentioned (and this is a personal preference) is that the instruction is a voice-over that is not my favorite and that I sometimes felt that the tracking was not ok Final Thought: For $ 15 Worth It!"

b'Every year as a child, I was eager to watch Rudolph, the red-nosed reindeer, during the holidays. In fact, I could not wait to see him on television, even as an adult! b"Alice Walker is a great pioneer. She is one of those African American women who deserve all our love and worship. She explores in this film and in the book, the slow and progressive liberation of black women from their auxiliary slavery. Everything must start in their heads. They must find the courage to develop their own personality and their freedom in the closed prison of their skulls, then, little by little, they find the strength and the power to resist men, then to society, then to excel. Liberalization is a mental process that finds its full power when it becomes public and considers society as the natural field of its realization. The film is moving, moving, sensitive, intelligent, sentimental and extremely powerful, even the most universal language we can imagine, the language of the liberation of women as the first step in the liberation of humanity. Alice Walker is universal in this story and she deals with the world and with every human being. Moreover, no one is lost, no one is left on the roadside, no one is lost forever for the cause of liberation. Even the worst tyrant will find in his moral depth the idea and initiative that will make him free with others, as well as those he has embodied for decades. The husband pays the immigration of the African husband and family of his wife 's sister. And he does it for nothing at all, because he stays away and does not claim his due. Salvation is for everyone or it will not be the case. Dr. Jacques COULARDEAU, Universities of Paris II and IX."
