b'Nobody can soak a book in a scary and wet atmosphere like Neil Gaiman, imbued with humor and more than a little horror. It\'s a little dark fairy tale, filled with rotten apartments, dancing rats and mysterious soulless doppelgangers, as well as a brave heroine who finds herself in that other "sinister" world. ) is bored. Her parents are too busy to do anything with her, and her neighbors are either crazy or boring. The only exception is Wybie, a boy who does not annoy him. It\'s the kind of relentless world that any little girl would want to escape - until Coraline does it. She meets a plastered door and a colorful wormhole, leading to a new caretaker. In fact, he is so similar that she has "other mother" in the eyes of pimples (Teri Hatcher) and "another father" (John Hodgman), as well as good food, games, a shimmering magical garden. , a choir of circus rodents and magic toys. First of all, Coraline is fascinated by the other world, especially since her other parents are as attentive as her real parents are not. Then she finds her real parents sealed in a mirror. With the help of a sarcastic cat, Coraline returns to the other world. But with her parents and a trio of dead children taken hostage, Coraline\'s only hope is to play with her own freedom - and she will be trapped forever if she fails. Corinne\'s book "Neil Gaiman" is a brilliant fairy-tale atmosphere - dilapidated flats, dead children, spider webs, beetles, disembodied hands, button eyes, and a woman with pimple eyes and insects who wants to claim Coraline for herself. It\'s a world of fairy tales that turns into a nightmarish world where souls get lost and horrible things sneak into the shadows. and James and giant fishing. "Instead, Selick gives him a dark, cobwebby atmosphere, brilliant colors and surreal details (the button eclipsing the moon). And it\'s full of pretty details that could have been stupid (the scary claw hand) while running brilliantly. , the slow story suddenly turns into a completely scary territory, and a truly terrifying climax where the other mother shows her true personality. Along the way, there are plenty of incredibly scary moments: the three ghosts in a rotting bedroom / mirror, buttons and thick black wire, strange circus acts and so much more. The horror is subtle, the delicious flippancy is not.Coraline - Alice in this country of the Low Countries - is a wonderful little heroine: strong, sensitive, self-sufficient but still quite frightened by what is going on around she. Normally, I\'m not crazy about Dakota Fanning, but the voice alone is very good in this role. The sarcastic cat is a wonderful counterpoint, and the original character of the film, Wybie, is a good companion. And the other mother is the stuff of nightmares - she is totally inhuman and ruthless, and by the climax of the movie, she is having nightmares. Oh, and the French and Saunders make a pair of funny cameos like the kooky neighbors. "Coraline" is a brilliantly dark little movie, filled with dark magic and strange creatures - definitely for Gaiman fans, dark fantasy and really scary stuff.'

Even if it\'s not in dialogue, manners, facial expressions, and actions can convey a lot of things about a character. It\'s hard to believe that Bella is not a robot. Even on the cover of the DVD, she just does not try. Compared to the two male sons. Actors should be able to sell the motivations of their characters. Stanley in "Streetcar" was totally wrong, but Brando sold it. Stewart does not, so Bella is one of the least deserving "heroines" to hit the screen.'

b"Good movies on the & quot; Great War & quot; (as was known before the Second World War) are rare. After & quot; Everything is calm on the western front and & quot; Paths of Glory & quot; the list is quite short. This film does not quite fit these standards, but it's still an excellent film. In general terms, the film is quite precise in terms of the representation of the battles of the First World War. Battle scenes are also close to & quot; Save Private Ryan & quot; level of realism that you can get on commercial television. Be warned that some scenes, especially the & quot; friendly fire & quot; Artillery attack, is not for the squeam.The support is a colorful and original collection of characters, devoid of most of the usual war movie clich\xc3\xa9s. You could not watch a character and say if he would be dead before the end of the movie. It was easy to imagine that these characters had been ripped off a street in New York around 1918. Rick Schroeder gives a first-rate performance as a deeply confrontational Major Whittlesey, torn between doing his duty and the well-being of his men . where the film hits a wrong note. Whittlesey's car at first was probably not built for 15 years after the end of the Great War. The scene where the major receives his orders seems to ignore the military protocol. And in a major issue of continuity, Whittlesey's executive office talks about the wandering artillery barrage that occurred that day, when it had happened the day before."

The gore, especially on the Unrated version, is rather lively, though a bit awkward and unconvincing. There is a big troll..which is never really explained..and..uh..ah, I would just like someone to give Uwe Boll career advice. Maybe he could be a choreographer of the fight scene, he likes them, or he could try to be a production assistant, go back to the top, relearn how to make a movie. Heck, he could be a scavenger for all I do not care, someone just tells him to stop making movies. In this way, all humanity could benefit."

b"The Forbidden Planet is perhaps the preeminent work of science fiction in the 1950s. It is not science fiction at all, but it is a thoughtful and intelligent offer in its own way. Fortunately (but very vaguely) based on Shakespeare's The Tempest, it's a movie where there are so many potential layers of meaning you want to find. With Morbius as Prospero, and Prospero, in turn, most likely based on the Elizabethan mage, Dr. John Dee, co-creator of the magical Enochian language, is it really a coincidence that Morbius himself is a linguist? There is much more that I would like to say here, but I hold back for those who do not already know the film. I do not want to give spoilers. For those who have seen the film and are prone to such exercises, I will simply ask them: who - or what - would you assign the respective roles of Ariel and Caliban? How would you adapt your answers to the larger themes of the film? And what do your answers suggest about how the mind and the material were conceived in the minds of Elizabethans and Americans of the 1950s? Just to think. For those who have not seen Forbidden Planet yet, I would first and foremost say that this is a great movie that works perfectly on a simple adventure that a 10 year old could enjoy. . As a sci-fi piece, I would only point out that such depths are more than science; although the classic science fiction themes of the 1950s are interpreted in a metaphorical form. Fortunately, the reds under the bed / saucers in the sky metaphor that has become such a clich\xc3\xa9; One thing I want to add before moving on to something else is that this film deserves to be seen only for the scenography. Whether you consider it classic or dated, it's up to you. but for me, I will simply say that I have never seen the visual lexicon of the science fiction of the 50s express themselves more completely. So, too bad for the movie. How about the DVD? Well, I'm happy to say it's great! The quality of the image is beautiful, and there are lots of extras and very good too. We receive tons of promotional material, including detailed behind-the-scenes information and even an extra children's movie that also uses Robbie the Robot as an accessory. Incidentally, because I have seen written reviews for editions or versions other than the one for which I originally wrote them, let me emphasize that I write all this on Forbidden Planet (Special Edition Two Discs ). you check my profile of criticism, you will see that I am not one of those reviewers who distributes raves five stars like sweets. But if you're interested in classic science fiction, it's a movie you MUST watch. And if you're looking for the best possible DVD version, to my knowledge, that's it. Theo."

b"Donald O'Connor embodies Aladdin as both hero and comic in this fantasy of Arab nights. Visibly American in a distribution that seems largely European, O'Connor 's Aladdin is of modest origin but never leaves his lack of means (or concrete ideas to acquire) to mitigate his dreams of greatness. When he discovers that his new lamp contains a genius that will grant him three wishes, his chance of greatness can finally become reality. No one believes it, especially the lovely Djalma, who has spent years waiting for her to give up her dreams, settle down and marry her. Assured of his deepest wishes, Aladdin goes to Basorah, a large neighboring town, which is already celebrating the impending marriage of the Sultan's daughter with the young but wise Molook. Meanwhile, the evil vizier of the prince conspires to kill Mollook and steal both his crown and his wife and, without any male heir to the sultan, the crown of the sultan. Throughout the plan, Aladdin is heading for an unlikely rescue with the help of the tricky prince and Basrah's fakir and beggar population. It's good for kids, not really violent (except for two scenes, both involving a doll made to look like a real exotic woman and designed to crush to death those who bog in her embrace) and manages to be at the times very Hollywood and also very convincing arabic at a time. Donald O'Connor manages to steal all the scenes in which he is. It was the kind of film that was on TNT every two or three months, but it's not been for years, so buy this tape."

b'* \'The Defiant Ones\' is one of those rare films that, having been seen once, have been able to stay with me for a lifetime! (Other gems that have had a similar effect on me include Chaplin\'s first "talkie", "The Great Dictator", the original "Night of the Living Dead", the Flick "Laserblast" sci-fi cult, and "Citizen Kane" by Orson Welles I just had the opportunity to buy the DVD and watch this movie for the second time only, and it was as beautiful and intense as I remember this first time! "The Defiant Ones" brings together the legendary Tony Curtis and the legendary and talented Sidney Poitier as convicted criminals John "Joker" Jackson and Noah Cullen who, following a physical brawl between them, contribute in part to the crash. The resulting accident gives these two chained prisoners the opportunity to escape on foot, but it was in the southern United States before the 1960s, when the legal officers responsible for following the pr If the two prisoners know that the two inmates have different racial backgrounds, they mistakenly assume that the two escapees kill you with racial hatred even before they reach five miles. Forced to cooperate despite racial tensions between them, Joker and Noah do not take their situation lightly and are constantly staying as far as possible from their pursuers. In the days that follow, the two men form a sort of difficult camaraderie, and the conversations between them seem to help alleviate some of the racial tensions they show towards each other, to a point of respect for everyone. The other . Joker is also confronted with unpleasant realities, like being forced to admit in his heart that Noah is the most rational of the two and, above all, having to accept the fact that his white skin is not a safety net when he is a criminal escaped on the run. There is also a story of "human interest" in the movie\'s sub-plot, some just ahead of its time: the county sheriff becomes the catalyst that prevents the hunt from becoming a "good old" imprudent and messy boy. Guns, Dawgs & Testosterone Party, and one of the townspeople, portrayed by the legendary Lon Chaney Jr., prevents citizens of a city from becoming an emotionally irrational lynching. Cinematography is excellent for a movie of its day, although some sets may have been better constructed and arranged (for example, there is a set where lights of the city of Los Angeles shine in the background, outside the studio) . It is also nice to hear actors speaking with southern accents that do not look like "Foghorn Leghorn". To think of "redoing" this classic film would not only be a terrible mistake, but it would be a virtual impossibility ... so, fortunately, no one in Hollyweird, or anywhere in the world, would think of doing it. one thing, and so let this great piece of history film stand out and continue to stand the test of time. * * *'

b"I am very disappointed with this movie. Mainly because it seems that we are talking about two different subjects at the same time. On the one hand, the film interviews experts in philosophy and theology, who retrace the history and progression of postmodern thought quite effectively. On the other hand, there are two filmmakers who simply discuss their pointless and sometimes irrelevant discussion ideas. The Williamson brothers pose questions that have little to do with postmodernism and more with their own discontent with the church. It's as if they're doing this film to cast their own ideas and advertise them as a film about postmodernism. Although some interviews with experts are useful for clarifying the trends of postmodern thought, this video as a whole is useless as a whole."

b'The Bride With White Hair 2 quickly followed the success of the original film, taking up the tragic story of Cho Yi-Hang (Leslie Cheung) and her forbidden love Lien Ni-Chang (Brigitte Lin). By betraying his sacred commitment never to doubt his beloved, Cho has unleashed a monster. Ni-Chang\'s fury over Cho\'s betrayal makes her completely mad, turning her into a white-haired witch who only lives to destroy all the living members of the eight clans, especially the Wu Tang clan to which Cho belongs. As for Cho, he retired to Mount Shin Fung, keeping a mystical flower whose blooming (and flowering only once every twenty years) can cleanse and restore the woman he still loves. Ten years have passed since the night of death Chang went crazy and almost destroyed the Wu Tang clan alone. Only two members of the clan survive: Cho, who stands guard at Mount Shin Fung in snowstorm conditions for all these years, and the nephew Kit of Cho (Sunny Chan). With Kit\'s impending marriage with Lyre (Joey Maan), the possibility of continuing the lineage exists - and this is how Ni-Chang blocks the group, kidnaps the bride and brings her back to her own private castle full of men -the deadly women. There, Lyre is indoctrinated in the witch\'s philosophy "See a man, kill a man" and programmed to kill Kit with his own hands. The eight clans send their best warriors to try to kill the witch and save Lyre, but they are almost all helpless against Ni-Chang, who uses his deadly hair as a very effective weapon (it sounds odd, I know, but it works really good). It soon becomes clear that the only person able to defeat the white witch is Cho Yi-Hang, which opens the way to an unforgettable meeting between the two former lovers. This sequel is a more direct, action-oriented film than the The original Bride With White Hair, and for this reason, I found it more pleasant on the surface. Yet, it lacks the depth and beauty of the original, largely because the two lovers do not meet face to face until the final scene - even if this meeting is well worth the wait. Most certainly, if you have seen and enjoyed the original, you will want to experience this suite.'

b"I was really looking forward to the Dinosaur episode of Disney's animated epic. After all, it would be eight and a half years. I do not know exactly what I expected. Do I think that the recent explosion of graphic technology will lead to a corresponding breakthrough in film narration? If so, I had to be naive, because what the Disney powers decided to do was take this dazzling technology and graft a story that would be a recovery from those used in some of their past success. The dinosaur proves that playing safely is not always the best solution. The opening is spectacular. A flock of dinosaurs graze peacefully. We see a mother watching a nest of eggs. Suddenly, a huge carnasour emerges from the woods in search of a dinner. In the chaos that ensues, only one egg survives. What follows is a spectacular series of events in which this egg is transported to a distant island and is populated with mammals rather than dinosaurs. A family of lemurs finds the egg, and it is here that the film begins to disintegrate. Lemurs begin to speak, and this is the first time words are used in the film. I did not expect Disney to make such a different film that none of the characters spoke, but I was surprised to find that they had been taken directly from King Lion and Tarzan. It's as if the African jungles were primitive to Disney World, as if things were happening millions of years ago, it's beyond the imagination of anyone. I can not emphasize enough the beauty of this film. This shows us that CGI technology continues to grow at a breathtaking speed. The camera flies through wonderful landscapes, the dinosaurs are fantastic to watch and the colors are wonderful. One scene in particular, in which the world of dinosaurs is almost destroyed by a spectacular meteor shower, is one of the best animated sequences ever produced. When it comes to history, I wonder how many Disney chefs have children. . One wonders if they make decisions based on the children they see around them or the focus groups. Has he ever thought that anything that fascinates children is not necessarily cute and cuddly or even safe? When I was young, for example, I fell in love with the ocean, not because I thought it was hot and safe, but for deeper reasons, I could not express. I'm not sure what children today think of dinosaurs, but I doubt they consider them as big old puppies or creatures of Judeo-Christian ethics. In this film, the dinosaur that lemurs save is a dinosaur that teaches his fellow creatures that the survival of the fittest is wrong and that's all it's all about. In one way or another, I do not think the average child will buy his arguments, not with respect to wild creatures. I think they will find his preaching a little tedious. Assuming kids take everything and translate it into a fantasy world, Disney underestimated the intelligence of its younger audience and demonstrated that it may have become a bit disconnected from its target market, at least in which concerns particular subject."

When you move from one movement to another, the camera almost never focuses on the teacher\'s feet to see what she\'s doing, so you can only guess. The "class" consists of a group of people totally helpless and struggling with rhythmic difficulties on the lawn of the Royal Hawaiian Hotel. They do not exercise in unison at all, and the camera is usually on them, not on the teacher. You must have hand weights to do the program. For the abs part of the program, the cameraman forgot to focus the camera. The two people are only fuzzy. In addition, there is no need to do abdominal, yoga or pilates on a rebounder. It\'s totally uncomfortable to do it and you can get a much better workout by doing them on a mat, without hurting yourself on the rebounder\'s frame. Although the exercises in the abs and yoga sessions have been good, I strongly recommend getting a different DVD from those who do not bounce, like Yoga Candlelight (very excellent) with Sara Ivanhoe. It has many of the same gestures as the yoga part of this training, but safe, well taught, photographed in a professional manner and, above all, ENTHUSIASM. It was just a very, very boring and repetitive exercise video. Urban Rebounding compilations are not perfect, but they are MUCH better.'

b'An amazing film made in almost impossible circumstances. In Paris, in the 1840s, along a district of theaters (the "Boulevard of Crime"), the story is about a mime (played by Jean-Louis Barrault) who falls in love with a "woman of experience". \'\' - played brilliantly by Arletty. In an incredibly poignant and delicate scene, Arletty asks Barrault to make love to her, but he does not seize the moment and he leaves her. She finds lust in the arms of others. Other main characters include a degenerate philosopher / writer; a Shakespearean actor; a rich account that "keeps" Arletty; and the woman who loves Barrault and finally the wife. But the love between Barrault and Arletty remains true over the years, but in the end, after spending a glorious night together, she leaves him permanently. The acting is superb, but what makes the film a masterpiece is the writing of Jacques Prevert: the dialogue is just great. The film was shot during the Nazi occupation and many actors left the plateau to fight in the resistance. The sets were constantly moved to avoid Nazi bombing and interference, as far as possible. The film lasts about 190 minutes; the Nazis had a law that no film could exceed 90 minutes, so this was done as TWO independent films. The film is not only a testimony of love in all its intensity (it\'s a French film after all), it is also about the survival of a country and a big city, Paris - a whole civilization, in reality of a fierce oppressor: it is the light of love and culture and the memory that always shines from the darkness of hell. An amazing feat in all phases of the production process, from the message of history to the scenery, staging and photography: it is a film of all time.'

b'I have been practicing yoga regularly for about a year. I am familiar with Vinyasa flow and Hatha yoga, and enjoy both. Unfortunately, Sybel\'s yoga was a disappointment. I kept thinking that she did not know what kind of yoga she was doing: it was a concentrated pose like Hatha, but the pace was extremely fast (faster than most Vinyasa I did) and there was really no flow to the movements. She jumped directly into the poses without focusing on her breathing, and instead of moving to warm the body, she began with stretching poses. This confusing pattern continued throughout the DVD as she moved from strength, stretching and relaxation to seemingly random. Each pose was held for only 2-3 seconds before continuing, and the reminders for "inhaling, exhaling" were far too fast for a good calming yoga breath. Although Sybel mentions in his opening speech that his yoga is for people of all levels, many of the poses included in this DVD are too advanced for beginners and would require a lot of modifications for someone who is not in fine fettle.'

b"Well, I saw that in Costco yesterday and I took it because it's one of my favorite movies of my childhood. My little brother and I used to rent this VHS to our local rental agency every year towards the start of the summer vacation. The film itself is ideal for a TV movie, it is just as good if not better than the animation of the series. The show itself has five stars, so why did I give it two stars? . . The quality is zero. If you put it in a computer and you check its size, it is only 3.7 GB, not even an 8 GB DVD. So they used the cheap method and used a single layer DVD. You can tell it when you play it because it is an interlaced DVD, interlaced Google DVD for more information. Basically, it's for playing on old TVs, not on today's HDTVs. It also seems that they used an old VHS for the rip instead of using original sources or even a LaserDisc, these record-size DVD discs, they were of much better quality than the VHS and did not degrade with the time as VHS. If they pulled off one of those, it would look a lot better. They also do not have much time to create menus, when you go watch trailers and change languages, it's a light blue menu without any sound. I could have done a better job with free software on the menus. In addition, the records were made in Mexico, they could not even splurge to make them in the United States. I'm glad it's on DVD now, but for something I've been waiting for a long time, I'm upset is so low quality. I can improve the quality a bit by tearing it up and using a Decomb filter to eliminate the intertwining, but why on earth could not they just bring out a better product? I also know some people with LaserDisc players, I could just buy the LaserDisc of this product and have it rip for me, burn it to DVD and put it in this case. The case is nice and looks good with my other DVDs and Blurays."

b'I had this video with the understanding that it will provide me with the basics of yoga, and that I will gradually become better at yoga and more comfortable practicing it. b'As for the plot, here\'s what the back of the box says: "Edward Carnby (Christian Slater) is a private researcher specializing in inexplicable supernatural phenomena. His business plunges into the dark corners of the world, searching for the truth in the hidden vestiges of ancient civilizations. Now, the greatest mystery of his past is about to become the most dangerous case he has ever faced. With the help of his ex-girlfriend, archeologist Aline Cedrac (Tara Reid), and his fierce rival, government agent Richard Burke (Stephen Dorff), Edward is about to learn that it\'s It\'s not because t means it can not kill you! "According to the character of Carnby, the fear of the dark is what keeps us alive. Unfortunately, the fear of crappy movies does not prevent us from praising them. Despite the horrible reviews, I decided to give in to the temptation to rent Alone In The Dark (I had a free rental, so I thought there could be no loss). It was even worse than I expected ... First, creatures that are liberated from the depths of darkness - or any other clich\xc3\xa9 object in history - are pathetic CGI dino-beasts. Something interesting, scary or just "cool" about them? Nope . Just useless computer-generated monsters that fail to entertain the public in any way. For two, the acting is horrible. Seeing Tara Reid on the main credits of the DVD made me roll my eyes, but seeing her try to play the role of archaeologist in a sci-fi action movie just made me laugh. Christian Slater is the only decent mid-actor, but that is not enough to cover the rest. And for three, the film is terribly boring, with few action scenes. Oh, of course, some unknown bumps here and there, creatures flashing across the screen, and a little gore is included. But the real action? Very little . The small amounts of action he has included are the reason why I gave two stars to this worst. I hate to see a movie suffer, but this one deserves it. In conclusion, do not make the same mistakes as most of these critics by praising the movie, knowing how terrible it must be. Just trust the ratings on this one. This will save you money and time.'

b'In 1879, a British column was almost annihilated by a great "impi" of Zulu warriors near Isandhlwana. Subsequently, a small British force camped near Rorke \'s Drift (a trading station and a mission) consisting of 104 soldiers and a number of disabled in a makeshift hospital became the next target. For two days, the station was attacked by waves of Zulu warriors. The total number of attackers was about 4500. In the end, nearly 400 Zulus were killed compared to only about twenty defenders, the hospital was burned down and 11 victims of the Victoria Cross were handed over. to the survivors. The film itself is a fairly faithful reconstruction of events. at Rorke \'s Drift, with a good rendition of Michael Caine, Stanley Baker, and a wide cast of Zulus. The ferocity of the assault, the stubborn and obstinate defense of the small garrison and the chaos of hand-to-hand combat in the barricades are felt through cinematography. A wonderful aspect of this film is that the battle scenes were shot using a large number of actors in the role of Zulu warriors, who were obviously able to recreate the tactics and movement of the real army of 1879. Their screams of war, their synchronized spear-to-shield movements and advancing formation create the feeling of a real army that attacks the seemingly doomed garrison. This is one of the few films that gives the viewer an idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bwhat the fight must have been at a time when mechanized armies appeared.'

b"That's what you expect from Monty Python guys. It's silly, irreverent and completely strange. The special effect does not compare much with that of other Python films made in the 1970s and it was made in 1989. The performances of the Monty Python distribution are not the best, but they are fun and satisfying. The thing is not really important. Erik the Viking is a good entertaining story with some thoughtful but subtle observations about the human condition and religion. Even if the darkest things end up not being so serious. This DVD is really hard to find and, to make matters worse, Sony has developed a Cut's Director, but has never bothered to release it in the United States. If you have a DVD without a region, there is a director sound available in the UK, so there is hope. If you find the rare American version for a reasonable price, I advise you to get it without asking questions, because Sony has made no announcement to make reissues. Those of you who do not get Python-esque humor will not appreciate that either. If you like the humor side mixed with mythic Nordic stories (and do not criticize low production budgets), then this movie should be a good diversion of reality."

b'We all got to know Clint Eastwood through his work. The countless first television shows and Western films in which he played introduced us to him. His role went from Star to Superstar in his epic portrayals of "Dirty Harry," the homicide inspector. Since then, we have seen his excellence as a director in many excellent dramas and westerns. Although controversial, we examined his morality and sense of compassion beyond the cultural senses of morality in Million Dollar Baby. Clint Eastwood directs and plays in a movie where he is retired drinking beer and smoking cigarettes on the verandah, scolding everyone, his neighbors, his wartime experiences and his own family! In Gran Torino, he shows that it is possible to teach an old dog new tricks. Always immersed in hatred, fanaticism and racial stereotypes, he is slowly transformed by his Hmong immigrant neighbors. As he takes a young Hmong teenager under his wing (although at first he was made to protect the only thing he really likes, his vintage, 1972 Gran Torino state), he keeps young Thao away from aimless Gang-Bangers and "Mans" Thao. (As a result, he discovered that emotionally, he discovers that, emotionally, he has much more in common with the ethics of immigrants than with his own parents! Like `` Walt \'\' softens and learns to appreciate the Immigrant\'s generosity and hospitality, we see the true heart of our "Dirty Harry." He has more reason to be in life now than to hate everyone and to love his Gran Torino When young Thao is a man enough to go to the rendezvous, Walt even allows him to use the Gran Torino to get the girl out in style! And when the neighborhood gang threatens and tries to kill the family Walt brings out the dirty Harry himself and sacrifices himself to protect the people who have adopted the "old bastard" as one of them! "Walt\'s last request was to give Thao his Gran Torino In the last scene, when we see Thao driving the old Gran Torino de Walt, the grimacing grille car like Walt did, the joy on Thao\'s face reveals that not only does Thao lead Walt\'s soul. but the soul of Walt has been transplanted to the young Thao! If anything that Clint Eastwood did in this film is worth it: show how, in a changing America, embracing and celebrating diversity in this country, we are all strengthening what the country is made of in the first place! "One among many others"'

b"When a nuclear submarine suddenly falls in the Pacific Ocean and a hurricane prevents the army from being able to send a crew after this operation, it subcontracts an underwater drilling team near Bud Brigman (Ed Harris ). To help the drilling team, the army sends a SEAL group of the Navy led by Lieutenant Coffey (Michael Biehn) accompanied by the designer of the underwater oil rig and his wife Lindsey Brigman (Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio ). But as they search the nuclear submarine, they realize that the sinking of the submarine may be bigger than expected, and that Lieutenant Coffey believes that the Russians are responsible, the crew believes he could there is something more ... supernatural There are few directors who really know how to outdo each effort as James Cameron does. His first film, The Terminator, set a precedent for action movies in the 80s, and he only stood out with Terminator 2. With Aliens, he made a film at least equal to Ridley's Alien Scott making a suite that changed the mood and style while respecting the original. In 1989, James Cameron directed The Abyss, a film that took place mainly underwater and was shot in the largest underwater ensemble of the time. The set, built in a half-finished nuclear reactor facility, included 7 million gallons of water. So, among the other achievements of Cameron, how is The Abyss? The Abyss is certainly Cameron's most underrated film. By watching movies such as Avatar, Aliens, The Terminator and Terminator 2, it's easy to see how a film like The Abyss can be forgotten, but if you take a closer look, The Abyss works well with others. Like Cameron's other films, he shows great attention to detail, with amazing special effects. On a technical level, the movie looks like real life, something that is always great when it comes to a Cameron movie. But as with Cameron's other films, it's not about the special effects but about the human element. Cameron does a great job of humanizing his characters and developing their relationships. The game is phenomenal, of course, I would not expect anything else from a movie including Michael Biehn (The Terminator, Aliens) and Ed Harris (The Truman Show), The Rock). Biehn is doing very well as a soldier who has lost contact with the outside world and must make calls for his next move, and that drives him crazy. Ed Harris is great as a hard ass leader looking for his ex-wife who keeps running away without him, and Marry Elizabeth Mastrantonio is awesome as the aforementioned wife who gets stuck with Bud and his repulsive crew, but grew up close to the husband she had left and the crew he manages. If you have not seen this movie, but you like Cameron's other movies, I strongly recommend you to give this shot. I would say that this movie is perhaps even better than The Terminator, and since I think the Aliens are better than The Terminator, I think it's exactly like Aliens. Give it a shot, it's definitely a sleeper classic that deserves more exposure than it gets."

b'I was terribly excited to discover that one of my favorite classic films, the 1963 Peter Brooks "Lord of the Flies" was on DVD, I was even more excited when I saw that He had received a luxury treatment from a studio called Criterion. "Lord of the Flies" was the first DVD I bought and he introduced me to the phenomenal Criterion collection. DVD is fantastic and interesting, there is no compliment or praise without meaning.The comment alone is worth the price of this DVD, it gives a magnificent overview of how this film was made: for example, the film was one of the first independent productions ever produced and is one of those rare comments that adds to your appreciation and understanding of the film Seven Samurai & "Grand Illusion & quot; (also both Criterion dvds) comments among the best I\'ve heard them The movie itself is absolutely fantastic, worlds better than any vhs or laserdisc edition I\'ve ever seen; The criterion has produced an astonishing and crisp image that will strike any video. The lord of the flies is one of my favorite novels; Golding has masterfully touched many themes and concepts of society and has managed to capture the essence of humanity in the boy caricatures he created. For the most part, these themes and ideas are very faithful to the movie. As stated in the DVD commentary; there is no credit for the script because there was no script, the production team worked directly from the novel, using it as the sole source of the story. The result is a remarkably clear and coherent adaptation of the original novel, animated with great faith and surprising feats for a novice filmmaker. Some technical limitations can still be observed in the final product, but they do not reduce the pleasure of your film. In short: a fantastic, dark and captivating story is brilliantly animated in such a way that it sometimes seems to look at the viewer as a documentary in progress. Finally, to top it off, the film received a royal treatment on DVD that perfectly complements and improves the film itself; in all, the price of entry is very high.'

b'Ghost World is a story of transition to adulthood that defines the character of a generation that is one of the most elusive of modern memory. Enid (Thora Birch) is stuck in a small town with peers and adults who are not going anywhere. According to him, only Norman, the long-time passenger, perhaps because he tries at least to leave the city, is not something to say to the public, but rather to think about it. a thoughtful film with attractive characters, a quick wit and a gentle warmth. The composition including the use of color in the set and the costume is lush and crisp; the editing and the camera are very expressive. I highly recommend this film to anyone who wants to better understand the life and problems of middle-class youth struggling with identity research at the end of the twentieth century.'

b'As a veteran of Marine and Vietnam, I do not agree with Mr. Brennan\'s portrait of the second half of this film. The war scenes were at best marginal and failed to capture the "realism" of the war ... The peloton was much better in this respect. Mainly because Oliver Stone was a veteran himself. However, the training camp scenes in the FMJ were accurate. R.Lee Ermey played to perfection as he should have done with the Drill Instructor, having been the same in real life. I had several D.I. It\'s like that in training camp and I can assure you that it was like that during the Vietnam War. I can laugh at the movie now, but while in training camp there was nothing to laugh about, we were there to learn to fight and to go to war, other skills were learned, but they were secondary. We had to be tough and they made sure we were. Part of the training camp was almost like a documentary for me! That said, the film was like two parts for me. The first half and the second half. One being dead and the other so little and completely based on a Hollywood perception of the war. For those who were not there, believe me ... It was very different from this version. All in all, thanks to the performance of R. Lee Ermey and Vincent D\'Onofrio, I give him 4 stars.'
